**EU MIFID II product governance / Professional investors and ECPs only target market**

Solely for the purposes of each manufacturer's product approval process, the target market assessment
in respect of the Notes has led to the conclusion that: (i) the target market for the Notes is eligible
counterparties and professional clients only, each as defined in Directive 2014/65/EU (as amended, "EU
**MiFID II"); and (ii) all channels for distribution of the Notes to eligible counterparties and professional clients**
are appropriate. Any person subsequently offering, selling or recommending the Notes (a "distributor")
should take into consideration the manufacturers' target market assessment; however, a distributor subject
to EU MiFID II is responsible for undertaking its own target market assessment in respect of the Notes (by
either adopting or refining the manufacturers' target market assessment) and determining appropriate
distribution channels.

**UK MiFIR product governance / Professional investors and ECPs only target market**

Solely for the purposes of each manufacturer's product approval process, the target market assessment
in respect of the Notes has led to the conclusion that: (i) the target market for the Notes is only eligible
counterparties, as defined in the FCA Handbook Conduct of Business Sourcebook ("COBS"), and
professional clients, as defined in Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue
of the EUWA ("UK MiFIR"); and (ii) all channels for distribution of the Notes to eligible counterparties and
professional clients are appropriate. Any distributor should take into consideration the manufacturers' target
market assessment; however, a distributor subject to the FCA Handbook Product Intervention and Product
Governance Sourcebook (the "UK MiFIR Product Governance Rules") is responsible for undertaking its
own target market assessment in respect of the Notes (by either adopting or refining the manufacturers'
target market assessment) and determining appropriate distribution channels.

**EU PRIIPs Regulation/Prohibition of Sales to EEA Investors**

The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered,
sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in the EEA. For these purposes, a retail investor


-----

means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of EU MiFID
II; or (ii) a customer within the meaning of Directive (EU) 2016/97 (the "Insurance Distribution Directive"),
where that customer would not qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of EU
MiFID II. Consequently no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 (the "EU
**PRIIPs Regulation") for offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors**
in the EEA has been prepared and therefore offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them
available to any retail investor in the EEA may be unlawful under the EU PRIIPS Regulation.

**UK PRIIPs Regulation/Prohibition of Sales to UK Retail Investors**

The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered,
sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in the United Kingdom. For these purposes, a retail
investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client, as defined in point (8) of Article 2 of
Regulation (EU) No 2017/565 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA; (ii) a customer within
the meaning of the provisions of the FSMA and any rules or regulations made under the FSMA to implement
the Insurance Distribution Directive, where that customer would not qualify as a professional client, as
defined in point (8) of Article 2(1) of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue
of the EUWA. Consequently, no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 as
it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA (the "UK PRIIPs Regulation") for offering or selling the
Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the United Kingdom has been prepared and,
therefore, offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the United
Kingdom may be unlawful under the UK PRIIPs Regulation.

**EU MIFID II product governance / Professional investors and ECPs only target market**

Solely for the purposes of each manufacturer's product approval process, the target market assessment
in respect of the Notes has led to the conclusion that: (i) the target market for the Notes is eligible
counterparties and professional clients only, each as defined in Directive 2014/65/EU (as amended, "EU
**MiFID II"); and (ii) all channels for distribution of the Notes to eligible counterparties and professional clients**
are appropriate. Any person subsequently offering, selling or recommending the Notes (a "distributor")
should take into consideration the manufacturers' target market assessment; however, a distributor subject
to EU MiFID II is responsible for undertaking its own target market assessment in respect of the Notes (by
either adopting or refining the manufacturers' target market assessment) and determining appropriate
distribution channels.

**UK MiFIR product governance / Professional investors and ECPs only target market**

Solely for the purposes of each manufacturer's product approval process, the target market assessment
in respect of the Notes has led to the conclusion that: (i) the target market for the Notes is only eligible
counterparties, as defined in the FCA Handbook Conduct of Business Sourcebook ("COBS"), and
professional clients, as defined in Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue
of the EUWA ("UK MiFIR"); and (ii) all channels for distribution of the Notes to eligible counterparties and
professional clients are appropriate. Any distributor should take into consideration the manufacturers' target
market assessment; however, a distributor subject to the FCA Handbook Product Intervention and Product
Governance Sourcebook (the "UK MiFIR Product Governance Rules") is responsible for undertaking its
own target market assessment in respect of the Notes (by either adopting or refining the manufacturers'
target market assessment) and determining appropriate distribution channels.

**_European Economic Area_**

**EU PRIIPs Regulation/Prohibition of Sales to EEA Investors**

Each Initial Purchaser has represented, warranted and agreed that it has not offered, sold or otherwise
made available to and will not offer, sell or otherwise make available the Notes to any retail investor in the
European Economic Area (the "EEA"). For these purposes, a retail investor means a person who is one
(or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of EU MiFID II or (ii) a customer within
the meaning of Directive 2016/97/EU (the "Insurance Distribution Directive"), where that customer would
not qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of EU MiFID II. Consequently no
key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 (the "EU PRIIPs Regulation") for
offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the EEA has been
prepared and therefore offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail
investor in the EEA may be unlawful under the EU PRIIPs Regulation.

January 1, 2019 as described below.

The preparation of financial statements in conformity with IFRS requires the use of certain critical
accounting estimates. It also requires management to exercise its judgment in the process of applying our
accounting policies. The areas involving a higher degree of judgment or complexity, or areas where
assumptions and estimates are significant to the financial statements, are disclosed in the Financial
Statements. See "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
_Operations—Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates."_

In making an investment decision, you must rely upon your own examination of the terms of this Offering
and the financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum. Prospective investors should consult
their professional advisors for an understanding of: (i) the differences between IFRS, generally accepted
accounting principles in the United States of America ("U.S. GAAP"), UK GAAP and other systems of
generally accepted accounting principles and how these differences might affect the financial information
included in this Offering Memorandum, and (ii) the impact that future additions to, or amendments of IFRS
principles may have on our results of operations and/or financial condition, as well as on the comparability
of the prior periods.

With respect to the 2019 Financial Statements, the Company applied the new IFRS 16 (Leases)
accounting standard, effective from January 1, 2019, using the modified retrospective approach, as defined
by the IFRS 16 accounting standard. The cumulative effects of applying this new accounting standard were
therefore recognised as an adjustment to retained earnings as of January 1, 2019 (the date of initial
application), while comparative figures were not restated. Additionally, previous lease-related balances
including operating lease prepayments, onerous lease provisions and straight-line rent accruals have been
derecognised as part of the Company's adoption of IFRS 16. The 2017 Financial Statements and the 2018
Financial Statements have not been restated for the adoption of IFRS 16 and thus cannot be directly
compared to the 2019 Financial Statements, and the Company has not otherwise restated comparative
amounts as of and for the years ended December 31, 2017 or 2018. IFRS 16 eliminates the classification
of leases as either operating leases or finance leases for lessees and introduces a single lessee accounting
model with some exemptions for short-term and low-value leases. The lessee recognises a right-of-use
asset representing its right to use the underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to
make lease payments. The effect of applying IFRS 16 is to align the presentation of leases more closely to
that of owned assets, rent expense is no longer deducted in arriving at operating profit or EBITDA and
instead profit before tax includes an interest charge on the unwinding of the lease liability and a depreciation
charge on the right of use asset. As a result of the adoption of IFRS 16, right of use assets of
£2,263.9 million and additional lease liabilities of £1,979.4 million were recognised as of January 1, 2019,
and operating costs decreased by £31.4 million and finance costs increased by £52.7 million compared
with lease-related expenses charged in the prior year under IAS 17. See note 1 ("Accounting Policies") of
the 2019 Financial Statements. For the avoidance of doubt, the historical financial information provided in
this Offering Memorandum in relation to IFRS 16 does not reflect the potential impact of the Forecourt
Assets Separation and the leases of the Select Retail Assets, the Substitute Retail Assets and the
Distribution Assets.

**Non-IFRS Financial Measures**

In this Offering Memorandum the Company presents certain financial measures that are not required
by or presented in accordance with IFRS (the "Non-IFRS Measures"). The Non-IFRS Measures included
in this Offering Memorandum do not alone provide a sufficient basis to compare the ASDA Group's
performance with that of other companies and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for
an equivalent IFRS measure (if applicable) or any other generally accepted measure as an indicator of
operating performance or liquidity. Such non-IFRS financial information has not been audited or reviewed
by Ernst & Young LLP.

We believe that the presentation of the Non-IFRS Measures enhances an investor's understanding of
our operating performance and our ability to service our debt. In addition, we believe that EBITDA is a
measure commonly used by investors. The Company's Non-IFRS Measures may not be directly
comparable with similarly titled measures used by other companies. The EBITDA Measures (as defined
below) and related leverage and coverage ratios are not measurements of financial performance under
IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to other indicators of our operating performance, cash
flows or any other measure of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. You are encouraged to
evaluate each of the adjustments reflected in the Company's presentation of the Non-IFRS Measures and
whether you consider each to be appropriate. In addition, each of the Non-IFRS Measures may be defined
differently from the definitions of corresponding or similar terms under the Indentures. The Company's NonIFRS Measures have important limitations as analytical tools. Some limitations of the Non-IFRS Measures
include:

3


-----

  - they do not reflect the interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service interest or
principal payments on the Company's debt;

  - they do not reflect any cash income and certain other taxes that the Company may be required to
pay;

  - they are not adjusted for all cash income or expense items that are reflected in the Company's
statements of cash flows;

  - they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters the Company
considers not to be indicative of its ongoing operations;

  - following the implementation of IFRS 16, they do not reflect any expense relating to leased assets
classified as interest or depreciation;

  - in respect of Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and the other Non-IFRS Measures
that reflect such measures, they reflect certain adjustments for anticipated cost savings, synergies
and other estimates that may not be realised, whether in part or at all; and

  - they may not fully take into account the impact of COVID-19 on the Company's financial
performance.

Furthermore, you should carefully consider the risks and limitations of the Non-IFRS Measures, as they
are based in part on assumptions made by the Company's management regarding the future impact of
actions that have not yet been, and which may not in fact be, implemented. For example, there is a risk
that the synergies we seek to achieve may not be realised in the anticipated time frame or at all and that
the magnitude of cost savings may be significantly less than expected.

Because of these limitations, our Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of
discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will
be available to us to meet our obligations, including in relation to the Notes offered hereby. You should
compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on the ASDA Group's IFRS results and using these
Non-IFRS Measures only in a supplemental manner to evaluate the ASDA Group's performance.

Our primary Non-IFRS Measures are defined as follows:

_EBITDA_

EBITDA, when used in this Offering Memorandum, is calculated by adding back to the Company's profit
for the period income tax expense, finance income, finance costs and amortisation and depreciation. By
eliminating potential differences in results of operations between periods caused by factors such as
depreciation and amortisation, financing and capital structures and taxation positions or regimes, we
believe EBITDA can provide a useful additional basis for comparing our operating performance with
industry peers.

_EBITDA Margin_

EBITDA Margin means the Company's EBITDA as a percentage of total revenue for the relevant period.

_Adjusted EBITDA_

Adjusted EBITDA, when used in this Offering Memorandum, means the Company's EBITDA for a
particular period as adjusted for certain historical costs, including impairment charges for both tangible,
intangible and leased assets, asset write-offs, elimination of IFRS 16 impact, pension guarantees, share
option costs and the removal of one-time items including ATM ("Automated Teller Machines") tax rebates,
one-off bonus payments, one-off contract implementation costs, estimated merger costs in relation to the
proposed merger with Sainsburys, increased pension contributions as a result of changes in eligibility
criteria and restructuring costs relating to significant restructuring programmes.

4


-----

_Adjusted EBITDA Margin_

Adjusted EBITDA Margin means the Company's Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of total revenue
(including petrol) for the relevant period.

_Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA_

_Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA, when used in this Offering Memorandum, means the Company's Adjusted_
EBITDA for a particular period as adjusted for the removal of Walmart royalties and IT costs and their
replacement with new costs under the TSA with Walmart, other adjustments including the impact of the
2020 leap year and estimated costs relating to ASDA operating as a standalone group, one-off net impact
of costs and benefits associated with COVID-19 and adjustment for certain anticipated cost savings, EG
foodservice partnership synergies, synergies from the roll-out of the ASDA wholesale convenience
business, the EBITDA associated with the Forecourt Assets and the Excluded Forecourts and the rent
associated with the Warehouse Assets and Select Retail Assets.

The Company believes that EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA (collectively,
the "EBITDA Measures") provide useful information to investors about its results of operations for the
following reasons: (a) they are, or will be going forward, among the measures used by the Company's
Board of Directors and management to evaluate the ASDA Group's underlying operating performance,
review business trends, identify strategies to improve results and make day-to-day operating decisions,
and (b) they allow a comparison of the Company's results across periods and results across companies in
the industry in which the ASDA Group operates on a consistent basis, by removing the effects on the ASDA
Group's operating performance of its capital structure (such as the varying levels of interest expense), asset
base and capital investment cycle (such as depreciation and amortisation) and items largely outside the
control of management (such as income taxes).

None of the EBITDA Measures should be considered in isolation or as a substitute for measures of the
ASDA Group's operating performance reported in accordance with IFRS. The EBITDA Measures have
limitations as analytical tools, some of which are as follows:

  - the EBITDA Measures do not reflect the Group's cash expenditures or future requirements for
capital investments or contractual commitments;

  - the EBITDA Measures do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, the Group's working
capital needs;

  - none of the EBITDA Measures reflects the interest expense on the Group's debt or the cash
requirements necessary to service interest or principal payments on the Group's debt;

  - although depreciation and amortisation are non-cash charges, assets are depreciated or amortised
over differing estimated useful lives and the assets being depreciated and amortised will often have
to be replaced in the future, and the EBITDA Measures do not reflect any cash requirements for
such replacements;

  - the EBITDA Measures exclude certain tax payments that may represent a reduction in cash
available to the Group;

  - the EBITDA Measures are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected
in the Company's income statement;

  - other companies in the industry in which the Group operates may calculate their own EBITDA
measures differently than the Company does, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures;

  - our calculation and presentation of the EBITDA Measures in this Offering Memorandum is similar
to, but different from, the calculation of Consolidated EBITDA under the Indentures governing the
Notes offered hereby or the agreements governing our Revolving Credit Facilities. In particular,
EBITDA reflects the adoption of IFRS 16 by the Company effective January 1, 2019, while Adjusted
EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA calculations under the Indentures may not. Accordingly
the EBITDA Measures do not provide precise indications as to the level of our adherence to the
terms of our Indentures and the agreements governing our Revolving Credit Facilities; and

  - certain adjustments made in calculating Adjusted EBITDA and _Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA_
contain estimates that management believes reflect the underlying results of operations and are
therefore subjective in nature and reflect certain adjustments for anticipated cost savings,
synergies and other estimates that may not be realised, whether in part or at all.

_Like-for-like sales growth (excluding petrol)_

Like-for-like sales growth (excluding petrol) is a measure of annual growth of sales (excluding VAT)

5


-----

calculated as comparable current year sales minus prior year sales for the current year comparable sales
divided by prior year sales for the current year comparable sales. Current year comparable sales includes
all revenue except petrol sales, sales generated from stores in the first twelve complete calendar months
following grand opening, sales generated from stores that have permanently closed, sales generated from
stores that have been temporarily closed for more than two consecutive complete calendar months within
the previous twelve full calendar months, financial services commissions, toyou sales and George
international franchise sales.

_Free Cash Flow_

Free Cash Flow is calculated as Adjusted EBITDA less capital expenditure. The ASDA Group uses Free
Cash Flow as a liquidity measure to monitor cash flow generation.

The Company presents Free Cash Flow because, in the Company's view, it provides investors with
useful information about the Company's underlying ability to generate and extract cash flows from its
various subsidiaries in order to make interest and principal payments on the Group's debt, including the
Notes offered hereby.

Free Cash Flow is not a measure of liquidity under IFRS and has limitations as an analytical tool, some
of which are as follows:

  - it does not represent the residual cash flow available for discretionary expenditures by the ASDA
Group, particularly because, in the case of pre-tax free cash flow, the ASDA Group's various tax
payment obligations are not deducted from such measure;

  - it does not deduct cash flows used by the ASDA Group in financing activities;

  - it is not a direct measurement of cash flows and attempts to derive and measure the ASDA Group's
ability to service debt from income statement data of the Company. Accordingly, it does not directly
correlate to the actual collection of cash. In addition, Free Cash Flow does not take into account
changes in working capital of the ASDA Group that are otherwise factored in when calculating its
net cash from operating activities;

  - it does not deduct certain other items settled in cash; and

  - other companies in the industries in which the ASDA Group operates may calculate Free Cash
Flow differently than it does, limiting its usefulness as a comparative measure.

_Cash Conversion_

Cash conversion is defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA.

_Capital expenditure_

Capital expenditure is defined as the total cost of assets classified as property, plant and equipment and
intangible assets that the Company takes ownership of within a financial period (as opposed to the IFRS
measurement of capital expenditure, which is based on cash flows).

_Pro forma net debt_

_Pro forma net debt consists of the Issuers' pro forma indebtedness in respect of the Notes, the Term_
Loan Facilities and leases, net of ASDA's estimated average cash and cash equivalents from January 4 to
February 2, 2021 (inclusive), as adjusted to give pro forma effect to the consummation of the Transactions
on the Acquisition Completion Date. Pro forma net debt does not include any indebtedness in respect of
the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, which is expected to be repaid from the proceeds of the
Warehouse Sale Transactions, or the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility, which is expected to be repaid
with the proceeds of the Forecourt Assets Disposal. See "Capitalisation." Our presentation and calculation
of the ratio of _Pro forma_ net debt to _Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA is different from the calculation of_
Consolidated Net Leverage Ratio under the Indentures and the Senior Facilities Agreement and is not
indicative of our level of adherence to the terms of the Indentures or the Senior Facilities Agreement. See
"Description of the Senior Secured Notes," "Description of the Senior Notes" and "Description of Certain
_Financing Arrangements."_

6


-----

_Pro forma net senior secured debt_

_Pro forma net senior secured debt consists of the Issuers'_ _pro forma indebtedness in respect of the_
Senior Secured Notes and the Term Loan Facilities, net of ASDA's estimated average cash and cash
equivalents from January 4 to February 2, 2021 (inclusive), as adjusted to give _pro forma effect to the_
consummation of the Transactions on the Acquisition Completion Date. Pro forma net senior secured debt
does not include any indebtedness in respect of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, which is
expected to be repaid from the proceeds of the Warehouse Sale Transactions, or the Forecourt Disposal
Bridge Facility, which is expected to be repaid with the proceeds of the Forecourt Assets Disposal. See
"Capitalisation." Our presentation and calculation of the ratio of Pro forma net senior secured debt to Pro
_forma Adjusted EBITDA is different from the calculation of Consolidated Senior Secured Net Leverage_
Ratio under the Indentures and the Senior Facilities Agreement and is not indicative of our level of
adherence to the terms of the Indentures or the Senior Facilities Agreement. See "Description of the Senior
_Secured Notes" and "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements."_

_Pro forma interest expense_

_Pro forma interest expense reflects the blended interest expense associated with the Notes, Term Loan_
Facilities and our leases for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020, as if the Transactions had occurred
on October 1, 2019. Pro forma interest expense excludes charges related to allocated debt issuance costs,
leases of Warehouse Assets or Select Retail Assets or other indebtedness. Pro forma interest expense
has been presented for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to represent what our interest
expense would have actually been had the above mentioned transactions occurred on the date assumed,
nor does it purport to project our interest expense for any future period or our financial condition at any
future date.

**Reconciliation of Non-IFRS Measures**

We present a reconciliation of the EBITDA Measures, Free Cash Flow and Cash Conversion to the
most directly comparable measure calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS and discuss their
limitations. For a reconciliation of these Non-IFRS Measures and such discussions, see "Summary
_Consolidated Financial and Other Financial Data—Other Financial Data."_

**Other Financial, Operational and As Adjusted Data**

This Offering Memorandum includes certain key performance indicators and other financial, nonfinancial operational and as adjusted data. This information has been provided for informational purposes
only and should not be considered indicative of actual results that would have been achieved had the as
adjusted for transactions been completed on the dates indicated and do not purport to indicate our future
consolidated results of operations or financial position. Our use or computation of these indicators may not
be comparable with the use or computation of similarly titled measures reported by other companies. None
of the key performance indicators or other non-financial operating data included in this Offering
Memorandum should be considered in isolation or as an alternative to any indicator of our operating
performance, cash flows or other measure of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. See
"Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information and Other Financial Data." These data have been
prepared solely for the purpose of this Offering Memorandum, some of which may not be prepared in the
ordinary course of our financial reporting, may not be part of our financial statements and may not have
not been audited.

**Rounding Adjustments**

Certain numerical figures set out in this Offering Memorandum, including financial data presented in
millions or thousands, certain operating data, percentages describing market share and penetration rates,
have been subject to rounding adjustments and, as a result, the totals of the data included in this Offering
Memorandum may vary slightly from the actual arithmetic totals of such information. Percentages and
amounts reflecting changes over time periods relating to financial and other data set forth in the sections
entitled _"Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations"_ are
calculated using the numerical data in the consolidated financial information of the Company or the tabular
presentation of other data (subject to rounding) contained in this Offering Memorandum, as applicable, and
not using the numerical data in the narrative description thereof. Figures shown as totals in some tables
and elsewhere may not be exact arithmetic aggregations of the figures that precede them.

**BROKERS' OPINIONS OF PRICING**

**The Brokers' Opinions of Pricing**

The Issuers received a broker's opinion of pricing dated November 26, 2020 and prepared as of October
20, 2020 issued by external real estate adviser Newsteer Real Estate Advisers ("Newsteer") related to the
ASDA Group's portfolio of 485 properties comprising 483 trading stores and two offices held on a freehold
and long leasehold basis (the "ASDA Store and Office Portfolio") (inclusive of the Select Retail Assets
and the Substitute Retail Assets) and a broker's opinion of pricing dated November 17, 2020 and prepared
as of October 20, 2020 issued by external real estate adviser Colliers International ("Colliers") related to
the ASDA Group's portfolio of 31 distribution sites held on a freehold and long leasehold basis (the "ASDA
**Distribution Sites Portfolio" and, together with the ASDA Store and Office Portfolio, the "ASDA Property**
**Portfolio") (the broker's opinion of pricing from Newsteer and the broker's opinion of pricing from Colliers**
are referred to collectively in this Offering Memorandum as the "Brokers' Opinions of Pricing"). The ASDA
Property Portfolio does not, and thus the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing do not, include certain other
properties, including retail rack-rented leasehold properties (131 properties), office leasehold properties
(one property), standalone petrol forecourts (18 properties), non-operational properties (ten freehold
properties and seven leasehold properties) and non-UK properties (five properties). The Brokers' Opinions
of Pricing also do not include opinions of pricing relating to petrol forecourts on a standalone basis (save
that where trading stores benefit from petrol forecourts, Newsteer has reflected the existence of petrol
forecourts with an addition of 5% to the base shell rental pricing for the relevant trading stores). Additionally,
the ASDA Property Portfolio does not, and thus the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing do not, reflect any income
received from tenants, concessions or third-party interests.

The Brokers' Opinions of Pricing are intended to be guides to the likely pricing of the ASDA Property
Portfolio prior to negotiation and/or agency instructions as may occur during a routine sales process. The
Brokers' Opinions of Pricing were not prepared in accordance with the Royal Institution of Chartered
Surveyors' Valuation–Global Standards (the "RICS Red Book Global Standards").

**Key Findings**

Subject to the facts, assumptions and qualifications set out in the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing and
summarised below, the ASDA Store and Office Portfolio had an aggregate capital pricing of £9,354,700,000
as of October 20, 2020 (based on 485 sites). The ASDA Distribution Sites Portfolio had an aggregate capital
pricing of £925,700,000 (based on 31 sites) as of October 20, 2020. The Select Retail Assets had an
aggregate capital pricing of £483,794,000 (based on 23 sites) and the Substitute Retail Assets had an
aggregate capital pricing of £639,501,000 (based on 15 sites), in each case as of October 20, 2020. The
capital pricing of the properties located in each of the jurisdictions where real estate will be pledged as
collateral (including the Select Retail Assets and the Substitute Retail Assets (but, in the case of the latter,
only if consents, approvals or certifications are outstanding at the relevant time in relation to the grant of
leases and security interests in respect of any Warehouse Asset or the transfer of any Warehouse Asset
to Bellis Select Warehouse Limited, or the registration of any of the foregoing, in each case as required
pursuant to the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility)) for the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge
Facility is broken down as follows: (i) based on the Colliers broker's opinion of pricing of the ASDA
Distribution Sites Portfolio (which, for the purposes of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility,
comprises 30 distribution properties): £820,000,000 in England, £62,200,000 in Scotland and £24,300,000
in Wales (total aggregate capital pricing: £906,500,000); (ii) based on the Newsteer broker's opinion of
pricing of the Select Retail Assets: £420,958,000 in England and £62,836,000 in Scotland (total aggregate
capital pricing: £483,794,000) and (iii) based on the Newsteer broker's opinion of pricing of the Substitute
Retail Assets (which includes the addition of 5% to the base shell rental pricing to reflect the existence of
petrol forecourts): £629,301,000 in England and £10,200,000 in Wales (total aggregate capital pricing:
£639,501,000). See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our
_General Operations—We rent certain of our properties pursuant to commercial leases that may be subject_
_to adjustments that could increase expenses and have a materially adverse impact on our business, results_
_of operations and financial condition," "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Financial, Reporting and Other_
_Matters—We cannot assure you that the projections or assumptions used, estimates made or procedures_
_followed in the third-party brokers' opinions of pricing of our portfolio of real estate assets are correct,_
_accurate or complete."_

**Reliance**

The information presented in the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing is presented for illustrative purposes only.
The Brokers' Opinions of Pricing are strictly confidential and provided only for the purposes of the
Transaction and providing an indication of pricing for the benefit of the Issuers in connection with the
preparation of this Offering Memorandum (the "Original Purposes"). Newsteer and Colliers have accepted
no responsibility whatsoever to any third party for any part of the contents of the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing
and as such no third party may rely upon the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing.

Prospective investors should be aware that the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing were prepared as of October
20, 2020 and are not as of the date of this Offering Memorandum. Neither Newsteer nor Colliers has been
requested to update or revise any of the information contained in the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing as of any
later date or the date of this Offering Memorandum, nor will they be asked to do so prior to the issuance of
the Notes or at any later date. Accordingly, the information included in the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing may
not reflect the current physical, economic, competitive, market or other conditions with respect to the Group
Property Portfolio.

Commercial property is generally bought and sold by reference to its security of income generation,
development potential, future rent generation or potential for capital growth. Any events that have a material
impact on a property's ability to trade or the development of the immediate vicinity can consequently have
a significant effect on pricing, more so than other property types. Examples of such events are:

    - macroeconomic conditions in the United Kingdom, the European Union and elsewhere;

    - an economic downturn, including as a result of COVID-19;

    - potential changes to the competitive landscape for grocery retail;

    - capital expenditure requirements;

    - changes in occupier and investor demand;

    - supply and demand generally affecting pricing;

    - adaptability or obsolescence;

    - regulation (e.g. minimum energy efficiency standards);

    - changes in consumer behaviour and shopping habits, either from gradual changes over time
or as a result of any other event listed above or under "Risk Factors" in this Offering
Memorandum; and

    - other factors discussed or referred to in this Offering Memorandum.

The foregoing factors and others described under "Risk Factors" should not be construed as exhaustive.

Due to such uncertainties and risks, readers are cautioned not to place reliance on the Brokers' Opinions
of Pricing. Pricings change over time and an opinion of pricing given on a particular date may not be valid
on an earlier or later date, when both market conditions and sale circumstances may be different as a result
of which we may not be able to realise such pricing upon a disposal. As neither Newsteer, Colliers nor any
other external real estate adviser has been requested to update or revise the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing
or prepare new opinions of pricing of the ASDA Property Portfolio for any date after October 20, 2020, if an
opinion of pricing of the ASDA Property Portfolio was conducted today there can be no assurance that it
would not be materially different from the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing. As a result, the information contained
in the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing may no longer reflect the characteristics of the property portfolio as of
the date of this Offering Memorandum or any date thereafter. Prospective investors should be aware that
the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing have been issued on the basis that they can only be relied upon by the
Issuers for the Original Purposes.

**Basis of Brokers' Opinions of Pricing**

The Brokers' Opinions of Pricing of the relevant properties have been prepared on the basis of existing
use of such properties, as supermarkets, offices or distribution warehouses. The opinions of pricing do not
reflect any alternative use, intensification or development of use of these properties.

In order to conduct its opinion of pricing, both Newsteer and Colliers relied on floor areas of the relevant
properties as provided by ASDA and Newsteer and Colliers have assumed that these floor areas have
been defined in compliance with the RICS Measurement Standards. For the purposes of its opinion of

18


-----

pricing, Colliers also relies on floor areas for certain of the properties that were measured by its rating
department under a separate instruction from ASDA, which comply with the current edition of RICS
Measurement Standards. Both Brokers' Opinions' of Pricing have been produced on a desktop basis only
without visual inspection of the properties and without undertaking the typical due diligence that would
normally be entered into by a purchaser. See "—Terms and Assumptions" and "—Methodology" for further
assumptions providing the basis of the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing.

**Terms and Assumptions**

The opinions of pricing of all properties were based on their existing use of the properties. Newsteer
and Colliers made various assumptions as to tenure, letting, taxation, town planning, and the condition and
repair of buildings and sites—including, among other things, ground conditions and contamination. If any
of the information or assumptions on which the studies are based are subsequently found to be incorrect,
the opinions of pricing may also be incorrect and should be reconsidered.

In particular, in preparation of their respective broker's opinion of pricing, Newsteer and Colliers
assumed each property to be the authorised use under planning legislation and in accordance with the use
registered with the relevant regulatory agency. During the course of their engagement, Newsteer and
Colliers did not perform site inspections, environmental audit, tests of services and amenities, investigations
or tests as to the condition of the properties. Newsteer and Colliers did not make planning or permitting
enquiries and did not examine deeds, leases or other documents in respect of tenure or title to the ASDA
Group's properties, building structure and condition, planning, environmental or other statutory information.
The Brokers' Opinions of Pricing assumed, among others, that as at October 20, 2020 (i) in the case of
Newsteer, the properties are let to ASL and in the case of Colliers, the properties are let to ASDA or to a
AAA-tenant, which could include ASDA, and in both cases that ASDA are in the market for all the properties
and benefits from an excellent rating, such as AAA and a very low risk of failure, (ii) all properties are
freehold or long leasehold and all title, tenure, lettings, planning, taxation, statutory and local authority
requirements are complied with and all properties possess a good and marketable title free from any
onerous restrictions or conditions, (iii) all properties benefit from full access and egress rights together with
sufficient parking and loading facilities and are connected to all main services, (iv) all properties are free
from defect, in good repair and condition and well maintained and in marketable condition, compliant with
all building, accessibility and fire safety regulations and there are no abnormalities as to repair and condition
of the properties, (v) the properties have no environmental issues such as contamination, deleterious
materials, flooding, ground conditions, invasive or protected plants or species and the properties are not
adversely affected by any existing or proposed environmental law, (vi) the floor areas provided to Newsteer
and Colliers by ASDA comply with the RICS Standards for measurement (other than those properties which
were measured by Colliers as part of separate instruction and which comply with the edition of the RICS
Measurement Standards current as at the date of this Offering Memorandum and upon which Colliers have
relied for the purposes of their opinion on pricing) and (vii) no capital expenditure is required in respect of
the properties. Both Colliers and Newsteer have assumed that each property is a vacant shell unit which
benefits from fully capped off services and no tenant fit-outs or fixtures and fittings beyond a typical
specification with which a vacant shell unit would be let or sold have been taken into account in the
respective broker's opinion of pricing.

**Methodology**

The Brokers' Opinions of Pricing have been prepared on the basis of "capital pricing" and have been
arrived at using comparable transactional evidence of leasing and sales transactions, adjusted to reflect
the characteristics of the properties in the ASDA Property Portfolio. Capital pricing as determined by
Newsteer and Colliers is based on certain qualifications and assumptions (including as to market
participants (e.g., that there is a willing lessor and willing lessee, as well as a willing vendor and purchaser,
in terms of demand for the properties in the open market, liens or other encumbrances, and the condition
and repair of buildings and sites, including environmental matters), estimates and projections. In both
cases, Newsteer and Colliers have assumed that the properties are fully leased at market rates as of
October 20, 2020. Newsteer has also assumed that the properties are open for business and trading as of
October 20, 2020 and are trading at sufficient levels that warrant the opinion of pricing.

Colliers has determined capital pricing by assuming an "all-risks" yield to the annual rent assumed under
a rental price exercise. The rental price exercise applies an overall rental price per square foot based on
the gross internal floor area of each building. The yield assumes that any occupier would have an
institutional-grade covenant similar to the leading grocery operators or other national or international
logistics firms, which could include ASDA. The rent and yield approach is cross-checked with a capital price
per square foot analysis that uses comparable transactional evidence. Benchmarks were drawn from recent

19


-----

transactions of similar properties in similar locations in the marketplace and a certain rent and yield range
was then applied depending on the characteristics of the properties and their locations. The yield range
applied varies from approximately 4.5% to 9.5% depending on the characteristics of the properties and
their locations. For each property, it is assumed that the property is subject to an occupational lease as of
October 20, 2020 on the following terms: (a) 20-year term to a AAA-rated tenant, (b) yearly indexation of
the rent based on Retail Price Index with 1% / 3% collar and cap, (c) no open market rent review, (d) full
repairing and insuring lease terms, (e) on institutional terms which are acceptable to landlords and tenants
typical of the properties, and (f) the lease has the benefit of security of tenure pursuant to the Landlord and
Tenant Act 1954. Colliers has not deducted any void costs nor any non-recoverable costs but assumes a
deduction of standard purchaser's costs applicable to property assets in determining capital pricing of the
ASDA Distribution Sites Portfolio.

Newsteer has determined capital pricing in the case of freehold properties by applying an estimated net
initial yield in perpetuity to the annual rent assumed under a rental price exercise for the freehold properties.
For long leasehold properties, Newsteer has applied an estimated term yield for the remaining term to the
profit rent assumed under a rental price exercise having disregarded any rent review provisions for the long
leasehold properties. In each case, the yield assumes that the occupier would have an institutional-grade
covenant similar to the leading grocery operators. Benchmarks were drawn from recent transactions of
similar properties in similar locations in the marketplace. The rental price exercise applies an overall rental
price per square foot based on the gross internal floor area of each store and the net internal floor area of
each office. For each store property that benefits from a petrol filling station, Newsteer has reflected the
existence of a petrol filling station with an addition of 5% to the base shell rental pricing for the stores. For
each property, it is assumed that the property is subject to an occupational lease on the following terms:
(a) 20-year term to an institutional-grade tenant, (b) five yearly upwards only open market rent reviews on
a shell basis with appropriate rent-free incentives, (c) on institutional terms which are acceptable to
landlords and tenants typical of the properties and (d) assuming that ASL is in occupation and that ASDA
would have bid competitively for the properties at the time of letting and paid the market rent assessment.
Newsteer has not deducted any voids nor any non-recoverable costs and has not deducted standard
purchaser's costs, thereby reporting on a gross capital pricing basis.

We cannot assure you that the projections or assumptions used, estimates made or procedures followed
in the capital pricing of the ASDA Group's properties are correct, accurate or complete. For example, if the
properties were assumed to be held with vacant possession, rather than being assumed to be occupied,
the capital pricing would be materially lower. Any opinions or conclusions reached in the Brokers' Opinions
of Pricing depend upon these assumptions, estimates and projections, some or all of which may or may
not occur or prove to be relevant. In addition, the methodologies and assumptions used in the Brokers'
Opinions of Pricing may differ from those underlying our projections and estimates contained elsewhere in
this Offering Memorandum.

The foregoing are brokers' opinions of pricing as set forth in the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing and are
distinct from the book value recorded on the ASDA's statement of financial position in respect of the Group's
properties in the "Property, plant and equipment" and "Investment properties" line items on the statement
of financial position of the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements. The Brokers'
Opinions of Pricing have not been prepared in accordance with IAS 16 "Property, Plant and Equipment" or
IAS 40 "Investment Property," which are the accounting principles applicable to the ASDA Group's property
and investment properties. See "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results
_of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—Significant Real Estate Asset Portfolio."_

**OVERVIEW**

We are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom and the second-largest grocery retailer
in the North of England, Scotland and Wales (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a
52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). We operate a significant store estate of
614 stores (excluding standalone PFSs) that are geographically diversified across the United Kingdom.
We also have the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom (in terms of Total Grocery
Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). The graph below
compares our total grocery market share with that of other major UK grocery retailers.

(Source: Kantar. Based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020. *Ocado Market share
shown.)

We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market that is underpinned by
favourable macroeconomic factors including GDP, population, consumer confidence and household
expenditure on food and beverages and which has historically demonstrated resilient performance through
economic fluctuations. Groceries are a necessary and regular consumer expenditure, which we believe
generally allows the grocery retail market to weather economic downturns better than certain other retail
markets. For example, the UK grocery retail market demonstrated its two strongest periods of growth in
recent history during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and during the COVID-19 pandemic. See also
"Industry."

One of the key capabilities that drives our performance is our differentiated operating model, which is
in turn centred around our omni-channel offer (with multiple fulfilment options), our commitment to "Every
Day Low Price" and our wholly-owned supplier, IPL, which enables us to take a vertically-integrated
approach to procurement and which we believe gives us a competitive advantage in food sourcing. Other
key capabilities that drive our performance include our profitable and well-established George Clothing and
George Home offers, our well-developed own-brand grocery offers and our team of flexible and engaged
colleagues. Historically, we have benefited from the support of Walmart, our former parent company. We
will continue to receive support from Walmart over the next three years pursuant to the Transitional
Agreements negotiated in connection with the Acquisition. For more information about the ongoing support
to be provided by Walmart, please see "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—
_Transitional Agreements with Walmart" and "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are_
_risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart."_

We are a highly cash-generative business of scale with strong asset backing. In the year ended
December 31, 2019, our revenue was approximately £22.9 billion (including petrol), of which approximately
£2 billion was online sales, and our Adjusted EBITDA was approximately £1.2 billion (including petrol).

The chart below presents the breakdown of our 2019 revenue by product category (food, general

profile is underpinned by strong Adjusted EBITDA margins, free cash flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA
less capital expenditure) and cash conversion (defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA)
in recent years. In 2018 and 2019, our average Adjusted EBITDA margin was 5.5% (including petrol), our

We believe that our business, operating model and financial performance also benefit from our
significant freehold real estate asset portfolio. See "Brokers' Opinions of Pricing."

We believe that our omni-channel food offer delivers low prices across the full basket and that we
maintain a meaningful price gap as compared to other traditional grocers in the United Kingdom. Within
the UK value market, we have strong market shares across ambient products (13.0%), fresh/chilled
(11.6%) and total grocery (12.2%) (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52
weeks ended December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). Our offer is strong across the full food basket: our
category market shares range from 12% to 14% (except household and toiletries) (in each case in terms
of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). We
believe that we are the least expensive full-selection traditional grocer in the United Kingdom: according to
internal ASDA data, our prices are approximately 6% to 7.5% less expensive than our traditional grocer
competitors (on a 2020 year-to-date (weeks 1-42) average, based on total goods price gap percentage).

Our food business is already of significant scale, is supported by a strong online offer and is
supplemented by a large clothing and general merchandise business. We offer our entire range of food
and non-food products to customers as a convenient "one-stop shop" experience that is supported and
enhanced by our strong online offer. We believe our omni-channel offer, through which we reach customers
at our brick-and-mortar stores, through our significant online offering and on our app, appeals to our
customers. In 2020, there were approximately 9.8 million weekly visits to groceries.asda.com, with
approximately 488,000 weekly orders pre-COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days
ended February 28, 2020), and approximately 723,000 weekly orders post COVID-19 (based on the
average orders for the seven days ended September 30, 2020). The COVID-19 pandemic has increased
use of and engagement with our online platforms and we currently fulfil approximately 720,000 online
orders per week. Our online grocery business operates from 350 stores, we offer at-home delivery and
customers are also able to collect their purchases at one of approximately 460 ASDA Click & Collect sites.
We are also expanding our 1-hour Click & Collect offer. Our business model integrates our store-based
and online offer by leveraging our stores to fulfil online orders.

Our online grocery business is profitable and has been consistently gaining market share within one of
the world's most developed online grocery markets. We have consistently outperformed the UK online
grocery market and increased our online market share in the last three years. According to Kantar, we
currently operate the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom, holding 18.2% of
market share (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales) as of December 2019, which
grew to 19.8% as of December 27, 2020 (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales),
representing a 1.5% gain and the second-strongest share gain since December 2019 amongst our key

According to Kantar, we are the second-largest online clothing retailer overall by volume in the United
Kingdom and we held 6.0% of the total UK online clothing (excluding essentials, footwear and accessories)
market by volume for the 52 weeks ended December 13, 2020. Combined sales for our online grocery
business and George.com have rapidly increased in recent years, growing from £1.7 billion (of which £1.5

2020. Additionally, our toyou service allows customers to conveniently collect and return orders from
George.com and other partner retailers at our stores. We have partnered with 119 brands and process

With our team of approximately 140,000 flexible and engaged colleagues serving approximately 15
million customers each week (based on the average of weeks 39 to 42 of 2020), we are committed to and
deeply invested in the UK food supply chain.

Our business model is supported by diversification. First, we are a mass market retailer that serves the
entire UK population, in terms of both customer demographics and geography, with our customer base

 • Long-term support and continued partnership with Walmart's management and leadership.

**KEY STRENGTHS**

We believe that we benefit from the following strengths, including being a business of significant scale
with a history of resilient performance, a differentiated operating model, a successful financial profile and
a significant asset backing, as further described below.

**_We are a business of significant scale with a history of resilient performance_**

_We operate in a large, historically stable, resilient and growing industry with favourable macroeconomic_
_tailwinds_

We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market, which has demonstrated
resilient performance underpinned by favourable macroeconomic factors including GDP, population,
consumer confidence and household spend on food and beverages. Since the 2007-2009 global financial
crisis, UK GDP growth has shown stable development: annual GDP growth has ranged between 1.3% and
2.9% between 2010 and 2019, according to ONS. In 2020, GDP growth in the United Kingdom is expected
to reflect a sharp decline due to the impact of COVID-19. However, it is predicted by ONS to quickly recover
to growth of approximately 5.5% in 2021 and, post-2021, UK GDP growth is expected to stabilise to an
average of 1.9% in subsequent years through 2025. The UK grocery retail market is also characterised by
favourable demographic characteristics, including a growing population. According to ONS, the UK
population is projected to grow from 67 million in 2019 to 70 million by 2031, which is expected to result in
an overall increase in the consumer base for groceries.

In addition to its historical stability, the UK grocery retail market is also resilient. Groceries are a
necessary and stable consumer expenditure, which generally allows the grocery retail market to weather

### 27


-----

economic downturns better than certain other retail markets that involve more discretionary spending. For
example, the UK grocery retail market demonstrated its two strongest periods of growth in recent history
during and following the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and during the COVID-19 pandemic. The UK
grocery retail market peaked at 6.2% year-over-year growth in 2011, with a CAGR of 5.1% between 2007
and 2011, in each case according to Euromonitor. Additionally, during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis,
according to ONS, the percentage of average weekly household spend on food and non-alcoholic drinks
remained fairly consistent at approximately 11.0%, demonstrating the market's resilience during periods of
macroeconomic difficulty. According to ONS, this percentage has remained relatively flat following the
2007-2009 global financial crisis and the 2011 sovereign debt crisis, averaging 10.6% between 2012 and
2019, which we believe underscores the largely non-discretionary nature of grocery purchases. According
to Kantar, the UK grocery market's year-over-year growth increased to 12.3% (on a Total Grocery Absolute
Sales basis for the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020), although growth in 2020 has been principally
driven by the impact of COVID-19 (mainly consisting of an increase in the consumption of food and drink
products at home during lockdowns), rather than long-term underlying growth drivers.

_We are the United Kingdom's third-largest grocer, holding sizeable market share_

According to Kantar, we are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom, with 12.2% of
market share and the second-largest grocery retailer in the North of England, Scotland and Wales (based
on Total Grocery Absolute Sales over 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020), with revenue of approximately
£19.6 billion and £20.0 billion (excluding petrol) for the year ended December 31, 2019 and the 12 months
ended September 30, 2020, respectively. We have a network of 614 stores (excluding standalone PFSs)
throughout the United Kingdom, with a particular focus on superstores, supermarket and online formats.
We are also the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom by value (in terms of Total
Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar) and have been
growing faster than our competitors except for Sainsbury's in this channel, having increased our market
share over many years and particularly throughout 2020 and the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result, we
believe that we are well-positioned as a large and established business with a clear set of peers.

We also believe that our multi-format, omni-channel offer positions us well to compete effectively and
to continue growing our market share. Despite not operating convenience formats, our Adjusted EBITDA
in the year ended December 31, 2019 was £1.2 billion (including petrol), which we believe indicates that
we have headroom for growth in the convenience market. We also cater to a broad target demographic,
which we believe provides us a long-term competitive advantage. In contrast to discounters, we provide a
broad range of branded as well as own-brand offers, while also having a more developed and established
online platform.

**_We believe we have faced the greatest impacts of discounters on our market_**

The adverse impact of discounters (primarily Aldi and Lidl) on the traditional grocers in recent years has
been significant but, while we believe that discounters will continue to put pressure on the market, we
believe that we have already faced the greatest impacts of this competition in the markets in which we
operate and that the discounters pose a greater challenge to other traditional grocers, who we believe are
more geographically exposed to the areas where discounters are likely to focus in the near-term.

As compared to our traditional grocer peers, our geographical concentration in the North of England,
Scotland and Wales, as evidenced by our number two market shares in those regions. The discounters
have already penetrated these areas and we expect the discounters to shift the focus of their expansion to
the South of England, the East of England and London, where we operate fewer sites as compared to the
Midlands, the North of England, Scotland and Wales. Furthermore, the catchment areas of 76% of our
stores already contain both major discounters, Aldi and Lidl, which is a higher percentage than any of our
traditional grocer competitors (the boundary used is a 10-minute drive-time radius around each point, which
is consistent regardless of location type or size of store and stores are only included in the count where
there is both Aldi and Lidl stores present within the drive-time boundary). Therefore, we believe that our
current performance already factors in the adverse impact of discounters to a large extent.

**_We have demonstrated resilience through downturns_**

Just as our market has proven resilient in times of economic difficulty and uncertainty, our business has
also proven resilient during recent economic and market downturns, including during the 2007-2009 global
financial crisis, as well as through a more recent period of low food inflation in the United Kingdom and the
rise of discounters in the UK grocery retail market in more recent years, particularly during 2014 to 2016.
During the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, we continued to perform well, achieving an average like-forlike sales (excluding petrol) growth rate of 6.1% for the fiscal years ended December 31, 2008 and 2009.

### 28


-----

Our EBITDA margins have also remained stable, ranging from 5.1% to 6.6% between 2007 and 2019.
During this same period, we also experienced stable revenue growth, at a CAGR of 2.5%.

**_We have performed well and have benefitted from an improved reputation through COVID-19_**

Despite the significant social and economic shifts driven by the COVID-19 pandemic, our business has
experienced strong overall performance, particularly in our online and supermarket formats. While large
stores did not perform as well as smaller formats during the first UK lockdown, they have remained
instrumental in supporting the growth of our online retail grocery business, with online grocery orders being
largely fulfilled from our stores. We also believe that the "one-stop stop" offer of our stores appeals to
customers seeking to leave their homes and fulfil multiple missions efficiently. Overall, our food business
has performed relatively consistently throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, despite an initial increase in
sales due to panic buying and customers stocking-up on key staples at the outset of each of the first three
lockdown periods. Following an initial decline at the beginning of the first lockdown, our general
merchandise business has also generally performed well throughout these lockdown periods, due to
increasing purchases of homeware products. While our clothing business was initially negatively impacted
during the early stage of the first UK lockdown period, we have recently experienced improved performance
in this business in line with an overall improvement of the general economy and a rebound in consumer
confidence. Finally, we have also taken steps throughout the COVID-19 pandemic to enhance our
reputation with our stakeholders through various initiatives, including meal donations, priority delivery
services to care homes and additional leave provided to staff affected by COVID-19, which we believe
have had an overall positive impact on perceptions of our brand and business.

**_We benefit from a differentiated operating model_**

_We operate the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom, which is profitable and_
_winning market share_

The United Kingdom has one of the most developed online grocery retail markets in the world, with one
of the highest rates of the population using the internet. There has been a significant shift in the grocery
retail market away from brick-and-mortar stores to online purchasing as demographic trends, greater
mobile and device usage, improved service proposition and technological advances in applications and
customer interfaces have driven increasing penetration rates in the online grocery retail market. We believe
we are poised to take advantage of these favourable consumer trends, as we have already established
ourselves in the rapidly growing UK online grocery retail market and our store and warehouse footprint is
strategically positioned across attractive geographic areas to service the growing demand for groceries
online.

According to Kantar, we are the second-largest online grocery retail platform in the United Kingdom,
holding 19.8% of market share (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales) for the 52-week period ended
December 27, 2020. Relative to our competitors, we have posted the second-strongest share gain since
December 2019 and through the COVID-19 pandemic, with an industry-leading 3.3% increase in our share
of the online grocery retail market between December 2017 and December 2020 and an increase of 154
basis points between December 2019 and December 2020, according to Kantar (based on Total Grocery
Absolute Sales for the 52-week periods through December 31 for 2017, 2018 and 2019 and the 52-week
period ended December 27, 2020).

As a result of our significant gain in online market share, our online sales, combined sales for our online
grocery business and George.com have rapidly increased in recent years, growing from £1.7 billion (of
which £1.5 billion were online grocery sales and £0.2 billion were George.com sales) in 2018 to £1.9 billion
in 2019 (of which £1.6 billion were online grocery sales and £0.3 billion were George.com sales) to a total
of £2.7 billion for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020 (of which £2.4 billion were online grocery sales
and £0.3 billion were George.com sales), representing a CAGR of 26% between 2018 and September 30,
2020.

We believe there is greater scope for our online profitability to improve further. We expect that the
demand for online groceries will continue to be strong as customers increasingly adopt online shopping as
a more permanent and preferred way to purchase groceries following the initial lockdowns.

_We benefit from vertically integrated procurement through IPL_

We believe that we have a competitive advantage in food sourcing via our captive sourcing arm, IPL,
which enables us to take a vertically integrated approach to procurement. We believe that IPL provides us
with valuable sourcing differentiation as compared to our competitors. IPL is the largest importer of produce
in the United Kingdom and, while IPL is a group company, it is also our largest supplier. The aim of our
vertically integrated procurement model is to consolidate import activity for key products and reduce our

### 29


-----

overall costs. In 2019, we purchased £1.5 billion of our products through IPL. The foundation of IPL's costprice advantage is that it eliminates the "middle man" who typically serves as the intermediary in the supply
chain, thereby giving us greater control of costs, quality and supply of a diverse range of products. We
have an extensive IPL footprint across the United Kingdom, with ten processing facilities across the country
and more than 4,200 colleagues. Our IPL product mix is diversified according to our needs, with a mix of
61% in produce, 27% in protein, 9% in beverages and 3% in grocery in 2019. Additionally, we have been
able to build upon and benefit from our supplier relationships to deliver supply chain continuity and make
progress in our sustainability agenda. We also believe that IPL will provide greater stability and allow us
greater control over our supply chain now that the United Kingdom has left the European Union's single
market and customs union.

_The George Clothing and George Home offers are profitable and well-established_

We launched our clothing offer, George, in 1990 and it is the second-largest clothing brand in the
United Kingdom by volume of units sold (excluding essentials, footwear and accessories) for the 52 weeks
ended December 13, 2020 and is the leading UK childrenswear brand with 21% market share by volume
of units sold as of December 13, 2020, in each case according to Kantar. Despite challenges to this product
category overall, our online clothing sales have increased from £104.3 million for the year to December
31, 2016 to £308.6 million for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020, with more than two-thirds of all
sales now made via mobile devices. We believe this demonstrates our strength in the online segment,
which is a key part of our operating model. Additionally, we have expanded the George branded offer to
include general merchandise. The George Home brand generated approximately £530 million in sales and
contributed approximately 38% of our total general merchandising sales for the fiscal year ended
December 31, 2019. Sales by the George Home brand grew at a CAGR of approximately 3% between the
years ended December 31, 2016 and 2019. Furthermore, the George Clothing and George Home product
categories generally have higher margins than our food product categories.

_We have well-developed own-brands_

We believe that our own-brand offers have been a key strength of our business and continue to offer
growth opportunities. We have an extensive own-brand product range in our food business, with
approximately 7,000 own-brand SKUs, while our premium "Extra Special" offer is our fastest growing ownbrand product line. Our award-winning approach to range development and innovation enables us to meet
changing customer needs: we launched approximately 850 new lines in 2020 and approximately 2,500
lines having been reformulated in 2020. In addition to our diverse and extensive product offer with our ownbrand range, we have also been able to drive growth through service and price positioning. We leverage
our IPL sourcing model to deliver value, especially in our produce, cooked meats and wine segments.

_We are driven by our commitment to Every Day Low Prices_

We believe our commitment to Every Day Low Prices is a significant competitive advantage as we aim
to lead on price while staying competitive on assortment. We believe that we are the least-expensive fullselection traditional grocer in the United Kingdom: according to internal ASDA data, our prices are
approximately 6% to 7.5% less expensive than our traditional grocer competitors (on a 2020 year-to-date
(weeks 1-42) average, based on total goods price gap percentage). Our low prices are supported by
rigorous cost control and a commitment to Every Day Low Prices, which enables us to control expenses
so that we can pass cost savings on to our customers.

**_We have achieved a successful financial profile_**

We have achieved a successful financial profile that is underpinned by strong Adjusted EBITDA
margins, free cash flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA less capital expenditure) and cash conversion
(defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA) in recent years. In 2018 and 2019, our average
Adjusted EBITDA margin was 5.5% (including petrol), our cumulative free cash flow was approximately
£1.7 billion and our average cash conversion was approximately 70%. This strong financial performance
is driven by our Every Day Low Price model, diverse product offer, strong own-brand grocery offer and
well-established George-branded product categories. Our Adjusted EBITDA margins have benefitted from
our cost transformation programmes, which have generated SG&A cost savings without compromising the
low prices we offer our customers. Our active working capital management has resulted in approximately
£400 million of improvements over the past three years. Furthermore, we have pursued a disciplined
approach to our capital expenditure over time, with the aim of maintaining and improving our real estate
platform. Our well-invested store real estate portfolio underpins our strong, ongoing cash flow generation.
