**BUSINESS STRATEGY**

Our primary strategy is designed to "win on price" by narrowing our price gap with discounters (such as
Aldi and Lidl) while providing good value and maintaining our price leadership position against our
traditional grocery peers, which we expect to further enhance customer loyalty. We aim to provide a
consistent, trusted experience, incentivising customers not to shop elsewhere, through the creation of
attractive store propositions and partnerships that increase our appeal to customers. We serve our
customers with our team of flexible and engaged colleagues, while increasing the number of self-serve
opportunities and transforming the in-store experience. We focus our growth where customers care,
expanding our addressable markets in online grocery, wholesale and community convenience.

**_Winning on price with value equivalent to the discounters_**

We are already well established as the lowest-price full-selection retailer in the United Kingdom and we
comfortably lead the traditional grocers in terms of lowest price. Moving forward, we intend to narrow our
price gap to the discounters and further expand our existing price gap with other traditional grocers. We
aim to achieve this by simplifying our core customer proposition to offer a curated range in food, general
merchandise and clothing that responds to customers' demonstrated willingness to shop a tighter range of
offers in-store. We will also create a more hassle-free customer experience in-store with our digital
transformation. For example, we intend to implement more customer self-serve options, such as moving
to a checkout model which features 80/20 self-checkout solutions and we plan to optimise our in-store

### 31


-----

fulfilment operations. We believe this will enable us to deliver a simplified operating model and end-to-end
supply chain efficiencies to drive further investment in value for the customer at the shelf edge, driving
greater traffic and therefore sales growth, which will in turn stimulate greater volume, thereby creating a
positive effect for our overall business.

We are assessing our approach to further reward customer loyalty by exploring non-traditional and
digitally-based loyalty mechanisms so that we can identify more customers in more transactions. We
believe that this approach will allow us to grow our customer analytics platform to bring better, faster, and
deeper customer insights to our largest investment decisions and to improve the overall customer
experience by personalising our offer.

**_Develop ASDA as a platform by forming relevant partnerships_**

We aim to grow ASDA as a platform through simplification of the store proposition by forming
partnerships that enable us to provide a broader set of relevant branded products and services, while also
building upon our existing capabilities, such as logistics and our customer-facing toyou proposition. We
believe adding partners to our platform will result in the creation of appealing "one-stop-shop" store
destinations for more customer missions. We are attracting relevant partners with our existing customer
base and scale, particularly with respect to the George brand clothing and general merchandise offers. For
example, our own-brand general merchandise proposition, led by the George Home brand, will become
more omni-channel focused as we grow those categories in which we believe we already have a strong
position and can maintain or gain leading market share. Meanwhile, in other categories, we will extend
product ranges with partners who specialise in those categories, have a strong affinity fit with our existing
customers and bring complementary expertise and reputation, such as in toys with The Entertainer. We
believe these partnerships will not only provide additional income through rent and revenue share models,
but will also create a positive effect on our overall business.

**_Growth where customers care, expanding our addressable market_**

We have grown our online grocery channel ahead of the market in 2020, having achieved 80% yearover-year growth as compared to the 66% year-over-year growth (in terms of value) achieved by the overall
UK online grocery market, according to Kantar (based on the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020).
However, we believe there is further headroom for growth based on continued channel shifting, demand
and customer "stickiness." We plan to continue to drive growth and market share gains in the online
channel through the acceleration of our online grocery channel's capacity to meet increased demand. We
continue to seek to optimise our online grocery operating model and further develop our already profitable
economic model through the ongoing assessment of our online product range and promotions, further
monetisation of our e-commerce assets, as well as other initiatives.

In addition to growing our core online grocery business, we are targeting further growth by expanding
the reach of our online platform and expanding our delivery services. We expect to provide customers with
greater and more convenient access to our product range by accelerating our last-mile delivery capabilities
via partnerships: for example, we have recently expanded our partnership with UberEats to over 100 of
our stores, with a further 100 planned in early 2021.

We believe that customers seeing ASDA in new locations and new formats will help us broaden our
customer base, thereby benefitting our core proposition (which is composed of our in-store and online food
and non-food offerings, and does not include trials, such as the ASDA On the Move wholesale-convenience
concept). We also believe that we can further expand our addressable market by accessing wholesale and
community convenience channels in an asset-light manner. We are looking to extend the reach of our
products delivered through wholesale and more specifically through partnerships that would provide
wholesale delivery services by using the logistics and distribution capabilities of IPL. We aim to broaden
our reach to existing and new customers through further convenience channel trials, using our established
partnerships to access the convenience channel within local communities. For example, ASDA On the
Move is our first entrance into the convenience market, where we are carrying out an initial trial with the
EG Group at three store locations in Ashby, Leamore and Primley. ASDA On the Move is a wholesale
arrangement whereby ASDA's own brand products as well as branded products will be sold in third-partyowned smaller convenience store formats.

**HISTORY**

Headquartered in Leeds, we are an omni-channel retailer across England, Scotland, Wales and
Northern Ireland. We have built our business on listening to our diverse range of customers, offering what
they need at the best value and bringing innovation to the UK market.

### 32


-----

We were founded in 1965 through the merger of the Asquith family grocery business with the Associated
Dairies company in Yorkshire. Our name is derived from this historic merger, combining "Asquith" and
"Dairies" to form "ASDA."

Founded in the North of England, we have a rich history, heritage and culture. The Asquith family has
deep ties to the grocery business, W.R. Asquith having run a butchers shop in Knottingly, West Yorkshire,
which eventually expanded to seven shops. W.R. Asquith's sons, Peter and Fred, went on to create the
United Kingdom's first self-service supermarket in Castleford, introducing food discounting to the UK
grocery market, and eventually co-founded ASDA. In parallel to the growth of the Asquith family business,
a group of West Riding dairy farmers joined forces, eventually becoming Associated Dairies & Farm Stores
Limited led by Arthur Stockdale. Arthur's son, Sir Noel Stockdale, went on to co-found ASDA with Peter
and Fred Asquith.

In 1965, we acquired GEM, a major U.S. discount retailer operating in the United Kingdom. With the
addition of general merchandise to the former GEM stores, we introduced the superstore to the UK market,
a landmark event in the development of UK retailing. To complement this offer, Peter Asquith also
introduced the first discounted petrol filling station.

By 1970, we operated over 30 stores and were poised to expand beyond our original home in the North
of England. Throughout the 1970s, we grew our presence in the South of England, opening stores in
Newport, Plymouth and Gosport. In 1977, we launched our "ASDA Price" TV adverts, featuring the "pocket
tap" which came to be the official sign language for ASDA. By the end of the 1970s, we were operating
over 80 stores and opened our 100th store in 1981.

Throughout the 1980s, we focused on expanding our distribution capabilities, opening seven new
distribution centres strategically located throughout the United Kingdom by 1985. In 1987, our flagship
Watford store opened, another landmark in UK retailing, and featured the longest-ever checkout bank at
the time, with 45 checkouts. In 1988, we opened our headquarters in Leeds, with Prime Minister Margaret
Thatcher overseeing the opening ceremonies. In 1989, George Davies was asked to produce a line of
clothing for us that was high-quality, high-value and had its own identity: the pioneering George brand was
born.

In the 1990s, we developed the ASDA Way of Working, an innovative framework for a new
organisational structure that focuses on our stores and promotes colleague involvement, which set the
stage for the ASDA culture of today. In 1996, we opened our first ASDA Pharmacy location in Harrogate,
North Yorkshire and launched our "Tickled Pink" campaign to raise money for the fight against breast
cancer, a partnership that continues to this day. In 1998, we began our online retail operations with a
dedicated depot in Croydon.

In 1999, we joined the Walmart family, becoming part of the world's largest retailer. Throughout the
early 2000s, we continued to grow and innovate, expanding our online and Click & Collect offers, opening
our first ASDA Living store and our first Eco Store, winning awards for the value we offer customers as
well as for the positive environment we create for colleagues, launching our Free From and Extra Special
offers, launching standalone PFSs as well as ASDA Opticians. In 2015, we celebrated our 50th birthday
and George's 25th birthday. In 2016, Roger Burnley joined our team as Chief Operating Officer and Deputy
Chief Executive and was promoted in 2018 to President and CEO. ASDA has continued to roll out
innovations, including the United Kingdom's first parcel tower, which allows customers to collect online
orders in less than 60 seconds, and voice-activated shopping through Google Home.

Our values are rooted in service to our customers, respect for the individual, striving for excellence and
acting with integrity. We pursue our values with the support of our colleagues, culture and technology.

**_The Acquisition and Acquisition Agreement_**

On October 2, 2020, the Issa Brothers and TDR Capital (the "Shareholders") caused their jointly
controlled entity, Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited (the "Purchaser"), to enter into the Acquisition
Agreement with the Seller, a subsidiary of Walmart, pursuant to which the Purchaser committed to acquire
all of the issued ordinary shares of the Company on the Acquisition Completion Date (the "Acquisition").
The Purchaser, a limited company formed under the laws of Jersey, is an indirect, wholly-owned subsidiary

### 33


-----

of the Issuers. It was formed by the Shareholders solely for the purpose of engaging in the transactions
contemplated by the Acquisition Agreement and has not commenced any operations, other than as set
forth in the Acquisition Agreement.

Pursuant to the Acquisition Agreement, the consideration payable by the Purchaser on the Acquisition
Completion Date will be £6,614.0 million (assuming an Acquisition Completion Date of February 16, 2021)
(the "Purchase Consideration"). Under the terms of the Acquisition Agreement, the Seller was required
to use commercially reasonable endeavours to cause the Company to make distributions to the Seller or
other Walmart Group Companies of at least £1,769.5 million prior to the Acquisition Completion Date. On
December 21, 2020, the Company approved a distribution of £1,769.5 million to ASDA Holdings UK
Limited, of which £1,269.5 million was a distribution in specie through the transfer of intercompany
receivables and £500.0 million was settled in cash. On the Acquisition Completion Date, the Company will
settle outstanding intercompany payables due by the ASDA Group to Walmart Group Companies in cash.

The Acquisition Agreement includes customary warranties by the Seller and the Purchaser. The Seller
and the Purchaser have also separately agreed on a dedicated indemnification regime applicable to any
losses arising from the Equal Value Claims. As contemplated by the Acquisition Agreement, the Acquisition
will be completed following receipt of the FCA's approval, but during the pendency of the review of the
Acquisition by the CMA, which is the competition authority that has the authority to review the Acquisition
following referral by the European Commission. The CMA's review is ongoing. Currently, the CMA is
conducting its phase 1 inquiry into the Acquisition. If the CMA identifies competition-related concerns over
the course of this phase 1 inquiry, we intend to propose remedies to address these concerns, which may
include the sale of certain PFS sites to unaffiliated third parties. See "—The Post-Completion
_Transactions—Forecourt Disposals." However, there can be no assurance that any remedies we may_
propose will be acceptable to the CMA. If the remedies we may propose are rejected, the CMA Clearance
Date could be significantly delayed and more extensive remedies may be required from us, which could
potentially include a mandated sale of the ASDA Group. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the
_Transactions—The Acquisition is subject to certain uncertainties and risks, which could adversely impact_
_recoveries under the Notes."_

In connection with the CMA's review of the Acquisition, we expect the CMA to issue an IEO shortly
before or immediately after Completion, which we expect to remain in force until the CMA Clearance Date.
Under this IEO, the Bellis Group will not be permitted to exercise de facto control over the ASDA Group or
otherwise direct its operations until the CMA Clearance Date. As a result, although we acquired the ASDA
Group on the Acquisition Completion Date, we will not effectively control the ASDA Group until the CMA
Clearance Date. Furthermore, while the IEO is in effect, it will prevent us from making any significant
structural or organisational changes to the ASDA Group, including the Forecourt Business Disposal, the
Excluded Forecourt Divestments or any other Post-Completion Transactions, unless we seek and obtain
a derogation from the CMA. Accordingly, we do not intend to initiate these post-completion transactions
until the CMA Clearance Date.

the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer will on-lend the net proceeds from
these drawings along with funds received from the Senior Notes Issuer under the Senior Financing
Proceeds Loan to the Purchaser, to be used as described in "Use of Proceeds." See "Description of Certain
_Financing Arrangements."_

_Utilisation of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility_

On the Acquisition Completion Date, the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower expects
to draw £950 million under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, which will be on-lent by way of
the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Proceeds Loan to Midco 2. Midco 2 and its subsidiaries, in
turn, will on-lend the net proceeds of the drawing to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer pursuant to a deeply
subordinated instrument, to be used as described in "Use of Proceeds." See "Description of Certain
_Financing Arrangements—Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility." To secure the Distribution Asset_
Disposal Bridge Facility, certain entities within the ASDA Group will grant first priority mortgages, fixed
charges or standard securities, as applicable, over the Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets and,
to the extent required thereunder, certain Substitute Retail Assets, as well as first-ranking pledges on the
Designated Bank Accounts. Prior to the execution of these mortgages, fixed charges, standard securities
and pledges, as applicable, entities within the ASDA Group are expected to enter into lease agreements
in respect of the Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, the Substitute
Retail Assets on substantially the terms summarised in "Certain Relationships and Related Party
_Transactions―ASDA Leases."_

_The Equity Contribution_

In connection with the Acquisition, the Shareholders and Walmart will cause Bellis TopCo Limited and
its subsidiaries to contribute to the equity of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or on-lend to the Senior
Secured Notes Issuer pursuant to deeply subordinated instruments approximately £1,280 million in
aggregate (the "Equity Contribution"), which includes the proceeds of Walmart's £500 million Rollover
Equity Investment and £780 million of funds raised by the Shareholders.

_The Offering and the repayment of the bridge loans_

On the Issue Date, the Senior Notes Issuer will use the proceeds from the Offering of the Senior Notes
to repay all amounts outstanding under the Senior Bridge Facility Agreement, and the Senior Secured
Notes Issuer will use the proceeds from the Offering of the Senior Secured Notes to repay all amounts
outstanding under the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities Agreement. See "Use of Proceeds."

_Estimated cash and cash equivalents as of the Acquisition Completion Date_

On or about the Acquisition Completion Date, ASDA will settle in cash intercompany loans owed to
Walmart of £409.0 million. In addition, on December 3, 2020, the Company announced that it will pay in
full its business rates for the UK tax year ending April 5, 2021 to the UK government (and the devolved
administrations of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland), thus waiving the relief it had received earlier in
2020 in respect of such payment as part of the UK government's measures in support of UK businesses
in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is estimated to be within a range of £320 million to £340
million. As a result, the Company expects to pay £254 million in retrospective business rates for the period
from April to December 2020, to be funded from cash available on the Company's balance sheet. The
Company expects to engage in due course with the competent UK authorities to discuss and agree the
exact terms of such payment, including its timing. ASDA also plans to resume its regular payments of the
business rates on a monthly basis commencing with the month of January 2021. The Company estimates
that its average cash and cash equivalents from January 4 to February 2, 2021 (inclusive), as adjusted to
give pro forma effect to the consummation of the Transactions on the Acquisition Completion Date and
excluding the amount earmarked to retrospectively pay business rates tax relief accepted from the UK
government for the period to December 31, 2020 was £505.6 million. ASDA's net working capital for the
month of January tends to be slightly lower than the yearly average due to the customary seasonal dip in
stock levels and the build-up of trade payables to suppliers in the early part of each financial year following
the Christmas trading period. ASDA's actual cash and cash equivalents available as of the Acquisition
Completion Date may however be different.

Acquisition, fund the gross proceeds of the Offering into Escrow Accounts, which will be held in the name
of the relevant Issuer, but controlled by the relevant Escrow Agent, and pledged in favour of the relevant
Trustee on behalf of and for the benefit of the holders of the relevant Notes, pursuant to the terms of the
Escrow Agreements and Escrow Account Charges dated on or before the Issue Date. Under the terms of
the Escrow Agreements, release of the Escrowed Proceeds will be subject to the satisfaction of certain
conditions, including the completion of the Acquisition and the solvency of the relevant Issuer. Following
release from escrow, we expect to use the proceeds of the Offering, together with the Equity Contribution
and amounts drawn under the Senior Facilities, the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility and the Distribution
Asset Disposal Bridge Facility (as described above and in "Use of Proceeds.") to fund our payment of the
Purchase Consideration on the Acquisition Completion Date. In the event we deposit the gross proceeds

occurred, or the conditions to the release of such Escrowed Proceeds have not been satisfied, on or before
the Outside Date, Midco has not elected to extend the initial Shortfall Agreement Termination Date (or any
extension thereof) and the Release has not occurred as at such date or in certain other circumstances,
subject to certain conditions, the Notes will be mandatorily redeemable at a price equal to 100% of the
aggregate issue price of the Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issue Date to, but not
including, the Special Mandatory Redemption Date and Additional Amounts, if any.

If the Offering is settled substantially concurrently with the completion of the Acquisition, we will forgo
these escrow procedures and will instead retain the proceeds of the Offering to fund part of the

_Forecourt Disposals_

On February 3, 2021, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and Bellis Forecourts Limited entered into the
Forecourt SPA, whereby the Senior Secured Notes Issuer undertook to sell to Bellis Forecourts Limited
the share capital of Acquisition 2 or any other member of the Bellis Group or a member of the ASDA Group
that holds the Forecourt Business, directly or indirectly, following the Acquisition Completion Date, the
CMA Clearance Date and completion of the acquisition by Acquisition 2 (or such other company) of the
Forecourt Business. Pursuant to a separate agreement, the EG Forecourt SPA, entered into on or about
the same date, Property Newco agreed to sell to Euro Garages Limited the share capital of Holdco (owning
in turn Bellis Forecourts Limited and therefore the Forecourt Business) promptly upon closing under the
Forecourt SPA. Property Newco may assign such separate agreement to the shareholders (i.e., Optima
Group S.à r.l. and Able Holdings Limited), who may sell Property Newco itself, rather than Holdco or one
of its subsidiaries. In preparation for, and prior to, the closing of the Forecourt SPA, we expect that ASDA
will distribute the Forecourt Business to Acquisition 2 as soon as practicable following the CMA Clearance
Date. In order to effect the distribution of the Forecourt Business to Acquisition 2 as a dividend in kind,
ASDA will have to arrange for the separation of the freehold or leasehold title to its co-located forecourts
(comprising the vast majority of the Forecourt Assets) from the parent title currently comprising adjacent
store or retail assets or sites by way of a Forecourt Assets Separation and the entities within the ASDA
Group that currently hold non-co-located Forecourt Assets will need to distribute such assets to Acquisition
2. We expect that the process of effecting these title separations and distributions to take several months
following the Acquisition Completion Date.

The headline enterprise value established under the Forecourt SPA, subject to customary working
capital adjustments, is £750 million, less the aggregate value of any Excluded Forecourts (and of any other
assets relating to the Excluded Forecourts). The consideration will be left outstanding at the closing of the
Forecourt SPA (the "Forecourt Disposal Receivable") and we expect it to be ultimately settled in cash
and in full promptly following the closing of the EG Forecourt SPA. See "Certain Relationships and Related
_Party Transactions—Forecourt SPA." The parties may decide to novate and assign the Forecourt SPA to_
another member of the Bellis Group or a member of the ASDA Group (as seller) and to a member of the
EG Group (as buyer), in which case the separate agreement between Property Newco and Euro Garages
Limited would be terminated and the Forecourt Business (or a holding company thereof) would be sold
directly to EG Group by the ASDA Group.

The IEO that is expected to be issued by the CMA will not permit us to sell any Forecourt Assets
pursuant to the Forecourt SPA for so long as the IEO remains in force. Consequently, we do not expect to
consummate the Forecourt Business Disposal before the CMA Clearance Date. The Forecourt SPA
requires us to complete the transactions contemplated thereunder as soon as reasonably practicable
following the satisfaction of the conditions precedent stipulated in its terms, which include the IEO to be
issued by the CMA ceasing to be in effect.

The CMA's investigation of the Acquisition is ongoing, and we may be required to take remedial action
to address any competition-related concerns the CMA may identify. If remedies prove necessary, we may
be required to designate certain Forecourt Assets (along with certain related assets) as Excluded
Forecourts and sell them to unaffiliated third parties (the "Excluded Forecourt Divestments"). Although
we will attempt to carry out the Excluded Forecourt Divestments by way of orderly sales following a
competitive sales process, there can be no assurance that the market conditions or circumstances of the
Excluded Forecourt Divestments will permit such an outcome, and the price we receive for any Excluded
Forecourts sold through the Excluded Forecourt Divestments may be less than what we would have
ultimately received in a fully voluntary sale. In addition, third parties may have rights over the Forecourt
Assets (including rights to acquire and pre-emption rights) exercisable in the event of a transfer of the
Forecourt Assets (whether of the freehold or leasehold interest or of whole or part). In all such cases, the
transfer of those Forecourt Assets may be significantly delayed, prevented in part or prevented entirely.
See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—The Acquisition is subject to certain uncertainties
_and risks, which could adversely impact recoveries under the Notes."_

Mohsin Issa CBE and Zuber Vali Issa CBE have been active in the forecourt and convenience retail
sector since the acquisition of a single petrol station in Bury, United Kingdom in 2001. Following a merger
of their UK-based Euro Garages business with TDR Capital LLP's EFR Group in 2016, EG Group was
established, which the Issa Brothers now lead as co-CEOs. The business, globally headquartered in
Blackburn, United Kingdom, has an established pedigree of delivering a world class fuel, grocery &
merchandise and foodservice offering and currently employs in excess of 44,000 people working in more
than 6,000 sites across Europe, USA and Australia. The Issa Brothers were honoured as Commanders of
the Order of the British Empire by HM The Queen in her Birthday Honours List 2020 for their contribution
to business and charity. They were also jointly named the 2018 EY Entrepreneur of the Year in the United
Kingdom.

TDR Capital LLP is a leading European private equity firm based in the United Kingdom, managing
over €10.0 billion of committed capital across three European buyout funds. Founded in 2002 by Manjit
Dale and Stephen Robertson, TDR Capital LLP has been creating value by applying a high-impact
approach to investing in a focused portfolio of companies. TDR Capital LLP has a proven value-based and
operationally focused investment strategy, which is delivered by a dedicated team of investment and
operating professionals from its single office in London. TDR's strong returns have been driven by
combining ambitious operational plans for portfolio companies with a rigorous focus on capital
preservation. TDR Capital LLP takes an active role in overseeing the transformation and growth of its
investments, working in partnership with management through board representation and professional
support. To date, TDR Capital LLP has completed 22 investments across the leisure, consumer, business
and financial services sectors.

Walmart Inc. helps people around the world save money and live better – anytime and anywhere – by
providing the opportunity to shop in retail stores and through eCommerce. Each week, Walmart serves
over 265 million customers who visit approximately 11,400 stores and numerous eCommerce websites
under 55 banners in 26 countries. Walmart is engaged in global operations of retail, wholesale and other
units, as well as eCommerce, located throughout the U.S., Africa, Canada, Central America, Chile, China,
India, Japan, Mexico and the United Kingdom.

**RECENT DEVELOPMENTS**

**COVID-19 Update**

Structural shifts due to COVID-19 have led to increased overall growth in the grocery retail market.
During the COVID-19 pandemic, customer behaviour has changed, with a shift away from out-of-home
food consumption towards at-home food consumption, to the benefit of the UK grocery market. The chart
below shows COVID-19-accelerated channel shifts over the periods presented. For further information on
prevailing trends in the UK grocery retail market and, in particular, the recent channel shifts which have
been accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic, please see "Industry."

(Source: Kantar Worldpanel, based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a year-to-date basis ended December 27, 2020.)

Grocery sales have grown by 12.3% between December 1, 2019 and December 27, 2020, according
to Kantar, based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales. Changes to consumer behaviour that have positively
benefitted the grocery market during the COVID-19 pandemic include: increased consumption of food at
home, a shift to online shopping channels, increased preference for shopping locally, in particular during
the first UK lockdown (which we believe benefitted retail groups with a strong convenience store presence),
and an increased focus on food safety, hygiene and health.

Despite significant challenges posed by COVID-19, our business has remained resilient, supported by
a well-developed online channel, which saw significant growth during government-imposed lockdowns as
customer behaviour evolved. We were able to quickly increase the capacity of our online offer in response
to increased demand driven by the pandemic, gaining market share and improving the profitability of our
online business.

During the COVID-19 pandemic, we have benefitted from healthy revenue growth driven by higher food
sales volumes (which were in turn driven by stockpiling and increased customer demand for in-home
groceries via the online grocery channel), while margins contracted due to adverse changes in sales and
product mix resulting from decreases in clothing sales, which impacted the George Clothing brand, the
temporary closure of 33 ASDA Living stores and the shift in product mix within the food category away
from higher-margin categories, such as food-to-go, and towards lower-margin categories, such as beer,
wine and spirits and meat, which factors were partially offset by lower levels of promotional activity and
stronger general merchandise sales. Furthermore, the George Clothing and George Home product
categories generally have higher margins than our food product categories. Profitability was also adversely
impacted by COVID-19-related increases in operating costs, such as the increase in retail colleague wage
costs (driven by bonus payments, overtime wages and wages paid colleagues absent from work due to
COVID-19, as well as wages paid to colleagues who worked during such sick colleagues' absences, rather
than as a result of increased wage rates), increased costs incurred in connection with goodwill
compensation paid to clothing suppliers, holiday markdowns, enhanced cleaning and related health and
safety measures, as well as higher retail operating expenditures.

We have considered the outbreak of COVID-19 to be a non-adjusting post-balance sheet event: the
impact on future results and cash flows is difficult to estimate and we have therefore considered a range
of scenarios as described in note 1 ("Accounting Policies") of the 2019 Financial Statements. See "Risk

_Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—The_
_impact of COVID-19 on our business and industry is significant and its effects will continue to create_
_uncertainty in our market and materially impact our business, financial condition and results of operations_
_for the foreseeable future due to many factors, most of which are beyond our control."_

We took significant steps during the first twelve weeks of the first lockdown period in the spring of 2020
to protect our most vulnerable colleagues, asking them to remain home on contracted pay in order to
ensure their safety, while we increased social-distancing and protective measures at our stores. When we
welcomed these colleagues back, we carried out individual risk assessments and conducted socialdistancing training for them. In September 2020, we further tightened our safety measures across our
stores to provide an enhanced level of protection to our customers and colleagues, introducing new door
marshals at the front of stores and increasing security presence in the aisles of larger stores; marshals
also provide sanitised baskets to customers as they enter stores. Colleagues continue to be on hand to
help customers with safety queries and reiterate government guidelines to wear a face covering and
maintain social distancing while they shop. Customers who do not have a face covering when they enter
the store are offered a pack of disposable masks that they can pay for as they complete their shopping.
Additional hand sanitisation stations are in place in the busiest sections of all stores in addition to the
multiple cleaning points already found throughout stores.

Should current safety guidelines continue, we believe that it is unlikely that we will continue to incur a
significant portion of the additional costs in the future that we incurred in responding to the COVID-19
pandemic during the first two lockdowns, as many of these costs incurred were one-off in nature. The chart
below shows the COVID-19 impacts for ASDA on a year-to-date basis as of September 30,

In March 2020, as part of a number of measures to support businesses during the COVID-19 pandemic,
the UK government, the Scottish government and the devolved administrations for Wales and Northern
Ireland announced full relief for rates charges applicable to certain eligible commercial properties for the
rates year beginning in April 2020 (and in the case of Northern Ireland, such support ended after July
2020). This relief applied to a number of properties owned or leased by the Group and as such, no rates
charge has been recognised in these accounts for the period to which this relief applied. On December 3,
2020, we publicly announced that we would voluntarily pay business rates for the April 2020/21 year on
the properties to which the relief applied. As rates relief was in place at September 30, 2020, no liability
existed at that date and as such, our directors have concluded that the announcement on December 3,
2020 is a non-adjusting post-balance sheet event per the guidance set out in IAS 10. Discussions with the
relevant local authorities relating to the timing of payment are ongoing.

following the CMA Clearance Date. In order to effect the distribution of the Forecourt Business to Acquisition 2 as a dividend
in kind, ASDA will have to arrange for the separation of the freehold or leasehold title to its co-located forecourts (comprising
the vast majority of the Forecourt Assets) from the parent title currently comprising adjacent store or retail assets or sites.
The entities within the ASDA Group that currently hold Forecourt Assets will then distribute such assets to Acquisition 2. We

### 50


-----

expect the process of effecting these title separations and distributions to take several months following the Acquisition
Completion Date. The headline enterprise value established under the Forecourt SPA, subject to customary working capital
adjustments, is £750 million, less the aggregate value of the Excluded Forecourts (and of any other assets relating to the
Excluded Forecourts). The consideration will be left outstanding at the closing of the Forecourt SPA (the "Forecourt Disposal
**Receivable") and we expect it to be settled in cash and in full promptly following the closing of the subsequent sale of Holdco**
or Property Newco pursuant to the separate agreement between Property Newco and Euro Garages Limited. See "Certain
_Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Forecourt SPA."_
Following closing under the Forecourt SPA, assuming no novation and assignment thereof, Bellis Topco Sub Limited will
acquire Midco from Holdco. The consideration for the transfer from Holdco will be the cancellation of Topco 2's class A shares
in Holdco. In connection with this transfer, Bellis Topco Sub Limited will issue additional shares to Topco 2. Following this
reorganisation (i) Bellis Topco Sub Limited will become the direct parent of Midco and an indirect parent of Midco 2, the
Senior Notes Issuer, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Purchaser and the ASDA Group, (ii) Property Newco will be the
sole shareholder in Holdco and (iii) Holdco's only direct subsidiary will be Bellis Forecourts Limited, which will be the direct
parent of Acquisition 2. Holdco or Property Newco will then be acquired by EG Group and the Forecourt Disposal Receivable
will be settled in cash, with the Senior Secured Notes Issuer being required under the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility
Agreement to use the proceeds of such payment to repay all or a portion of the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility. As an
alternative to the foregoing steps, the parties may decide to novate and assign the Forecourt SPA to the Company or one of
its subsidiaries (as seller) and/or to a member of the EG Group (as buyer), in which case the separate agreement between
Property Newco and Euro Garages Limited would be terminated and the Forecourt Business (or a holding company thereof)
would be sold directly to EG Group by the ASDA Group. The proceeds of such sale would be applied following receipt by the
ASDA Group to repay all or a portion of the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility. The transfer of the Forecourt Assets and the
implementation of the Forecourt Business Disposal entail certain risks, and there can be no assurance we will be able to
consummate these transactions as described herein or at all. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—We
_may not be able to consummate the Post-Completion Transactions as quickly as we anticipate, or at all, and the manner in_
_which we execute the Post-Completion Transactions may differ from what we present in this Offering Memorandum."_
(2) Following the CMA Clearance Date, ASDA will transfer the Warehouse Assets, the balances credited to the Designated Bank
Accounts, and, to the extent required by the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Agreement, some or all
of the Substitute Retail Assets and Select Retail Assets, to Bellis Select Warehouse Limited ("Propco 2") or other affiliates
who are obligors thereunder (the "Post-Completion Disposals") in exchange for consideration left outstanding (the "Post**Completion Disposal Receivables"). Alternatively, Select Retail Assets and, as relevant, Substitute Retail Assets may**
remain held by the ASDA Group but will continue to be charged in favour of the lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal
Bridge Facility as described in the paragraph below. ASDA will agree to subordinate its claims against Propco 2 or such other
affiliates to those of lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility pursuant to a separate subordination
agreement. The transfers of each of the Warehouse Assets and, to the extent required by the terms of the Distribution Asset
Disposal Bridge Facility, Substitute Retail Assets and Select Retail Assets in connection with the Post-Completion Disposals
will be subject to the ASDA Leases, which will remain in effect. To the extent any part of a Substitute Retail Asset or a Select
Retail Asset comprises a Forecourt Asset, following the CMA Clearance Date, if documents are agreed by such date, that
part of the ASDA Lease which comprises the Forecourt Asset will be surrendered (or, as applicable, renounced) and any
security affecting that part of the Substitute Retail Asset or the Select Retail Asset which comprises the Forecourt Asset will
be released, such that the Substitute Retail Asset or the Select Retail Asset will be transferred to Propco 2 or its affiliates (to
the extent required by the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility) without title to the Forecourt Asset, which
will be retained by ASDA by way of a Forecourt Assets Separation. If any relevant Substitute Retail Asset or Select Retail
Asset remains held by the ASDA Group at the time of the Forecourt Business Disposal, that part of the ASDA Lease which
comprises the Forecourt Asset will be surrendered (or, as applicable, renounced) and any security affecting that part of the
Substitute Retail Asset or the Select Retail Asset which comprises the Forecourt Asset will be released and the Distribution
Asset Disposal Bridge Facility will permit the disposal of the Forecourt Asset pursuant to the terms of the Forecourt SPA by
way of a Forecourt Assets Separation such that the remaining part of the Substitute Retail Asset or the Select Retail Asset
excludes the title to that Forecourt Asset.

The initial term of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility is one year from the Acquisition Completion Date, with the
Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower retaining an option to extend it for a further six months at its own
discretion. The Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility has no scheduled amortisation and we intend to repay it in full
ahead of maturity primarily with the net proceeds from the Warehouse Sale Transactions, which would have to be applied
promptly in mandatory prepayment of the facility. We may consummate Warehouse Sale Transactions before or after the
transfer of Bellis Select Warehouse Holdings Limited to the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower described in
footnote 3 below. Depending on market conditions and expected transaction values, the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge
Facility Borrower or Propco 2, as applicable, may also sell some or all of the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable,
some or all of the Substitute Retail Assets (in each case subject to ASDA Leases), the proceeds of which would also have to
be applied in mandatory prepayment of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. We anticipate that the Distribution
Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower (or Propco 2, as may be the case) will return to the Issuers, by way of contribution to
their equity, in-kind loan pursuant to a deeply subordinated instrument or repayment of Post-Completion Disposal
Receivables held by the Group, any Select Retail Assets and Substitute Retail Assets that it does not sell to repay the
Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, and, to the extent such proceeds are not used to repay amounts outstanding
under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, amounts equal to any net proceeds directly or indirectly received from
the sale of any Select Retail Assets and Substitute Retail Assets (including any Retail Asset Disposal Proceeds) (the "Retail
**Assets Contributions"). After the Retail Assets Contributions have been made, we expect to distribute any remaining Post-**
Completion Disposal Receivables to Topco, in the amounts that remain outstanding at the time, by way of dividends in kind,
and Topco to then arrange for such receivables to be extinguished by contribution to Propco 2.
In connection with sale transactions entered into by the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower, we may be
required to amend the terms of the ASDA Leases. Such amendments will be permitted under the Indentures and the Senior
Facilities Agreement, subject to compliance with the covenants described in "Description of the Senior Secured Notes—
_Certain Covenants—Limitation on Affiliate Transactions" and "Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants—_

Principles, the Senior Notes will be secured by (i)
first-priority security interests over (a) all the issued
Capital Stock of the Senior Notes Issuer, (b) the
Senior Notes Issuer's material intercompany
receivables owing by the Senior Secured Notes
Issuer, (c) the Senior Notes Issuer's material bank
accounts located in England and Wales and

may be released under certain circumstances.

and a portion of the amounts drawn under Facility B
in connection with the Acquisition, if the Acquisition
Completion Date occurs prior to the Issue Date.

If the Acquisition Completion Date is delayed until
after the Issue Date, unless the Offering is
consummated substantially concurrently with or
after the Acquisition, we will fund the gross proceeds
of the Offering into Escrow Accounts, which will be

controlled by the relevant Escrow Agent, and
pledged in favour of the relevant Trustee on behalf
of and for the benefit of the holders of the relevant
Notes, pursuant to the terms of the Escrow
Agreements and Escrow Account Charges dated on

the Acquisition Completion Date, subject to the

or levied by or on behalf of a Relevant Taxing
Jurisdiction is required by law to be made from any

restated. EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2019, for the nine months ended September 30, 2019, for the nine months ended
September 30, 2020 and for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020 is presented after giving effect to the adoption of IFRS 16. Adoption
of IFRS 16 in the year ended December 31, 2019 resulted in a decrease in operating costs of £31.4 million and an increase in finance costs
of £52.7 million compared to lease-related expenses charged in the prior year under IAS 17. Adoption of IFRS 16 is the primary reason for
the increase in finance lease interest of £52.7 million and the increase in depreciation of assets held under finance leases of £149.5 million
in the year ended December 31, 2019 compared to the prior year. The addition of these line items back into the calculation of EBITDA results
in a higher EBITDA than if EBITDA were prepared under IAS 17, which would include operating lease expense charges within EBITDA. The
operating lease expense included in EBITDA in the year ended December 31, 2018 is £188.3 million.

(B)   The elimination of IFRS 16 impact adjustment deducts from EBITDA rental payments made during the period in respect of finance leases
that would have been accounted for as operating leases under IAS 17 prior to the entry into force of IFRS 16 on January 1, 2019. Under IAS
17, our leases would be classified primarily as operating leases, with no assets or liabilities on the balance sheet and rental charges instead
of depreciation and interest in the income statement. Increases in rental charges of £133.8 million, £129.7 million and £177.9 million for the
nine-month periods ended September 30, 2019 and September 30, 2020, and the year ended December 31, 2019, respectively, are
recognised through the foregoing adjustments within EBITDA. Additionally, below EBITDA adjustments decreasing depreciation and
amortisation by £107.7 million, £104.1 million and £143.6 million, and adjustments decreasing interest by £38.4 million, £37.6 million and
£51.3 million for the same respective periods have also been made.

(C)   The asset write-off adjustment relates to the non-cash write off of all tangible fixed assets with value written off in the normal course of
business, usually as a result of store or depot remodelling activities. 2019 also includes an additional write off for some work in progress on
an IT system project.

### 71


-----

(D) The prior year ATM rates adjustment reflects the removal of income that has been included in EBITDA following a change in the assessment
of business rates for automated teller machines (ATMs). In 2020, a retrospective change was made, as a result of which the Company was
entitled to a refund for business rates previously paid. This adjustment removes the income resulting from those refunds for periods earlier
than financial year 2020.

(E) The bonus top-up adjustment comprises discretionary retrospective enhancements to the annual bonus over and above the parameters of
the standard bonus structure.

(F) The contract implementation costs adjustment comprises one-off costs relating to the implementation of a new contract for retail colleagues
in 2019. In particular, these cost comprised (i) a one-off cost associated with estimated incremental costs as a result of the one-to-one
consultations with individual colleagues affected by the proposals, which required such colleagues to be absent from work on the retail shop
floor and replaced with incremental time from other colleagues, and (ii) a holiday pay top-up resulting from a transitional agreement made
with colleagues to top-up their holiday allowance for 2019 after the new colleague contract introduced in November 2019.

(G) The merger costs adjustment reflects an adjustment to remove the directly attributable one-off costs incurred as part of the proposed merger
between the Company and J Sainsbury's plc that was subsequently abandoned following CMA review. The adjustment reflects actual costs
incurred and management's judgement around which costs were directly attributable to the proposed merger. Costs include consultancy and
legal fees, as well as one-off retention bonuses paid to colleagues in connection with that transaction. The proposed merger was announced
in May 2018 and the CMA's review was completed in April 2019.

(H) The pension contribution adjustment comprises one-off transitional arrangement voluntarily made by the Company that included two annual
payments to colleagues' pension funds resulting from changes to the eligibility regime for such contributions.

(I) The transaction bonuses adjustment comprises £0.5 million accrued for one-off bonuses that will be paid to colleagues working on the
Acquisition. There are expected to be additional transactional bonuses accrued prior to completion.

(J) The restructuring adjustments comprise one-off provisions relating to severance costs in connection with the restructuring of home office
functions.

(K) The pension guarantee adjustment removes amounts paid to Walmart in connection with Walmart's guarantee of the ASDA defined benefit
pension scheme. This guarantee payment was terminated when the pension scheme buy-in was completed in October 2019. Therefore,
these charges will not continue on a going-forward basis.

(L) Options in Walmart shares have historically been awarded to employees of the Company; these share option awards have been accounted
for within EBITDA as cash settled equity awards. As no new awards of such options in Walmart shares will be granted and all existing options
in Walmart shares will be settled within six months following the Separation, the corresponding charges will fall away and, as a result, are
added back for the relevant periods (for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020, £96.3 million, for the nine months ended September 30,
2019 and 2020, £116.7 million and £83.7 million, respectively, and for the years ended December 31, 2018 and 2019, £44.6 million and
£129.3 million, respectively). On a going-forward basis, the Company will, however, enhance other colleague incentive programmes. The
estimated annual incremental cost of these enhanced incentive programmes is estimated to be £38 million. Therefore, a charge of £38.0
million has been included for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020 as well as the years ended December, 31 2018 and 2019. A prorated charge of £28.5 million has been included for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 and 2020. This adjustment thus reflects the
net amount remaining following the removal of the Walmart shares options and the incremental cost of the enhanced colleague incentive
programmes.

(M)   The Walmart royalties adjustment reflects the removal of royalties paid by the Company to Walmart as part of an advance pricing agreement
calculated using a transfer pricing methodology whereby the amount payable is based on the financial performance of ASL. The services
covered by the charge include the use of Walmart intellectual property, which is broadly defined as trade marks, business strategies and
business systems. These costs will no longer be applicable following the Separation. However, on-going use of Walmart's trade marks,
business strategies and business systems will be covered by the TSA, the TMA and the ASA.

(N)   The ISD recharge adjustment removes recharges paid to Walmart in respect of IT services that are allowable for tax purposes. This cost will
no longer be applicable following the Separation. However, some of the same services that this cost captures will be covered by the TSA.

(O) The TSA charge adjustment relates the charge under the TSA for on-going access to Walmart's IT services, business systems and
technology related intellectual property following the Separation.

(P) For the 12 months ended September 30, 2020, other adjustments relate to: £8.0 million in adjustments relating to the impact of having had
an additional trading day in February 2020 as a result of leap year and £10.0 million in IT and non-IT costs relating to ASDA operating as a
standalone company. These costs include the increase in the commissions payable by the Company as consideration for the services
provided to the Company by Walmart Global Sourcing, the increase in costs associated with ocean freight, the costs incurred in connection
with the creation of new roles to replace certain capabilities previously sourced from Walmart and the cost of insurance cover replacing the
insurance cover ASDA has received prior to the Separation through Walmart under Walmart's umbrella insurance policies.

(Q) This adjustment relates to certain one-off costs due to the impact of COVID-19 (£226 million), net of certain one-off benefits related to the
UK government's business rates holiday for businesses affected by COVID-19 (£171 million). Management has identified incremental costs
for the first three quarters of 2020 due to COVID-19, including costs resulting from colleague absences (due to quarantine requirements and
protective measures taken for vulnerable colleagues), a one-time "thank you" bonus paid by the Company, costs relating to goods not for
resale (e.g., face masks, safety provisions, additional security and screens), incremental inventory and supplier costs and the impact of
changes in product mix that are expected to be temporary. Management identified a one-off benefit of £171 million, being approximately £28
million per month for the period from April 2020 to September 2020, resulting from a business rates holiday announced by the UK
government, which applies to businesses in eligible sectors, including retail businesses, for the UK 2020-2021 tax year. On December 3,
2020, however, ASDA announced its decision to pay business rates tax relief accepted from the UK government in 2020. In calculating this
adjustment we have not taken into account any benefit related to the increase in revenues we have experienced as a result of and during
the COVID-19 pandemic.

(R) In connection with the Acquisition, the Shareholders engaged an international leading consultant to assist them in conducting financial and
operational due diligence on ASDA management's plan, with a particular focus on SG&A costs (excluding personnel costs). Based on these
due diligence activities conducted to date in connection with the Acquisition, the Shareholders currently believe that there is an opportunity
to achieve net run-rate cost savings of £60 million from ASDA's SG&A cost base (excluding personnel costs) within 18 months of the
Acquisition Completion Date. In particular, the Shareholders expect projected cost savings from product rationalisation and business
integration initiatives. While detailed bottom-up plans are yet to be developed due to regulatory restrictions in place prior to the CMA's
approval of the Acquisition, these SG&A cost savings estimated to be realised within 18 months of the Acquisition Completion Date represent
only 1.3% of ASDA's SG&A costs of £4.5 billion during the 12 months ended September 30, 2020. The CMA might complete its regulatory
approval process relating to the Acquisition later than currently anticipated. Any such delay by the CMA might limit our ability to achieve
these expected SG&A cost savings, whether within the timeframe or to the full extent currently anticipated. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating
_to the Transactions—The Acquisition is subject to certain uncertainties and risks, which could adversely impact recoveries under the Notes"_
and "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart."
