**Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry**

**Risks Relating to Our General Operations**

**_We operate in a highly competitive industry and our business, financial condition and results_**
**_operations, as well as the strength of our brand, may be materially adversely affected by actions_**
**_of our competitors and our failure to respond to competitive pressures._**

The UK grocery market is particularly competitive. There can be no assurance that we can continue to
successfully compete with existing competitors or new market entrants. Our competition generally includes
international and domestic brick-and-mortar retailers (including, generalist grocers, supermarket chains,
discount retailers, grocery specialists and convenience stores), some of which also operate omni-channel
businesses, as well as online pure players, such as Amazon and Ocado. In recent years, the historically
stable grocery retail market in the United Kingdom has undergone a structural shift towards discounters,
such as Aldi and Lidl, convenience formats and online retailers, to the detriment of traditional supermarkets
and hypermarkets. We generally compete for, among other things, customers, market share, employees,
digital prominence, products and services and in other important aspects of the business with many other
local, regional, national and global omni-channel retailers, wholesale operators and retail intermediaries.
Our competitors generally compete with us on the basis of, among other things, price, quality, selection,
availability, services offered to customers, location, store hours, in-store amenities, shopping convenience,
brand reputation, overall shopping experience, attractiveness and ease of use of our online platforms, cost
and delivery speed of merchandise purchased through our digital platforms or through our omni-channel
integration of our physical and digital operations.

In executing our strategy, we may face a variety of competitive challenges, including, among others:

  - potential emergence of new competitors, including foreign and domestic retailers entering our
markets, or consolidation, strengthening or expanded offerings of existing operators, as has been
the case in recent years with the emergence of discounters (for more information, see "Industry"
and "Business—Key Strengths");

  - potential creation by competitors of new store formats, additional convenience grocery retail store
offerings, in-store or online services, delivery and pick-up options or online platforms that
customers may prefer;

  - the risk of our competitors successfully adopting our business model in their own stores;

  - competitive pressure on product pricing from core competitors, as well as discount and online
retailers; and

  - the risk of our competitors providing better service, quality, value or availability of products.

The performance of our competitors and changes in their pricing, promotions, product mix or other
business strategies, and our response (or failure to respond) to such competitive pressures, may lead to
lower sales revenue, higher operating expenses and/or lower profit margins and may require a significant
amount of management attention and resources, which may disrupt or otherwise have a material adverse
effect on our ongoing business operations. There can be no assurance that, with evolving customer
preferences, our customers will not shift towards competitors with a different business model.

### 75


-----

Even in geographies, channels and formats where we have a strong retail presence, we face the risk
that new retail market entrants may attempt to gain market share through pricing pressure. For example,
the UK grocery retail market has seen the rapid growth of discounters (mainly represented by Aldi and
Lidl) that compete through differentiation on price coupled with a more limited selection of own-brand
products. We experience downward pricing pressure, and if we are unable to maintain our competitive
position, we could experience additional downward pressure on prices, lower demand for our products,
reduced retail margins, the inability to take advantage of new business opportunities and the loss of market
share, which could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.

In recent years, and in particular during the COVID-19 pandemic, the demand for online shopping
services has increased substantially and many of our competitors have expanded their online offerings. If
our competitors are able to offer faster or cheaper deliveries, and/or more convenient delivery options, we
could lose current or potential customers, our brand and reputation could suffer, all of which could have a
material adverse effect on our results of operations. To remain competitive, we must continue to develop
and enhance our online offering and the information systems that support our online activities, as well
continue to optimise our logistics and distribution capabilities. This may require the acquisition of
equipment and software and the development, either internally or through third-parties, of new proprietary
software and logistics and distribution solutions. In addition, any impairment of or disruption to our supply
chain or delivery fleet could result in a disruption in the delivery of our products to our online customers,
which could harm our brand and could generate additional costs. Furthermore, the online grocery industry
in the United Kingdom may not sustain or improve upon current levels of demand, and we may fail to
develop our online retail proposition to successfully appeal to a broader customer base and sustain current
growth rates. If we are unable to effectively compete with our online competitors or if we fail to retain and
attract online customers, this may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and
results of operations. Additionally, we may fail to successfully compete with the growing convenience retail
market. If we are unable to successfully expand our operations into the convenience retail market and the
convenience retail market continues to grow, this may have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations.

**_The impact of COVID-19 on our business and industry is significant and its effects will continue to_**
**_create uncertainty in our market and materially impact our business, financial condition and results_**
**_of operations for the foreseeable future due to many factors, most of which are beyond our control._**

In late 2019, a new strain of coronavirus (severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 or SARSCoV-2), which can cause coronavirus disease (COVID-19), was detected in Wuhan, China. In March 2020,
the World Health Organization declared COVID-19 a global pandemic and governmental authorities
around the world implemented measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19. For example, in March 2020,
the United Kingdom imposed the first set of significant lockdown measures to control the spread of COVID19. These measures to stop the spread of COVID-19 have adversely affected workforces, customer
sentiment, economies and financial markets, and, along with causing overall decreased customer
spending and widespread uncertainty following months of lockdowns and related uncertainty, have led to
an economic downturn in the United Kingdom and have had a direct impact on our business.

COVID-19 poses a risk to our colleagues, our customers, our suppliers and the communities in which
we operate. As the pandemic has developed, customer fear about becoming ill with the virus and
recommendations and/or mandates from national and local authorities to social distance or self-quarantine
have continued to have an impact on the UK marketplace. These recommendations and mandates, as
well as general fears about gathering in public places, has adversely affected, among other things, our instore traffic, our ability to adequately staff our stores, depots, packing and processing facilities and other
facilities and our suppliers' ability to provide products on a timely basis. See "Management's Discussion
_and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Our Result of_
_Operations—COVID-19." If we do not respond appropriately or in a timely enough manner to the pandemic_
and its effects, or if customers or colleagues perceive our response to be inadequate or inappropriate, our
brand, reputation, business, financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely
affected.

Resurgences (or "waves") of COVID-19 are likely to occur. We cannot predict when or where these
waves will occur, the duration of such waves, how far into the future such waves will continue to occur nor
can we predict with any certainty the impacts of such subsequent waves, including the impacts of future
national or local lockdowns or other measures implemented by national and/or local authorities. As of
January 2021, subsequent waves of COVID-19 were significantly affecting many countries, including the
United Kingdom and other countries from which we source products, with cases rising markedly in recent
weeks and with new, more contagious strains of the virus emerging. On October 12, 2020, the UK Prime
Minister announced a three-tiered system of restrictions across England, which came into effect on

### 76


-----

October 14, 2020 in order to help control the spread of the virus. Under this system, regions are classified
as either 'medium', 'high' or 'very high' risk and assigned increasingly stringent lockdown restrictions to
correspond with their designated tier. On November 5, 2020, the United Kingdom imposed its second set
of significant lockdown measures, which ended on December 2, 2020. On December 18, 2020, the UK
Prime Minister announced the addition of a fourth tier in the COVID-19 restrictions system, due to the
presence of a new, more infectious variant of the virus in the United Kingdom. On December 20, the United
Kingdom imposed its third set of significant lockdown measures and placed the South East of the United
Kingdom, including London, into tier four lockdown. On January 4, 2021 the UK Prime Minister announced
the addition of a fifth tier in the COVID-19 restrictions system, the highest level of COVID-19 restrictions,
due to the record high and escalating case numbers of COVID-19 present in the United Kingdom. In tier
five, England is in a full lockdown, pursuant to which all persons are instructed to stay home except for a
few necessary purposes, including essential work and buying food and medicine. The tier five lockdown
is expected to continue until at least February 15, 2021. While none of our grocery retail stores have been
closed as a result of such lockdowns, there can be no guarantee that this will continue to be the case or
that more stringent rules and restrictions will not be applied in the future in a manner that could materially
adversely impact our business. Additionally, local authorities have imposed and may impose stricter rules
and restrictions in addition to those imposed by the national tiered system, which may have further material
adverse impacts on our business and industry. The placement of areas into the tiers is outside of our
control and is expected to be dynamic and unpredictable for the foreseeable future. The tiered alert system
applies only to England: the devolved administrations in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are in
charge of designing and implementing their own COVID-19 restrictions, which may be as or more stringent
than the English tiered system. In light of rising case levels in the United Kingdom and around the world,
future national and local lockdowns are foreseeable. Additionally, there may be a decrease in demand for
certain of our products in the event of further resurgences of COVID-19 or the occurrence of other
pandemics, other public health emergencies or threats, or potential or perceived threats to food and drug
safety, any of which may necessitate certain regulatory responses and the result of which may materially
adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

We currently operate our grocery retail stores and facilities as an "essential" business. If the
classification of what an "essential" business is changes, or other government regulations are adopted,
we may be required to severely or even completely curtail operations, which would have a material adverse
impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Even though our stores and facilities
are considered essential businesses, national and local authorities may impose regulations and limitations
on the operations of our stores and facilities, such as, among other things, limiting customer traffic, hours
of operation or access to certain products (as has been the case in Wales, where "firebreak" measures
have limited the products that grocery retailers are permitted to sell during the firebreak period to certain
essential goods), requiring us to implement track and trace measures and mandating certain health and
safety measures. Complying with these regulations and limitations requires the diversion of financial and
human resources away from other parts of our business and increases costs, which may have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, our noncompliance, or perceived non-compliance with lockdown measures could lead to formal sanctions and
could also harm our brand and reputation.

Even while our stores are open, social distancing and other policies implemented to slow the further
spread of COVID-19 may impact the operation and appeal of our stores. For example, customers
unaccustomed to wearing face coverings or observing social distancing guidance may choose to shop
online, which may reduce our in-store business. Even when social distancing policies are lifted, interest in
visiting stores and making discretionary purchases may remain weak due to health concerns or
recessionary spending patterns. Furthermore, we believe that some of the changes that have arisen during
and in response to the COVID-19 pandemic by us and in the United Kingdom as a whole will be persistent
and potentially long-lasting, while others may be less so. For example, following the end of the pandemic,
there may be a shift of consumer preferences to more out-of-home dining, which could materially adversely
affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Certain of our colleagues have tested positive for COVID-19. We have, and may in the future be
required to temporarily close certain of our stores, offices or other facilities for cleaning or to take other
responsive or precautionary measures. Likewise, planned construction, renovation and maintenance, as
well as the opening of new stores may be delayed, suspended or terminated due to COVID-19-related
requirements, such as requiring that workers only leave their homes for essential business, or due to the
suspension of governmental permit issuances due to the pandemic. Where appropriate and possible, we
have transitioned a significant number of our colleagues to a remote work environment, in an effort to
mitigate the spread of COVID-19, which may exacerbate certain risks to our business.

### 77


-----

A large part of our workforce, such as our colleagues who work in our stores, factories or our distribution
facilities, cannot work remotely and we cannot be certain that the measures we have taken can fully
mitigate the risks posed to them and to our customers by COVID-19 and we may be subject to potential
litigation as a result of colleagues alleging that we have facilitated an unsafe working environment or have
increased their exposure to COVID-19, or customers or colleagues who claim they have contracted the
virus at our stores or other facilities, which may cause us to incur significant costs and which may have a
negative impact on our brand and reputation. During the first lockdown, we experienced increased costs,
including, amongst others, as a result of goodwill payments to suppliers, increased employment costs
relating to increased absences (including for sick colleagues or colleagues following quarantine
recommendations), full pay to vulnerable staff members during the 12-week isolation period, employment
of safety marshals and operation of stores with extended hours to decrease store congestion. Certain of
these costs continued during the second lockdown and we may be subject to similar costs in the event of
future lockdowns. We may also be subject to potential litigation initiated by colleagues alleging that we
have facilitated an unsafe working environment or have increased their exposure to COVID-19. All of these
risks may be further exacerbated by resurgences of the virus. Although the government has increasingly
employed sophisticated strategies for combatting the virus such as Test and Trace and localised R-factor
measurement in an effort to avoid costly and extensive lockdown measures, the magnitude of possible
virus resurgences and the resulting impacts on the economy may materially negatively impact our
business, financial condition, and results of operations.

Our business is sensitive to reductions in discretionary spending by customers, public health events
and other factors described elsewhere in this "Risk Factors" section. To date, the COVID-19 pandemic
has caused, and is continuing to cause, significant disruption in economic activity globally, which is
expected to lead to a decline in discretionary spending. Our revenue may be negatively impacted by
adverse changes in the perceived or actual economic climate, including higher unemployment rates,
declines in income levels and loss of personal wealth resulting from the impact of COVID-19 and measures
implemented to respond to it. Although we are generating revenue, our revenue may not increase in
proportion to our fixed costs and deferred costs and our revenue may not be sufficient to offset the full
impact of a potential shutdown of our stores, were that to occur, or curtailment of our operations. If our
cost base is higher than our revenue, our cash management policies may fail due to factors beyond our
control. In 2020, our profitability has been adversely impacted by COVID-19 in terms of increased costs
associated with retail colleague wages, bonus payments and higher retail operating expenditures. During
the first lockdown, consumers favoured convenience stores over larger grocery retail stores. Unlike the
traditional grocers, currently we do not operate any convenience grocery retail stores and, as a result, this
shift towards convenience grocery retail stores adversely affected us. Future lockdowns with similar
consumer preferences could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of
operations. COVID-19 has also impacted our sales in terms of product mix, with changing customer habits
towards less out-of-home consumption, stockpiling and increased use of online grocery services driving
higher food sales volumes, while decreased clothing sales and the temporary closure of our ASDA Living
stores has led to decreases in non-food sales and the effects of lockdowns on automobile usage has
driven decreases in fuel sales.

During the first wave of COVID-19 and the accompanying lockdown periods, we relied on access to
government aid and mitigation programmes, including the business rates relief holiday for the 2020 to
2021 tax year. Our mitigation strategy was reinforced by legislation such as the UK Coronavirus Act 2020,
the Coronavirus (Scotland) Acts of 2020 and the UK Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020,
which introduced certain protections in relation to lease forfeitures (and irritancies), and temporary
restrictions on the ability of creditors to file statutory demands and winding up petitions in the United
Kingdom based solely on the failure to comply with (for example) rent payment obligations as a result of
COVID-19. However, in December 2020, we announced our intention to voluntarily resume payments of
the applicable business rate, for the period during the COVID-19 pandemic where we had benefitted from
the business rates holiday relief. We estimate that the payment of business rates for the full period of the
business rates holiday to range from approximately £320 million to £340 million. While we have entered
into initial discussions with HMRC around repayment, the mechanism and timing of repayment has not yet
been agreed. During subsequent waves of COVID-19 such government aid, mitigation programmes,
negotiations with landlords and/or protective legislation may not be available to the same extent as in the
past and our cash outlay levels to meet ongoing additional COVID-19 related costs might be significantly
higher during such subsequent waves than they were during the first wave. Therefore, we would only be
able to rely on our ability to pause capital expenditures, implement cost reductions and defer payments,
which could significantly reduce our overall ability to mitigate potential cash burn.

### 78


-----

In addition to the lockdown measures imposed in the United Kingdom, on December 20, 2020,
numerous countries across Europe, including France, imposed travel restrictions on travellers from the
United Kingdom in response to the discovery and spread of the more infectious variant of the virus in the
United Kingdom. Such restrictions resulted in a temporary disruption of the main trade routes between
Europe and the United Kingdom, in particular at UK ports.

On December 21, 2020, the Port of Dover halted all exports to France for 48 hours in response to the
travel restrictions imposed by the French government on travellers from the United Kingdom. We rely on
UK ports such as the Port of Dover to import a large portion of our supplies. We can provide no assurance
that significant restrictions affecting movement of goods into or out of UK ports will not be imposed in the
future, including as a measure to control the spread of COVID-19. Such restrictions may result in significant
disruption and delays to our supply chain and may require us to incur additional costs or make
amendments to our usual supply chain, which may in turn have a material and adverse effect on our
business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

On December 22, 2020, France reopened its borders with the United Kingdom to lorry drivers, provided
they are tested for COVID-19. Future travel restrictions due to the COVID-19 pandemic imposed by France
or other European countries could lead to further and longer supply disruptions for the goods we import
from or through Europe. Such disruptions could result in our inability to offer certain products to customers
or force us to increase prices of certain products, which could have a material adverse effect on our
revenues and, as a result, our business, financial condition and results of operations.

In addition to the factors listed above, COVID-19 and the measures taken to respond to it have created
an environment of uncertainty and rapid, unpredictable changes that exacerbates and magnifies certain
of the other risks we face. The effect of COVID-19 on our business and our wider industry will ultimately
depend on a number of factors, including, but not limited to, the duration and severity of the pandemic in
the United Kingdom and globally, the length of time it takes for demand to return to normal levels and for
normal economic and operating conditions to resume and the potential for, and uncertainty surrounding,
virus resurgence. There are no comparable recent events that provide us with guidance, and so we cannot
yet know the full impact of COVID-19 on our business with any certainty nor can we provide any assurance
that COVID-19 will not have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of
operations in the future. To the extent COVID-19 impacts our business, financial condition and results of
operations, it may also have the effect of heightening other risks described in this "Risk Factors" section,
such as those relating to our high level of indebtedness, our need to generate sufficient cash flows to
service our indebtedness and our ability to comply with the covenants contained in the agreements that
govern our indebtedness. Each of the factors above may have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations. See "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial
_Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Our Result of Operations—COVID-19."_

**_The United Kingdom's withdrawal from the European Union may lead to increased costs and_**
**_potential staff shortages, adverse currency impacts and increased regulatory burden._**

We are a UK-based company and operate principally within the United Kingdom. On June 23, 2016, a
majority of voters in the United Kingdom opted to withdraw from the European Union in a national
referendum and on January 31, 2020, the United Kingdom withdrew from the European Union ("Brexit").
On December 24, 2020, it was announced that a draft trade and cooperation agreement had been agreed
between the United Kingdom government and the EU Commission. This agreement has provisional
application as of January 1, 2021, was ratified on December 30, 2020 by the UK Parliament and is subject
to formal approval by the European Parliament. If the agreement is not formally approved by the European
Parliament, the United Kingdom will no longer have access to the European Union Single Market, which,
could result, among other things, in the disruption of the free movement of goods, services and people
between the United Kingdom and the European Union, undermine bilateral cooperation in key geographic
areas and significantly disrupt trade between the United Kingdom and the European Union or other nations
as the United Kingdom pursues independent trade relations. This could have an impact on our operations
and on the general and economic conditions in the United Kingdom.

Following withdrawal from the European Union, barrier-free trade access between the United Kingdom
and other member states of the European Union could be diminished or eliminated and the United
Kingdom may no longer be covered by trade agreements entered into by the European Union which apply
to all member states and so will either have to seek to negotiate new trade agreements or join existing
trade agreements (such as the World Trade Organisation tariffs) which could result in the transfer of goods
between the European Union and the United Kingdom, or between certain non-European Union countries
and the United Kingdom, becoming subject to import/export duties and/or non-tariff trade barriers
(including health and safety, product labelling and other standards, many of which are currently
standardised across the European Union). Such trade barriers could lead to delays to our logistics and

### 79


-----

distribution operations including delays in the importation of fresh produce or a reduction of our product
catalogue (we have modelled scenarios with respect to a reduction in capacity at Calais and have instituted
a port delay risk mitigation plan to be deployed in case of delays) and result in the cost of doing business
being materially adversely affected if not passed on, in whole or in part, to customers in the form of price
increases. Even if we are able to pass on some or all of such costs through price increases, such price
increases may influence customer spending decisions and priorities and adversely impact our revenue.
According to UK government figures, in 2019, 26% of food consumed in the United Kingdom was sourced
from the European Union, and we believe that a similar percentage applies to our own food sales. A loss
of access to global trade deals could lead to import tariffs that increase our supply costs.

Additionally, since we operate 17 stores in Northern Ireland, Brexit could have an additional impact on
our business, results of operation and prospects due to significant bureaucratic hurdles. Currently, the EU
has granted the United Kingdom a six-month exemption from the EU ban on prohibited and restricted
goods (such as minced meat) being transported into Northern Ireland. Once this exemption ends in July
2021, ASDA will require alternative sourcing. In addition, current Brexit proposals would result in the
required significant re-labelling and customs classification and declarations on products sold in Northern
Ireland. We may not be able to preserve our profit margin during periods of increased food inflation and
increased production costs without suffering reduced revenue, which in turn could have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Another potential outcome of the
United Kingdom's withdrawal from the European Union is that limitations may be placed on the principle
of free movement of people which currently permits European Union nationals to work in the United
Kingdom. IPL and certain of our primary producers and suppliers currently employ a significant number of
European Union nationals and since the United Kingdom's withdrawal from the European Union is
expected to lead to restrictions being placed on European Union nationals working in the United Kingdom,
the number of people employed by these primary producers and suppliers may decline which could have
a material and adverse effect on their business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

The referendum result has created significant political and economic uncertainty about the future
relationship between the United Kingdom and the European Union generally, and the United Kingdom's
future trading relationship with countries within and outside the European Union specifically, which could
make adverse changes in general economic conditions or adverse exchange rate movements more likely
to occur and which could, in turn, have a material and adverse effect on our operations and financial
performance.

The United Kingdom's withdrawal from the European Union, including the above effects and others we
cannot anticipate, could lead to increased costs, potential staff shortages, adverse currency impacts and
increased regulatory burden and could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations,
financial condition and prospects. See also "—The occurrence of catastrophic events, such as war,
_terrorist attacks, civil unrest, disruptive geopolitical events, epidemics, pandemics and natural disasters,_
_could materially adversely affect our and our suppliers' (including other third parties on which we rely)_
_business, financial condition and results of operations."_

**_Any events that negatively impact the reputation of, or value associated with, our brands could_**
**_materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and prospects._**

Our brand and reputation constitute a significant part of our value proposition. Our success has been
founded in part on our ability to develop our brand as a leading UK retailer of quality, competitively priced
grocery, clothing and general merchandise. Maintaining the reputation of and value associated with our
brand is central to the success of our business. This can be an especially difficult task for retailers,
particularly in light of the development of social media in recent years, which has led to a sharp increase
in reputational risks. Any event, such as a significant product recall or negative press reaction to
statements made or actions taken, or the failure to make certain statements or take certain actions, by us
or our senior management, that could damage our brand or reputation or cause customers to lose
confidence in the safety and quality of the products we sell could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

Our principal brand names and trade marks (such as the ASDA logo) are key assets of our business.
See "Business—Our Intellectual Property." We rely upon a combination of copyright and trade mark laws
to establish and protect our intellectual property rights, but cannot be certain that the actions we have
taken or will take in the future will be adequate to prevent material violation of our proprietary rights. There
can be no assurance that litigation will not be necessary to enforce our trade mark or proprietary rights or
to defend ourselves against claimed infringement of the rights of third parties. Adverse publicity, legal
action or other factors could lead to substantial erosion in the value of our brand, which could lead to
decreased customer demand and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and
results of operations. See also "—From time to time we and/or our management are subject to claims that

### 80


-----

_can result in litigation, arbitration, tax or regulatory proceedings which could distract management from_
_our business activities and result in significant liability."_

The brand names of our own-brand products also represent an important asset of our business. Certain
of these own-brand items are manufactured and/or packaged by third parties, and while our policies set
out quality control standards, we do not control these third parties or their quality control, employment,
ethics or other business practices. If we are unable to control and guarantee the quality of our own-brand
products, our reputation may be damaged, which may result in a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations. Maintaining broad market acceptance of our own-brand items
depends on many factors, including pricing, costs, quality and customer perception, and we may not
achieve or maintain expected sales for our own-brand label items. See also "—We rely on certain suppliers
_and partners, some of which are third parties, and any failure by these suppliers and partners to comply_
_with obligations could have a materially adverse impact our brand, reputation, business, results of_
_operations and financial condition and our agreements with these suppliers and partners may be subject_
_to adjustments that could increase our expenses."_

In light of the stringent employment, health and safety, environmental and other regulations to which
we are subject and the scrutiny we face from, among others, regulators, other national or local authorities,
non-governmental organisations and other stakeholders, a violation, or allegations of a violation of such
laws or regulations, or a failure to achieve particular standards by any of our suppliers or manufacturers
we purchase goods from, could lead to unfavourable publicity and a decline in demand for our products,
or require us to incur additional costs or to make changes to our supply chain and other business
arrangements to ensure compliance. Any such events concerning us or any of the manufacturers or
suppliers that supply products to us could substantially erode the reputation of, or value associated with,
our brands and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial conditions and results of
operations. Likewise, any failure to meet workplace health and safety or other legal standards and any
death, injury or illness to customers, colleagues, contractors, suppliers or third parties may lead to a loss
of trust and confidence in us, as well as litigation and/or financial or other penalties being imposed.

**_Adverse developments with respect to the safety and quality of our products, including loss of_**
**_customer confidence in the food supply chain or the quality and safety of our products for any_**
**_reason, and/or concerns about the safety of the food industry in general, may damage our_**
**_reputation, increase our costs of operations or decrease demand for our products._**

Food and product safety and food hygiene and traceability (including in respect of product origins,
freshness and conditions of preservation through the supply chain) are top priorities for us: the actual
safety of the food and other products and services we offer, as well as the public's perception of that safety,
are essential to our business, brand and reputation. We are subject to a number of food safety and hygiene
regulations. See "Business—Regulation—Food Safety, Hygiene, Labelling and Nutrition and Consumer
_Protection." Failures to comply with these regulations could result in a number of adverse consequences,_
including fines, loss of licences, costs of compliance or certification requirements.

We may not be able to ensure that our customers always enjoy safe, quality products. We sell food for
human consumption, which subjects us to safety risks such as contamination (including the presence of
an undeclared allergen, a foreign object, substance, unintentional microbe or chemical, other agent or
residue or the introduction of a genetically modified organism), spoilage, mislabelling and product
tampering, all of which could lead to product withdrawals or recalls or destruction of inventory and could
result in bad publicity, temporary store or warehouse closures and substantial costs in connection with
compliance or remediation. We may also be impacted by any assertion that our products have caused
illness or injury, whether true or false, proven or unproven. We could also be subject to claims or lawsuits
relating to an actual or alleged illness or injury stemming from product contamination, spoilage,
mislabelling, product tampering or any other incidents that compromise the safety and quality of our
products. From time to time we also recall products.

Risks to the health of our customers can also arise from our branded and own label suppliers, some of
whom are third-parties who operate outside of our direct control, in relation to the ingredients, foods and
products we sell in our stores. For example, we rely on suppliers, some of whom are third-parties who
operate outside of our control, for ingredients, foods and products we sell in our stores. Our use of thirdparty suppliers increases the risk that any of the aforementioned types of incidents could be caused by
factors outside of our control and that multiple locations could be affected. In addition, food or product
safety-related risks may also occur under any one of our own-brand labels and we may be impacted by
negative publicity regarding any assertion that our food or other products have resulted in illness or injury.
Our customers expect that we will provide them with a large selection of safe, high-quality products. If we
are unable to control and guarantee the quality of the products we sell, especially our own-brand products
and in-store services, our brand and reputation may be negatively impacted.

### 81


-----

We rely upon electrical power to operate all of our facilities across our distribution network. To attain
maximum performance, these types of facilities must often operate on a continuous basis and at the
appropriate pre-set temperatures. As a result, any shortage or interruption in power supply may result in
food spoilage and any extended power supply shortages or interruptions could result in perishable food
losses, each of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results
of operations. Cold chain requirements, setting out the temperatures at which our ingredients and products
must be stored and transported, are established both by law and by us to help guarantee the safety of our
food products. Our cold chain must be maintained from the moment the ingredients arrive at, or are frozen
by, our suppliers, through transportation and ultimately to the time of sale in our stores or delivery to our
customers. A failure in our cold chain could lead to food spoilage, risks to the health of our customers,
fines and other penalties and damage to our brand and reputation, each of which could materially
adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Consumers are increasingly focused on the traceability of food products to assist them in deciding what
to purchase. In January 2013, incidents of horse meat in parts of the European food supply chain
mislabelled as beef were identified, negatively impacting retailers and producers throughout Europe,
including ASDA, and led to additional standards, such as BRC standards on traceability, food fraud and
food defence. While we conduct quality practices and procedures, it may be difficult to detect
contamination, spoilage, mislabelling, product tampering or any other incidents that compromise the safety
and quality of our products, particularly fraudulent or malicious activity. Adverse publicity about these types
of problems, whether valid or not, may discourage customers from buying our products or may affect our
brand and reputation. Our actual or perceived sale of unsafe food products could result in product liability
claims, a loss of customer confidence, product recalls and legal claims, which could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

We also face additional risks from product defects in relation to the sale of our non-food products,
including, for example, the risks of battery explosions, appliance malfunction or toys or other items that
prove to be dangerous. If products we purchase from our suppliers are damaged or defective, we may not
be able to return products to these suppliers and obtain refunds on our purchase price or obtain
indemnification from them for any damages caused. Our brand and reputation could be damaged by the
marketing of such dangerous or defective products, especially in case of serious defects, such as products
containing harmful substances, causing death, physical harm or other health problems. In addition, there
is a risk that compliance lapses by us or by our suppliers could occur, which could lead to investigation by
agencies responsible for customer product safety. In all such cases, especially if there is a prolonged
impact on product quality, our brand and reputation, business, financial condition and results of operations
may be materially adversely affected.

Certain risks are inherent in the operation of food-to-go, serve-over and self-serve counters and our
brand and reputation could be damaged to the extent the quality of these facilities fall below our
established standards. For example, if particular temperatures and environments are not properly
maintained, food safety could be compromised and harmful bacteria, such as Escherichia coli or Listeria
monocytogenes could develop. Additionally, these facilities are also subject to public tampering and
contamination, over which we have limited control.

A significant lawsuit, widespread product recall or other events leading to the loss of customer
confidence in the safety and quality of our products could damage our brand and reputation and negatively
impact our sales, profitability and prospects for growth. Further, if a product recall is required in
circumstances where the financial consequences are not covered by the relevant supplier or our
insurance, it may have a material adverse effect on our financial performance. Although we maintain
product liability insurance, we cannot be certain that our coverage will be adequate for liabilities actually
incurred or that insurance will continue to be available to us on economically reasonable terms, or at all.
Even if future product liability claims against us are unsuccessful, these claims could be costly and timeconsuming and may divert our management's time and resources from operating our business and may
harm our brand and reputation.

Even if our products are not affected by contamination or other incidents that compromise their safety
and quality, we are subject to risks affecting the food industry generally, including risks posed by
widespread contamination, widespread diseases (such as H1N1, SARS, MERS, BSE and avian influenza)
and evolving nutritional and health-related concerns. Regulatory authorities may limit the supply of certain
types of food products in response to public health concerns, and customers may perceive certain products
to be unsafe or unhealthy, which could require us or our suppliers to find alternative ingredients or products
that may not be available at commercially reasonable prices or within acceptable time constraints. In
addition, such governmental regulations may require us to identify replacement products for our customers
or, alternatively, to discontinue certain offerings or limit the range of product offerings. We may be unable

to find substitutes that are as appealing to our customers, or such substitutes may not be widely available
or may be available only at increased costs. Such substitutions or limitations could also reduce demand
for our products. Each of the factors above may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition and results of operations. See also "—Any events that negatively impact the reputation of, or
_value associated with, our brands could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and_
_prospects."_

**_Our business is dependent on the economic situation in the United Kingdom and we are exposed_**
**_to local, regional, national and global economic, political, social and other trends that could_**
**_materially adversely impact our operations and financial performance._**

General economic conditions in the United Kingdom and globally may adversely affect our financial
performance. Higher interest rates, fluctuating petroleum product prices (including crude oil, natural gas,
gasoline, and diesel fuel), higher costs for electricity and other energy, weakness in the housing market,
inflation, deflation, increased costs of essential services, higher levels of unemployment, decreases in
disposable income, reduced access to customer credit, higher customer debt levels, changes in customer
spending and shopping patterns, fluctuations in currency exchange rates, higher tax rates, imposition of
new taxes or other changes in tax laws, state-implemented austerity measures, other regulatory changes,
the imposition of tariffs or other measures that create barriers to or increase the costs associated with
international trade, overall economic slowdown or recession and other UK or global economic factors could
materially adversely affect customer demand for the products we sell, cause us to change the mix of
products we sell to one with a lower average gross margin, cause a slowdown in discretionary purchases
of goods, adversely affect our revenue and result in slower inventory turnover and greater markdowns of
inventory, or otherwise materially adversely affect our operations and results of operations and could result
in impairment charges to intangible assets, goodwill or other long-lived assets.

**_Sales of our products are subject to changing customer preferences and trends and we may be_**

The success of our business depends on the continued appeal of the range of products and services

customers. Given the varied backgrounds and tastes of our customer base, we must offer a sufficient
range of products to satisfy a broad spectrum of preferences.

Demand for our food products is affected by customer tastes and preferences, which are impacted by,
among other things, social trends, health concerns, ethical considerations and culinary trends. Customers
are increasingly focusing on health and wellness, including avoiding foods with certain ingredients such
as trans fats, gluten, sugar, sodium, processed wheat, animal products or other product attributes and
preferring foods which fit in to their image of a healthy lifestyle. Customers have also shown increasing
preference for vegan and organic products, ethically sourced products, environmentally-friendly product
packaging and products that support local business. We must adapt and develop products to address
these trends and preferences in a timely manner in order to remain competitive. Further, our customers
increasingly expect a seamless omni-channel experience and when making a decision to purchase
products from us, want to be able to have access to greater amounts of information than ever before,
including on traceability, environmental sustainability and nutritional value. Likewise, our clothing, home
product lines and general merchandise offer are subject to changing customer tastes in apparel and decor
and are also impacted by sustainability considerations. Customers also increasingly expect to be able to
interact with us in a variety of ways, such as through mobile application purchases, which require
investments in technology and human resources.

If we do not identify or effectively respond to customer trends and preferences in a timely manner, or if
we fail to meet our customers' expectations, it could negatively affect our relationship with our customers,
demand for our products and services, our market share and the growth of our business, which could in
turn have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. It is
difficult to quickly, consistently and successfully predict the products and services our customers will be
interested in and respond to changes in their shopping patterns. Responding to shifts in customer
preferences and expectations also can entail significant costs.

The success of our business depends on how accurately and quickly we predict customer demand,
availability of merchandise, the related impact on the demand for existing products and the competitive
environment. Price transparency, assortment of products, customer experience, convenience and the
speed, ease and cost of delivery or collection options are of primary and increasing importance to
customers, particularly as a result of the growth of digital tools and social media that inform customers.

up excess inventory for those products, which could result in a decrease in their sales price and inefficient
working capital management which, if material, could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations.

The retail business continues to rapidly evolve and consumers increasingly embrace online shopping.

and mobile application-based solutions. Our ability to adapt our online offer and, in particular, to develop
online sales depends on a number of factors, including our ability to successfully market our websites and

the capability of our existing distribution network to accommodate our growing online operations and the
ability to integrate our growing online operations on a profitable basis. Additionally, we cannot assure you

the expected increased proportion of online operations could negatively impact our future profitability. In
addition, integrating innovative omni-channel options into the retail store experience is critical for us to

technology solutions that allow us to integrate innovative online shopping processes into our operations.
We may not be able to secure the requisite technology to implement our strategy, either due to cost or
intellectual property rights of third parties. We may also fail to integrate new digital tools into our systems
which could reduce their effectiveness.

Our strategy, which includes investments in online channels, technology, store remodels and other
customer-focused initiatives, may not adequately or effectively allow us to grow our business, maintain or

including increasing online grocery sales, could result in a reduction in the amount of traffic in our stores,

**_Competitive pressures in the apparel, footwear and homeware retail industries are high._**

The apparel, footwear and homeware retail industries are each highly competitive and the marketplace
is highly fragmented as many different retailers compete for market share by utilising a variety of store and
on-line formats and merchandising strategies. The George Clothing and George Home brands compete
on the basis of, among other things, the location of our stores; website, mobile applications and their
respective design; the breadth, quality, style price and availability of our merchandise; and the level of
customer service offered. In particular, the George Clothing brand faces competition from other low-cost
and fast fashion retailers that have recently made significant price investments in their merchandise
offerings and target some of the same categories of customers as the George Clothing brand. We expect
competition to increase in the future. There are no significant economic barriers for others to enter our
apparel, footwear and homeware retail sectors and our existing competitors are constantly adjusting their
pricing, business strategies and promotional activity (particularly during holiday periods) in response to
changing market conditions or their own financial condition. As a result of such competition, the George
Clothing business has experienced declining revenue over recent years.

Additionally, the substantial sales growth in online apparel, footwear and homeware retail within the
last decade has encouraged the entry of many new competitors, new business models and an increase in
competition from established companies looking for ways to create successful online shopping
alternatives. The internet and other technologies also facilitates comparison shopping in our apparel,
footwear and homeware retail segments. Our digital channel competes against numerous websites,
mobile applications and catalogues, which may have a greater volume of circulation and web traffic or
more effective marketing through online media and social networking sites. We offer an omni-channel
shopping experience for our customers and use social media and mobile applications as a way to interact
with them to enhance their shopping experiences. Omni-channel retailing is constantly evolving and we
must keep pace with changing customer expectations and new developments by our competitors. There

personal or confidential information is unlawfully obtained and misused, any of which events could have a
material adverse impact on our business and results of operations and impede the execution of our
strategy or the growth of our business.

The UK online grocery industry is still developing and rapidly evolving. Our online grocery operations
must, therefore, be considered in light of the risks and difficulties we encounter operating in an industry
that is still evolving. These risks and difficulties include:

  - managing rapid growth in personnel and operations;

  - developing sufficient management and technology capability in a rapidly evolving industry;

  - managing and further developing a complex business system;

  - capital expenditures associated with the development of our online operations and support
functions;

  - risks surrounding online payments;

  - further development to our infrastructure and technology solutions;

  - maintaining our profit margins if consumer preferences shift overall to prefer online sales over
brick-and-mortar store sales; and

  - accurately predicting future capacity requirements and ability to maintain or grow market share.

remains largely unsettled, even in areas where there has been some legislative action. In addition, the
