**_We cannot assure you that the projections or assumptions used, estimates made or procedures_**
**_followed in the third-party brokers' opinions of pricing of our portfolio of real estate assets are_**
**_correct, accurate or complete._**

This Offering Memorandum refers to the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing with respect to the real estate
portfolio owned by ASDA. Opinions of pricing of property (including those used in the Brokers' Opinions of
Pricing) are prepared on the basis of various assumptions, estimates and projections. In particular, the
Brokers' Opinions of Pricing were produced without visual inspection of ASDA's properties and are thus
based on information provided by management and certain assumptions, including, but not limited to, the
assumptions that (i) in the case of Newsteer, the properties are let to ASL and in the case of Colliers, the
properties are let to ASDA or to a AAA-tenant, which could include ASDA, and in both cases that ASDA
is in the market for all the properties and benefits from an excellent rating, such as AAA and a very low
risk of failure, (ii) all properties are freehold or long leasehold and all title, tenure, lettings, planning,
taxation, statutory and local authority requirements are complied with and all properties possess a good
and marketable title free from any onerous restrictions or conditions, (iii) all properties benefit from full
access and egress rights together with parking and loading facilities and are connected to all main
services, (iv) all properties are free from defect, in good repair and condition and well maintained and in
marketable condition, compliant with all building, accessibility and fire safety regulations and there are no
abnormalities as to repair and condition of the properties, (v) the properties have no environmental issues
such as contamination, deleterious materials, flooding, ground conditions, invasive or protected plants or
species and the properties are not adversely affected by any existed or proposed environmental law, and
(vi) the floor areas provided to Newsteer and Colliers by ASDA comply with the RICS Standards for
measurement (other than those properties which were measured by Colliers as part of separate instruction
and upon which Colliers have relied for the purposes of their opinion on pricing) and (vii) no capital
expenditure is required in respect of the properties. Both Colliers and Newsteer have assumed that each
property is a vacant shell unit which benefits from fully capped off services and no tenant fit-outs or fixtures
and fittings beyond a typical specification with which a vacant shell unit would be let or sold have been
taken into account in the respective broker's opinion of pricing. In addition, during the course of their
engagement, Newsteer and Colliers did not perform site inspections, environmental audit, tests of services
and amenities, investigations or tests as to the condition of the properties. Newsteer and Colliers did not
make planning or permitting inquiries and did not examine deeds, leases or other documents relating to
the title to our properties. The real estate advisers both assumed each property to be used to its respective
authorised use under planning legislation and in accordance with the use registered with the relevant
regulatory agency.

We cannot assure you that the assumptions or projections used, estimates made or procedures
followed in the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing are correct, accurate or complete. Newsteer and Colliers
provided their opinions of pricing on the relevant properties as of October 20, 2020 and do not take into
account subsequent events, including the uncertain impacts of COVID-19 after such date. Accordingly,
the information included in the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing may not reflect the current physical, economic,
competitive, market or other conditions with respect to the property portfolio. Furthermore, the Brokers'
Opinions of Pricing are addressed to the Issuers only and Newsteer and Colliers have accepted no
responsibility to any third party for the whole or any part of the contents of the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing.

Other appraisers may reach different opinions on pricing of ASDA's property portfolio. Moreover, the
pricing determined in the Brokers' Opinions of Pricing could be significantly higher than the amount that
would be obtained from the actual sale of the properties included in the ASDA Property Portfolio, especially
in a distressed or liquidation scenario, in the event of a downturn in the local, regional or national real
estate market, or if the properties are sold on an individual basis. Accordingly, the Brokers' Opinions of
Pricing should not be considered a representation of the actual present or future pricing of ASDA's property
portfolio. The realisable pricing of the applicable property portfolio at any given time will depend on various
factors, including:

    - macroeconomic conditions in the United Kingdom, the European Union and elsewhere;

    - an economic downturn, including as a result of COVID-19;

    - potential changes to the competitive landscape for grocery retail;

    - capital expenditure requirements;

    - supply and demand generally affecting pricing;

    - adaptability or obsolescence;

    - regulation (e.g. minimum energy efficiency standards);

    - changes in consumer behaviour and shopping habits, either organic or as a result of any other
event listed above or elsewhere under "Risk Factors;" and

    - other factors discussed or referred to in this Offering Memorandum.

In addition, we anticipate that the price of ASDA's property portfolio will change over time, and it may

Our internal controls over financial reporting are intended to ensure we maintain accurate records,
promote the accurate and timely reporting of our financial information, maintain adequate control over our
assets, and detect unauthorised acquisition, use or disposition of our assets. Effective internal and
disclosure controls are necessary for us to provide reliable financial reports and to operate successfully
as a business. Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal
controls.

Any system of controls, however well designed and operated, can provide only reasonable, and not
absolute, assurance that the objectives of the system are met. In addition, the design of any control system
is based in part upon certain assumptions about the likelihood of future events. Because of these and
other inherent limitations of control systems, there can be no assurance that any design will succeed in
achieving its stated goals under all potential future conditions, regardless of how remote. If our internal
controls do not keep pace with the size and sophistication of our businesses and the applicable financial
reporting framework, we may not be able to implement and maintain adequate internal controls. If we fail
to implement and maintain effective internal controls, it could result in material misstatements in our
financial statements or failure to meet our reporting obligations in a timely manner, which may cause a
loss of confidence in our reported financial information which could increase our operating costs and
materially impair our ability to operate our business.

**_Our long-lived assets, primarily goodwill and store-level assets, may not be fully realisable and are_**
**_subject to periodic testing for impairment, and we may incur significant impairment charges as a_**
**_result._**

Our long-lived assets, primarily goodwill and store-level assets, are subject to periodic testing for
impairment. We have recorded a significant amount of goodwill. Total goodwill, which represents the
difference between the consideration paid plus any non-controlling interest and the acquisition date fair
value of identifiable net assets, was £508.0 million as of September 30, 2020, or 2.8% of our consolidated
total assets on a post-IFRS 16 basis. This represents the current carrying value of goodwill in ASDA Group
Limited prior to any purchase accounting relating to the Acquisition and does not necessarily reflect the
goodwill which will be recorded following the Completion when purchase price accounting will have been
completed in accordance with IFRS 3 (Business Combinations). The value of any goodwill recorded on
our financial statements may not be fully realisable upon sale of all or part of the business or any other
liquidity event.

Goodwill is recorded on the date of acquisition and, in accordance with IFRS, is tested for impairment
annually and whenever there is any indication of impairment. Impairment may result from, among other
things, deterioration in our performance, a decline in expected future cash flows, adverse market
conditions, adverse changes in applicable laws and regulations, any changes in the key assumptions used
for internal calculations of values in use and a variety of other factors. The amount of any impairment must
be expensed immediately as a charge to our income statement. We can give no assurance that we will
not record any goodwill impairments in the future. Any future impairment of goodwill may result in material
reductions of our income and equity under IFRS.

**Risks Relating to the Transactions**

**_The Acquisition is subject to certain uncertainties and risks, which could adversely impact_**
**_recoveries under the Notes._**

The Acquisition was referred by the European Commission to the CMA on December 8, 2020. While
consummation of the Acquisition is expected to take place on or about February 16, 2021, the CMA's
phase 1 review of the Acquisition remains ongoing. There can be no assurance that the Acquisition will be
approved within the expected timeframe, approved at all, or approved subject to conditions.

If in the course of its phase 1 investigation, the CMA considers that the Acquisition may be expected
to result in a substantial lessening of competition within any market or markets for goods or services in the
United Kingdom, the CMA may refer the Acquisition for an in-depth phase 2 investigation. It is common
practice in such circumstances to propose remedies to address any concerns identified by the CMA, in
lieu of proceeding with a full phase 2 inquiry. Such remedies may include an undertaking to sell certain
Forecourt Assets, to unaffiliated third parties. In the event we propose remedies to the CMA following their
phase 1 investigation, there can be no assurance that our proposal will be accepted. The CMA may reject
our proposal, require additional divestments or impose terms or other conditions that we may be unable
or unwilling to accept. If we are unable to reach an agreement with the CMA concerning remedies in lieu
of a referral to a phase 2 investigation and the Acquisition is so referred, the CMA Clearance Date could
be significantly delayed.

If we agree to remedies that require divestment of certain Forecourt Assets to unaffiliated third parties,
the price we receive from such a mandated sale may be less than what we would have received in a fully
voluntary sale process. There can be no guarantee that market conditions would be favourable in the
period provided for such sales or that the price we would obtain from buyers in a mandated sale would be
equal to the price that would otherwise be offered as part of a customary sales process. If we agree to
remedies that require divestments but are unable to complete these transactions on acceptable terms in
the time permitted, we would be in breach of our agreement with the CMA, which could result in loss in
control over the divestment process or other consequences that could have a material adverse effect on
our business.

If the CMA believes the Acquisition may implicate a material public interest consideration, it is required
to bring the matter to the attention of the UK Secretary of State. Under certain circumstances, the UK
Secretary of State may issue a Public Interest Intervention Notice ("PIIN"), which would allow the UK

### 108


-----

Secretary of State to assume responsibility for review of the Acquisition. If a PIIN is issued in connection
with the Acquisition, the CMA Clearance Date could be delayed.

In the event the CMA refers the Acquisition to a phase 2 investigation, it has broad authority to impose
remedies to address their concerns. In the event the CMA considers that remedies would not address their
concerns, the CMA may decide not to approve the Acquisition. If this were to occur, the entire ASDA Group
would have to be divested to unaffiliated third parties. The price we receive from such a mandated sale
may be less than what we would have received in a fully voluntary sale process. There can be no
guarantee as to the consideration we would obtain from buyers in a mandated sale and, in such an event,
there may be insufficient funds for the Notes to be repaid.

In connection with the CMA's review of the Acquisition, we expect the CMA to issue an IEO shortly
before or immediately after Completion, and we expect the IEO to remain in force until the CMA Clearance
Date. Under the IEO, the ASDA Group business will have to be operated independently so as not to take
any action that could potentially impede the CMA's review and remediation of Acquisition-related
competition concerns. In addition, the IEO will prevent any integration activities, substantive changes to
the organisational structure of the ASDA Group, dispositions of ASDA Group assets and exchanges of
commercially sensitive information between the ASDA Group and the Bellis Group unless we seek and
obtain a derogation from the CMA. As a result of the IEO, the Bellis Group will not be able to exercise de
_facto control over the ASDA Group during the pendency of the CMA investigation. Accordingly, the Issuers_
will not be able direct the ASDA Group to comply with the covenants described in "Description of the Senior
_Secured Notes" and "Description of the Senior Notes" until the CMA Clearance Date, and the ASDA Group_
will have no contractual obligation to comply with those covenants until each of the ASDA Guarantors
accedes to the relevant Indenture. Nevertheless, those covenants will apply to the ASDA Group from the
Issue Date, and any failure to comply with these covenants will constitute a default under the Indentures.
Furthermore, subject to any derogations granted, the IEO's restrictions on the ability to exchange
information with the ASDA Group may limit the support that the Bellis Group may be able to provide to the
ASDA Group and affect our ability to grant and creditors' ability to enforce guarantees and security
interests for so long as the IEO is in force. As a result, there may be a delay in our ability to realise
anticipated synergies. If we fail to abide by the terms of the IEO, the CMA may impose financial penalties
of up to 5% of our total turnover. The CMA may appoint a monitoring trustee to monitor compliance with
the IEO and, if it were ultimately to consider it to be necessary, the CMA may appoint a hold separate
manager to operate the ASDA Group on an arm's-length basis until the CMA Clearance Date.

Furthermore, if the conditions to the release of the Escrowed Proceeds, as more fully described under
"Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Acquisition Agreement; Timing of Completion and Issue Date;
_Escrow of Proceeds" and "Description of the Senior Notes—Acquisition Agreement; Timing of Completion_
_and Issue Date; Escrow of Proceeds" have not been satisfied on or prior to the Outside Date or in certain_
other circumstances (including at the discretion of Midco, a holding company of the Issuers, subject to
certain conditions), the Notes will be subject to a Special Mandatory Redemption and you may not obtain
the return you expect to receive on the Notes. See "—If the conditions precedent to the release of the

**_There are risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart._**

The Separation is a complex transaction that will require significant management attention and poses
a number of risks, including:

    - a failure to establish or maintain our own information systems;

    - a failure to establish and negotiate new wholesale energy supply agreements;

    - a failure to establish or negotiate new deep sea freight agreements;

    - our inability to renegotiate key contracts previously held at the Walmart level;

    - our inability to renegotiate key insurance policies previously held at the Walmart level;

    - our inability to retain key personnel of ASDA;

    - the incurrence of unexpected expenses and working capital requirements;

    - our inability to achieve our financial and strategic goals, including synergies for the combined
businesses; and

    - difficulty in maintaining internal controls, procedures and policies.

Any of the foregoing obstacles, or a combination of them, could decrease operating profit margins or
increase operating costs in absolute terms and/or as a percentage of revenue, which could in turn
negatively impact our profit for future periods and cash flows.

Following the Acquisition, Walmart will continue to provide a reduced selection of services to ASDA,
including services such as IT and access to innovation and know-how under the TSA and the ASA, for a
transitional period (envisaged to be up to three years from the Acquisition Completion Date in respect of
services under the TSA (although the TSA is expected to allow for services to be provided past this date
subject to an increase in costs under a cost ratchet), and for a period of two years from the Acquisition
Completion Date, in respect of the services under the ASA). ASDA expects that it will be dependent on
these services provided by Walmart, for the duration of the agreements pursuant to which they will be
provided. For more information see "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional
_Agreements with Walmart." At Completion, Walmart will grant ASDA a licence pursuant to the TMA to use_
the George brand within the United Kingdom (for sale, marketing and distribution purposes on an exclusive
basis) and outside the United Kingdom in certain European countries where ASDA has used the George
brand prior to the date of the Acquisition Agreement (on a non-exclusive basis) (and is expected to grant
ASDA a licence to use the George brand in certain other territories outside the United Kingdom and such
specified European countries (on a non-exclusive basis) in substantially the same way and to the same
extent as the brand was used by ASDA immediately prior to the date of the Acquisition Agreement, as
specified in, and subject to the terms of, the TMA), in each case on and subject to the terms of the TMA
(see "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions – Trade Mark Agreement"), while Walmart
will continue to own the brand and retain the ability to use it in all other territories. See "Business—Our
_Intellectual Property."_

We will have ongoing service relationships and agreements with Walmart pursuant to which Walmart
has provided certain services to ASDA in the past. These services include sourcing of clothing and general
merchandise. It is possible that such ongoing service relationships and agreements will be insufficient to
cover our needs as a stand-alone company or that the agreements pursuant to which they are provided
may contain terms and conditions that are not favourable to ASDA or not competitive with alternatives in
the market. In addition, failure by Walmart to perform the services provided for under the service
arrangements and agreements to an acceptable service level or at all may result in operational problems
and increased costs to ASDA. The services to be provided by Walmart after the Acquisition may not
function as efficiently as they did prior to the Acquisition and, in the event any of our service relationships
and agreements with Walmart are terminated, ASDA may find it difficult to find a suitable alternative
supplier of such services in a timely fashion or at all. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

As a result of the commercial deleveraging resulting from the Separation, we may not have the same
ability to negotiate with third-parties and achieve the same or similar terms as under existing agreements
through Walmart. We may have substantially higher costs if we fail to negotiate new agreements on similar
terms or at all.

### 110


-----

In addition, the Acquisition will constitute a change of control under certain agreements entered into by
ASDA and its subsidiaries. Those counterparties will be entitled to terminate their agreements with us.
Some of these counterparties may exercise their termination rights, which could have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial position and results of operations.

The benefits of the operational improvements that we plan to make following the Acquisition may be
undermined by certain other risks we face in our day-to-day operations, including, among other things, the
loss of key contracts, customers and suppliers and strikes and other industrial actions by our colleagues,
which could result in disruptions to our operations and increased costs. Operational efficiency measures
generally require a significant amount of management attention and resources, which may disrupt or
otherwise have a material adverse effect on our ongoing business operations. These factors may offset
any cost savings we anticipate and which we have included in our _Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA._
Consequently, our inability to realise any anticipated cost savings could have a material adverse effect on
our business, financial condition and results of operation.

**_The ASDA Group will need to transition to being a standalone company and there are risks_**
**_associated with such a transition._**

The ASDA Group has historically been part of the operations of Walmart, which provided them with
operational, financial, and other support. As a result of the Acquisition, we became a standalone company
and, accordingly, we must develop and implement the systems and infrastructure necessary to support
our current and future business. We cannot assure you that we will make the transition successfully. For
example, historically, certain of our accounting and information technology systems were incorporated in
Walmart's larger operations. There can be no assurance that there will not be errors, delays, or other
related issues resulting from the transition to a standalone company and adjustments to associated
business processes or that we will be able to fix any error or issue. Any such errors or issues could have
a material and adverse impact on our business, financial condition, and results of operations. Any delays
in implementing required systems may lead to increased operating expenses.

On the Acquisition Completion Date, ASL and Walmart are expected to enter into the TSA, under
which Walmart is expected to provide certain information technology services to ASDA on a transitional
basis (the "Transitional Services"). The Transitional Services, which Walmart is expected to agree to
provide to support and facilitate our ability to operate on a standalone basis, cover all information
technology services and telecommunication services that were provided to ASDA in the 12 months prior
to the Acquisition Completion Date. Under the TSA, each relevant Transitional Service is expected to be
supplied by Walmart until the earlier of (i) the migration of the relevant service as part of the separation of
ASDA from Walmart, and (ii) the termination of the TSA by Walmart or ASL under certain circumstances
as described under "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements with
_Walmart—Transitional Services Agreement." (provided that where ASDA requires any Transitional_
Services to be provided after a three-year long stop date set out in the TSA, the charges for such remaining
Transitional Services under the TSA will be subject to increase pursuant to a cost ratchet). If Walmart
terminates the TSA in accordance with its terms or is unable or unwilling to provide the Transitional
Services as agreed, we may not be able to replace these services at an acceptable price and in a timely
manner, or at all. The Transitional Services include certain IT services which are provided pursuant to
third-party vendor contracts. These services will require the vendor consent to extend the term of the
underlying agreement past the Acquisition Completion Date, and thereafter will have to be renegotiated
with the IT vendor. We may not be able to successfully transition these systems to our standalone
operations in a timely manner, or at all, or may have underestimated the costs required to do so. Any
delays in implementing required functionalities and systems may lead to increased operating expenses.

We will also incur costs in the future that have historically been part of Walmart's larger cost structure,
including costs associated with health and welfare benefits for our colleagues, as well as internal legal,
tax, regulatory and treasury services. In particular, we will need to bear the cost of hiring additional
colleagues to fill any gaps left by the withdrawal of Walmart services. We will incur costs searching for and

**_The ASDA Group may have liabilities that are not known to us._**

Before making investments, the Shareholders conduct due diligence that they deem reasonable and
appropriate based on the facts and circumstances applicable to each investment. The objective of the due
diligence process is to identify attractive investment opportunities, to identify possible risks associated with
that investment, including actual or potential liabilities, and to prepare a framework that may be used from
the date of an acquisition to drive operational achievement and value creation. In conducting due diligence
in connection with the Acquisition, the Shareholders also relied on resources available to them, including

### 114


-----

public information, information provided by the ASDA Group and its former owners and information
provided by third-party advisers, including in the preparation of this Offering Memorandum. When
conducting due diligence, the Shareholders typically evaluate a number of important business, financial,
tax, accounting, environmental and legal issues in determining whether or not to proceed with an
investment. Outside consultants, legal advisors, accountants and investment banks are involved in the
due diligence process in varying degrees depending on the type of investment. Nevertheless, when
conducting due diligence and making an assessment regarding an investment, the Shareholders must rely
on resources available to them, including information provided by the target of the investment and, in some
circumstances, third-party investigations.

The ASDA Group may have liabilities that the Shareholders failed or were unable to discover in the
course of performing due diligence investigations in connection with the Acquisition. Following the
Acquisition, we may learn of additional information about the ASDA Group that adversely affects us, such
as unknown or contingent liabilities and issues relating to compliance with applicable laws and regulations.
Any such liabilities, individually or in the aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on the business
of the ASDA Group, or on the financial condition and results of operations of the ASDA Group and our
ability to fulfil our obligations under the Notes.

There can be no assurance that the due diligence undertaken in connection with the Acquisition has
revealed or highlighted all relevant facts necessary or helpful in evaluating the Transactions. Furthermore,
there can be no assurance as to the adequacy or accuracy of information provided during the due diligence
exercise or that such information will be accurate or remain accurate in the period from the conclusion of
the due diligence exercise until Completion. The due diligence process is inherently subjective. If the due
diligence investigation failed to identify or appreciate material information regarding the Acquisition, we
may later be forced to write down or write off certain assets, significantly modify the business plan for the
ASDA Group or incur impairment or other charges. Similarly, the materialisation of certain risks, which
may or may not be identified during due diligence, may lead to a loss of property, loss of value and,
potentially, subsequent contractual and statutory liability to various parties.

In connection with the Acquisition, ASDA Holdings UK Limited (the "Seller"), has given certain
customary warranties and undertaken certain customary indemnification obligations in the Acquisition

Purchaser may not be able to enforce any claims against the Seller relating to breaches of these warranties

Purchaser, and therefore indirectly we, may temporarily be required to bear these losses ourselves.

**_We are susceptible to claims of anti-competitive practices._**

Part of our overall strategy is to be a leader in our business sectors. We may be accused of anticompetitive practices based on our conduct and taking into account our market position. This risk may
increase after the Acquisition as the Shareholders also control other entities involved in the retail industry
in the United Kingdom. Any such claims could materially adversely affect our reputation, potentially result
in legal proceedings that could have an impact on our business, financial condition and results of
operations and require us to divest assets. Such claims could also impair our ability to conduct acquisitions
accretive to our business. Before certain potential future acquisitions can be consummated, we may be
required to seek approvals and consents from regulatory agencies or there may be applicable waiting
periods that will need to expire. We may be unable to obtain such regulatory approvals or consents, or, in
order to obtain them, we may be required to dispose of assets or take other actions that could have the
effect of reducing our return on potential future acquisitions. Even if regulatory authorities do not require
disposals or other actions, the regulatory approval process may have the effect of delaying our ability to
implement potential future acquisitions.

**_We may be unable to achieve some or all of the operational cost improvements and other benefits_**

We believe that, after giving effect to the Transactions, we will be able to, among other matters, better
focus our financial and operational resources on our business, growth profile and strategic priorities,

priorities, streamline our processes and infrastructure to focus on core strengths, implement and maintain

Our anticipated cost saving and operational run-rate synergies are based upon assumptions about

**_Any change resulting from our operations as a standalone company, whether real or perceived_**

**_The Group's corporate structure has undergone, and will undergo, organisational changes in the_**
**_context of the Transactions, including the Separation and the Post-Completion Transactions,_**
**_making it challenging to transparently assess past and future performance and legal risks of the_**
**_ASDA Group._**

The Group's corporate structure has undergone, and will undergo, substantial organisational changes
in the context of the Transactions, including the Separation and the Post-Completion Transactions. As a
consequence, past events that are described in the Offering Memorandum as having occurred with respect
to the ASDA Group reflect events that occurred before the Company existed as a stand-alone business,
and may not be indicative of events that will occur following the Transactions, when the Company operates
a stand-alone business. It is therefore difficult to assess the applicability or magnitude of risks disclosed
in the Offering Memorandum given that such risks are based on the performance of the ASDA Group when
it was operating as part of Walmart rather than as part of a separate, stand-alone legal or reporting entity.
Similarly, it is difficult to predict our future performance following the Transactions, given that the historical
financial information for the Company as presented in this Offering Memorandum reflects periods that
have occurred prior to the Separation.

The measures and share transfers implemented to reorganise the ASDA Group may also have tax
effects on the Company and its subsidiaries. Given the substantial value of the Company and the
complexity of the measures taken, taxes relating to those measures could have an adverse effect on our
business, financial position and results of operations.

**_We have incurred, and expect to continue to incur, significant transaction costs in connection with_**
**_the Transactions._**

In connection with the Transactions, we have incurred and expect to continue to incur and bear
significant, costs and expenses, including taxes, financial advisory, legal, accounting, consulting and other
advisory fees and expenses, reorganisation and restructuring costs, severance and employee benefitrelated expenses, printing expenses and other related charges. In addition, we may incur significant onetime charges as a result of costs associated with the Transactions. We will not be able to quantify the
exact amount of these charges or the period in which they will be incurred until after the Transactions are
completed. Some of the factors affecting the costs associated with the Transactions include the timing of
the completion of the Transactions, the resources required to transition the business to a standalone
company and the length of time during which transitional services are provided by Walmart. There are
also a large number of processes, policies, procedures, operations, technologies and systems that must
be developed in connection with the Transactions. While we have assumed that a certain level of expenses
will be incurred in connection with the Transactions, there are many factors that could affect the total
amount or timing of the integration and implementation expenses. There may also be additional
unanticipated significant costs in connection with the Transactions that we do not anticipate and may not
be able to recoup. These costs and expenses could reduce the benefits and income we expect to achieve
from the Transactions.

**Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure, Our Financing and Our Indebtedness**

**_Our leverage and debt service obligations could materially adversely affect our business, financial_**
**_condition, liquidity, results of operation or prospects._**

As of September 30, 2020, after giving effect to the Transactions, we would have had total third-party
debt of £4,721.0 million (equivalent). See "Capitalisation." From the Issue Date, we will be highly leveraged
and we anticipate that leverage will be sustained at this level or higher for the foreseeable future. The level
of indebtedness that we will hold from the Issue Date could, among other things:

     - limit our ability to obtain additional financing to fund future working capital, capital
expenditures, business opportunities and other corporate requirements;

     - reduce our flexibility to respond to, and pose additional risks for us in the face of, general
adverse economic and industry conditions;

     - reduce the portion of our cash flow from operations that will be available for uses other than
servicing our debt, such as funding working capital, capital expenditures, acquisitions, joint
ventures or other general corporate purposes;

     - restrict us from pursuing strategic acquisitions or exploiting certain business opportunities;

     - limit our flexibility in planning for, or reacting to, changes in our business and the competitive
environment and the industry in which we operate;

     - place us at a disadvantage compared to our competitors that are not as highly leveraged;

### 117


-----

     - negatively impact credit terms with our creditors; and

     - limit our ability to borrow additional funds and increasing the cost of any such borrowing.

Any of these, or other, consequences or events could have a material adverse effect on our ability to
satisfy our debt obligations, including our obligations under the Notes.

**_We may incur additional debt in the future, which may make it difficult for us to service our debt,_**
**_including the Notes, and impact our ability to operate our businesses._**

The agreements governing our debt limit our ability to incur additional indebtedness, but do not prohibit
us from doing so. The terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility
(or, in the case of the Indentures, will) permit us to incur additional debt, including in respect of committed
borrowings of up to £690.0 million under the Revolving Credit Facilities. Some of this debt could rank pari
_passu with the Notes, be structurally senior to the Notes or be secured on assets which do not form part_
of the Collateral for the Senior Secured Notes or part of the Senior Notes Collateral for the Senior Notes.
Additional debt could also mature prior to the Notes. In addition, under the terms of the Indentures and the
Intercreditor Agreement, we are permitted, subject to certain conditions (including the refinancing of the
Term Loan Facilities in full), to incur new debt that has super senior priority status over the Notes in respect
of the proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral and certain distressed disposals. If new debt is
added to the Group's existing debt levels, the related risks that we currently face would increase.
Furthermore, if we are able to designate some of our Restricted Subsidiaries under the Indentures as
Unrestricted Subsidiaries, those Unrestricted Subsidiaries would be permitted to borrow beyond the
limitations specified in the Indentures and engage in other activities in which Restricted Subsidiaries may
not engage. See "Description of the Senior Secured Notes" and "Description of the Senior Notes." In
addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement does not, and the Indentures will not, prevent us from incurring
obligations that do not constitute indebtedness as defined under each of these documents, including shortterm working capital facilities up to the greater of £360.0 million and 30% of our Consolidated EBITDA (as
defined in the respective documents), which are permitted to be secured by security interests in the
Collateral (including on a super senior basis, subject to the refinancing or repayment of the Term Loan
Facilities in full and certain other conditions). If we are ever unable to service our debt, it would likely have
a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects
and our ability to fulfil our obligations under the Notes and the Notes Guarantees.

**_Each of the Issuers is a holding company dependent upon cash flow from subsidiaries to meet its_**
**_obligations on the Notes and the Notes Guarantees._**

Each of the Issuers is a holding company with no independent business operations or significant assets
other than investments in our subsidiaries, and we depend upon the receipt of sufficient funds from our
subsidiaries to meet our obligations. We expect our operating subsidiaries to provide us with funds to meet
our obligations in respect of the Notes through a combination of dividends and payments in respect of
intercompany loans. Our subsidiaries' obligations under intercompany loans will be junior obligations and
will be subordinated in right of payment to all of the Group's existing and future senior and senior
subordinated indebtedness, including obligations under, or guarantees of obligations under, the Senior
Facilities Agreement, the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior
Notes.

If our subsidiaries do not distribute cash sufficient to make scheduled payments on the Notes, we will
not have any other source of funds that will allow us to make payments to the holders of the relevant
Notes. In addition, various agreements governing the Group's debt may restrict and, in some cases may
actually prohibit, the ability of these subsidiaries to move cash within their restricted group. Applicable tax
laws may also subject such payments to further taxation and applicable corporate law may limit the
amounts that some of our subsidiaries will be permitted to pay as dividends or distributions on their equity
interests, or even prohibit such payments. In particular, our subsidiaries' ability to pay dividends to us may
be limited to the amount of distributable reserves available to them. Finally, our subsidiaries that do not
guarantee the Notes have no obligation to make payments with respect to any of the Notes.

The inability to transfer cash among entities within their respective consolidated groups may mean that,
even though the entities, in aggregate, may have sufficient resources to meet their obligations, they may
not be permitted to make the necessary transfers from one entity in their consolidated group to another
entity in their consolidated group in order to make payments to the entity owing the obligations.

**_The Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes will each be structurally subordinated to the_**
**_liabilities and preference shares (if any) of the Group's non-guarantor subsidiaries._**

Generally, claims of creditors of a non-guarantor subsidiary, including trade creditors, and claims of
preference shareholders (if any) of the subsidiary, will have priority with respect to the assets and earnings
of the subsidiary over the claims of creditors of its parent entity, including claims by holders of the Notes
under the Notes Guarantees. In the event of any foreclosure, dissolution, winding-up, liquidation,
reorganisation, administration or other bankruptcy or insolvency proceeding of any of the Group's nonguarantor subsidiaries, holders of their indebtedness and their trade creditors will generally be entitled to
payment of their claims from the assets of those subsidiaries before any assets are made available for
distribution to the parent entities of such non-guarantor subsidiaries. As such, the Senior Secured Notes,
the Senior Notes and each Notes Guarantee will each be structurally subordinated to the creditors
(including trade creditors) and preference shareholders (if any) of the Group's non-guarantor subsidiaries.
In addition, neither the Senior Secured Notes Indenture nor the Senior Notes Indenture will require
subsidiaries that become a member of the Regulated Group to Guarantee the Notes under any
circumstances and any Notes Guarantee will be automatically released upon the relevant Guarantor
becoming a member of the Regulated Group.

As of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, the ASDA Guarantors collectively accounted
for more than 99.9% of the ASDA Group's consolidated revenues and, as of October 20, 2020, the ASDA
Guarantors held title to sites representing 99.9% of the aggregate capital pricing of the ASDA Store and
Office Portfolio, as described in "Brokers' Opinions of Pricing." In addition, our audited consolidated
financial statements include both Guarantor and non-guarantor subsidiaries and, as such, may be of
limited use in assessing the financial position of the Guarantors.

**_Your rights in the Collateral may be adversely affected by the failure to perfect security interests_**
**_in the relevant assets._**

Under certain applicable law, a security interest in certain tangible and intangible assets can only be
properly perfected, and its priority retained, through certain actions undertaken by the secured party and/or
the grantor of the security. The security interests in the Collateral may not be perfected with respect to the
claims of the Senior Secured Notes or the Senior Notes, as applicable, if we, or the Security Agent, fail or
are unable to take the actions required to perfect any of these security interests. The Security Agent has
no obligation to perfect any of these liens or any security interest. In addition, certain applicable law
requires that certain property and rights acquired after the grant of a general security interest, such as real
property, equipment subject to a certificate and certain proceeds, can only be perfected at or promptly
following the time such property and rights are acquired and identified. Absent perfection, the Security
Agent, on behalf of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes or the Senior Notes, as applicable, may have
difficulty enforcing or may be entirely unable to enforce rights in the Senior Secured Notes Collateral (in
the case of the Senior Secured Notes) or the Senior Notes Collateral (in the case of the Senior Notes) in
competition with third parties, including a trustee in bankruptcy and other creditors, including those who
claim a security interest in the same assets. The Trustees and the Security Agent have no obligation to
monitor the acquisition of additional property or rights that constitute collateral or perfection of any security
interest and will not be expected to do so. There can be no assurance that we will inform the Trustees or
the Security Agent of, the future acquisition of property and rights that constitute collateral, and that
necessary action will be taken to properly perfect the security interest in such after-acquired collateral.

**_It may be difficult to realise the value of the Collateral securing the Notes._**

The Collateral will be subject, in each case, to any and all exceptions, defects, encumbrances, liens
and other imperfections permitted under the Indentures and the Intercreditor Agreement and accepted by
other creditors that have the benefit of security interests in the Collateral from time to time, whether on or
after the date the Notes are first issued. The existence of any such exceptions, defects, encumbrances,
liens and other imperfections could adversely affect the value of the Collateral, as well as the ability of the
Security Agent to realise or foreclose on such Collateral. Furthermore, the ranking of security interests can
be affected by a variety of factors, including, among others, the timely satisfaction of perfection
requirements, statutory liens or characterisation under the laws of certain jurisdictions.

Enforcement of the Security Interests by the Security Agent will be subject to practical problems
generally associated with the realisation of security interests in collateral. For example, under English law,
the enforcement of share pledges, whether by means of a sale or an appropriation, is subject to certain
specific requirements. The share pledges will be enforced by the Security Agent. The Intercreditor
Agreement regulates the ability of the Senior Secured Notes Trustee or the holders of the Senior Secured
Notes to instruct the Security Agent to take enforcement action. Initially, the Security Agent will not be
required to take enforcement action unless instructed to do so by an Instructing Group with a sufficient
majority. The Security Agent may also need to obtain the consent of a third party to enforce a security
interest. The Group cannot assure you that the Security Agent will be able to obtain any such consents
when required to facilitate a sale of, or appropriate or otherwise foreclose on, the Collateral. For example,
any change in the direct or indirect control of ASL will require the approval of the FCA. Accordingly, the
Security Agent may not have the ability to sell or foreclose upon Collateral assets the sale of which would
result in any such change of control. In any such case, the value of the Collateral, may significantly
decrease.

**_Holders of the Notes will not control certain decisions regarding the Collateral, and the sale of_**
**_particular assets could reduce the pool of assets securing the Notes._**

The Security Documents will, subject to the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Forecourt

making ordinary course cash payments, including repayments of indebtedness. Any of these activities
could reduce the value of the Collateral and consequently the amounts payable to holders of the Notes
from the proceeds of any sale of the Collateral in the case of an enforcement.

**_Each Notes Guarantee and security interest will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement_**
**_and may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defences that may limit its validity and_**
**_enforceability._**

Each Notes Guarantee will provide the relevant holders of the Notes with a direct claim against the
relevant Guarantor. In addition, the Senior Notes Issuer, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Guarantors
and certain other security providers, in the case of the Senior Secured Notes, and, in the case of the Senior
Notes, the Jersey Security Provider will secure the payment of the Notes by granting security under the
relevant Security Documents. However, each security interest granted under a Security Document will be
limited in scope to the value of the relevant assets expressed to be subject to that security interest, and
each Indenture will provide that each Notes Guarantee will be limited to the maximum amount that can be
guaranteed by the relevant Guarantor, without rendering the relevant Notes Guarantee or security interest
(as applicable) voidable or otherwise ineffective under English or other applicable law, and enforcement
of each Notes Guarantee or Security Document (as applicable) would be subject to certain generally
available defences. These laws and defences include those that relate to corporate benefit, fraudulent
conveyance or transfer, voidable preference, financial assistance, corporate purpose, capital maintenance
or similar laws, regulations or defences affecting the rights of creditors generally. See "Certain Insolvency
_Considerations and_ _Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and Security_
_Interests."_

Although laws differ among various jurisdictions, in general, under fraudulent conveyance and other
laws, guarantees and security interests can be challenged (by the bankruptcy receiver or trustee, in case
of bankruptcy of the relevant Guarantor, or by any of the creditors of such Guarantor outside bankruptcy),
and a court could declare unenforceable against third parties (including the beneficiaries thereof) and/or
void, any legal act performed by a Guarantor (including, without limitation, the granting by it of the Notes
Guarantees or the security interests granted under the Security Documents) and, if payment had already
been made under a Notes Guarantee or enforcement proceeds applied under a Security Document,
require that the recipient (and possibly, subsequent transferees thereof) return the payment to the relevant
Guarantor, if the court found, inter alia, that:

      - the amount paid or payable under the relevant Notes Guarantee or the enforcement
proceeds under the relevant Security Document was in excess of the maximum
amount permitted under applicable law;

**●** the relevant Notes Guarantee or security interest under a Security Document was
incurred with actual intent to hinder, delay or defraud creditors or shareholders of the
Guarantor or, in certain jurisdictions, even when the recipient was simply aware that
the Guarantor was insolvent when it granted the relevant Notes Guarantee or security
interest;

**●** the Guarantor did not receive fair consideration or reasonably equivalent value for
granting the relevant Notes Guarantee/security interests and the Guarantor was: (i)
insolvent or rendered insolvent because of the relevant Notes Guarantee/security
interest; (ii) undercapitalised or became undercapitalised because of the relevant
Notes Guarantee/Security Document; or (iii) intended to incur, or believed that it would
incur, indebtedness beyond its ability to pay at maturity; and/or

**●** the relevant Notes Guarantees/Security Documents were held to exceed the corporate
objects of the Guarantor or not to be in the best interests or for the corporate benefit
of the Guarantor.

**_Currency exchange rates may have an impact on our business, financial condition, liquidity,_**
**_results of operations and prospects._**

We will be subject to foreign currency translation and transaction effects because the Group's business
is based in the United Kingdom and the Group prepares its consolidated financial statements in pounds
sterling; however, following the Issue Date, we will have a significant amount of euro-denominated debt
and may incur further euro-denominated debt in the future. Our results of operations may be affected by
both the transaction effects and the translation effects of foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations. We

### 123


-----

will be required to pay principal and interest payments in a currency outside of our functional currency,
exposing us to unrealised and realised gains and losses due to foreign exchange depending on
fluctuations in exchange rates. In addition, fluctuations in the euro-sterling currency exchange rate could
have a substantial effect on our financial statements due to related gains or losses resulting from the
conversion into sterling of euro-denominated liabilities. Although we may use currency swaps to hedge
against the effect of changes in the euro-sterling rate, there can be no assurance that hedging will be
available on commercially reasonable terms and, even if such arrangements are available, they may not
completely insulate us from currency exchange risks. In addition, hedging itself carries certain risks,
including that we may need to pay a significant amount (including costs) to terminate any hedging
arrangements.

**_Our variable interest rate debt may be impacted by applicable regulation and may bear interest that_**
**_could rise significantly, thereby increasing our costs and reducing our cash flow._**

The debt the Group will incur under the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge
Facility will bear interest at variable rates, and we will be exposed to the risk of fluctuations in interest
rates. In addition, the Indentures will permit us to incur substantial additional indebtedness, which may
bear a floating rate of interest. These interest rates could rise significantly in the future, increasing our
interest expense associated with these obligations, reducing cash flow available to fund working capital,
capital expenditures or other general corporate purposes and hindering our ability to make payments on
the Notes. Although we may enter into and maintain certain hedging arrangements designed to fix a
portion of these rates, there can be no assurance that hedging will be available on commercially
reasonable terms or that it will continue to be available on such terms in the future. Hedging itself carries
certain risks, including that we may need to pay a significant amount (including costs) to terminate any
hedging arrangements.

In addition, following allegations of manipulation of the London Interbank Offered Rate ("LIBOR"), a
measure of interbank lending rates, regulators and law enforcement agencies from a number of
governments and the European Union are conducting investigations into whether the banks that contribute
data in connection with the calculation of the daily Euro Interbank Offered Rate ("EURIBOR") or the
calculation of LIBOR may have been manipulating or attempting to manipulate EURIBOR and LIBOR. In
addition, LIBOR, EURIBOR and other interest rates or other types of rates and indices which are deemed
to be "benchmarks" are the subject of recent and ongoing national and international and other regulatory
reform, including the implementation of the IOSCO Principles for Financial Market Benchmarks (July 2013)
and the new European regulation on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial
contracts or to measure the performance of investment funds, which entered into force on June 30, 2016.
Following the implementation of any such reforms, the manner of administration of benchmarks may
change, with the result that they may perform differently than in the past, or benchmarks could be
eliminated entirely, or there could be other consequences which cannot be predicted. For example, on
July 27, 2017, the UK Financial Conduct Authority announced that it will no longer persuade or compel
banks to submit rates for the calculation of the LIBOR benchmark after 2021 (the "FCA Announcement").
The FCA Announcement and a subsequent speech by the Director of Markets and Wholesale Policy at
the FCA on January 28, 2019 indicates that the continuation of LIBOR on the current basis cannot and will
not be guaranteed, and market participants should not rely on its publication, after 2021. In July 2019, the
Chief Executive Officer of the Financial Conduct Authority commented that the market should prepare for
the end of LIBOR. The potential elimination of the LIBOR benchmark or any other benchmark, changes in
the manner of administration of any benchmark, or actions by regulators or law enforcement agencies
could result in changes to the manner in which EURIBOR or LIBOR is determined, which could require an
adjustment to the terms and conditions, or result in other consequences, in respect of any debt or hedging
linked to such benchmark. If LIBOR or EURIBOR were discontinued or otherwise unavailable, the rate of
interest on our floating rate debt will be determined for the relevant period by the fallback provisions
applicable to such debt. Any such change, as well as manipulative practices or the cessation thereof, may
result in a sudden or prolonged increase in reported EURIBOR or LIBOR, which could have an adverse
impact on the Group's ability to service debt that bears interest at floating rates of interest.

of purchase. A change of control may also result in an event of default under, acceleration of, or an

**_In certain circumstances, a Change of Control Offer will not be required to be made._**

The change of control provisions contained in the Indentures may not necessarily afford you protection
in the event of certain important corporate events, including a reorganisation, restructuring, merger or
other similar transaction involving us that may adversely affect you, because such corporate events may
not involve a shift in voting power or beneficial ownership or, even if they do, may not constitute a "Change

_Secured Notes—Change of Control" and "Description of the Senior Notes—Change of Control," each_
Indenture will not contain provisions that would require the relevant Issuer to offer to repurchase or

The definition of "Change of Control" in each Indenture will include a disposition of all or substantially

Although there is a limited body of case law interpreting the phrase "substantially all," there is no precise
established definition of the phrase under applicable law. Accordingly, in certain circumstances, there
may be a degree of uncertainty as to whether a particular transaction would involve a disposition of
"substantially all" of the assets of the applicable Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries taken as a whole.
As a result, it may be unclear as to whether a change of control has occurred and whether the Issuers

The Group cannot assure you as to:

Future trading prices for the Notes will depend on many factors, including, among other things,

alternative admission to listing on another stock exchange) of the relevant Notes, as applicable, from the

In addition, each Indenture will allow us to issue additional notes in the future which could exacerbate

**_Investors may face foreign exchange risks by investing in the Notes._**

The Notes will be denominated and payable in sterling. If investors in Notes measure their investment
returns by reference to a currency other than sterling, such investment in the Notes will entail foreign
exchange-related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes in the values of the
sterling relative to the currency by reference to which investors measure the return on their investments
because of economic, political and other factors over which the Group has no control. Depreciation of the
sterling against the currency by reference to which investors measure the return on their investments
could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result
in a loss to investors when the return on such Notes is translated into the currency by reference to which
the investors measure the return on their investments. Investments in the Notes denominated in a
currency other than U.S. dollars by U.S. investors may also have important tax consequences as a result
of foreign exchange gains or losses, if any. See "Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United States
_Federal Income Tax Considerations."_

**_The Notes may be issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes._**

The Notes may be issued with original issue discount ("OID") for U.S. federal income tax purposes. A
series of Notes will be considered to be issued with OID if the stated principal amount of such series
exceeds their issue price (as determined for U.S. federal income tax purposes) by an amount equal to or
more than a statutorily defined de minimis amount. In such event, investors in such series of Notes subject
to U.S. federal income taxation generally will be required to include such OID in their gross income (as
ordinary income) on an annual basis under a constant yield accrual method regardless of their regular
method of accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. As a result, such investors generally will
include any OID in income in advance of the receipt of cash attributable to such income. See "Certain
_Tax Considerations—Certain United States Federal Income Tax Considerations—Original Issue_
_Discount."_

**_You may not be able to recover in civil proceedings for U.S. securities law violations._**

Each of the Issuers, the Jersey Security Provider and the Guarantors and their respective
subsidiaries are organised outside the United States, and the Group's business is conducted entirely
outside the United States. The directors, managers and/or executive officers of the Issuers, the Jersey
Security Provider and the Guarantors are non-residents of the United States. Although the Issuers, the
Jersey Security Provider, the Guarantors and their respective subsidiaries will submit to the jurisdiction
of certain New York courts in connection with any action under U.S. securities laws, you may be unable
to effect service of process within the United States on these directors, managers and executive officers.
In addition, as all of the assets of the Issuers, the Jersey Security Provider and the Guarantors and their
respective subsidiaries and those of their directors, managers and executive officers are located outside
of the United States, you may be unable to enforce judgments obtained in the U.S. courts against them.
Moreover, actions of the Issuers, the Jersey Security Provider and the Guarantors may not be subject to

### 127


-----

the provisions of the federal securities laws of the United States. The United States is not currently bound
by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments, other than arbitral awards,
rendered in civil and commercial matters with England and Wales or Jersey. There is, therefore, doubt
as to the enforceability in England and Wales and Jersey of U.S. securities laws in an action to enforce
a U.S. judgment in such jurisdictions. In addition, the enforcement in England and Wales and Jersey of
any judgment obtained in a U.S. court, whether or not predicated solely upon U.S. federal securities laws,
will be subject to certain conditions. There is also doubt that a court in England and Wales and Jersey
would have the requisite power or authority to grant remedies sought in an original action brought in such
jurisdictions on the basis of U.S. securities laws violations. For further information see "Service of Process
_and Enforcement of Judgments."_

**_The Notes will initially be held in book-entry form, and therefore you must rely on the procedures_**
**_of the relevant clearing systems to exercise any rights and remedies._**

Unless and until Notes in definitive registered form, or definitive registered notes are issued in
exchange for book-entry interests (which may occur only in very limited circumstances), owners of bookentry interests will not be considered owners or holders of Notes. The common depositary (or its
nominee) for Euroclear and Clearstream will be the sole registered holder of the global notes. Payments
of principal, interest and other amounts owing on or in respect of the relevant global notes representing
the Notes will be made to the Paying Agent, which will make payments to Euroclear and Clearstream.
Thereafter, these payments will be credited to participants' accounts that hold book-entry interests in the
global notes representing the Notes and credited by such participants to indirect participants. After
payment to the common depositary for Euroclear and Clearstream, we will have no responsibility or

### 128


-----

liability for the payment of interest, principal or other amounts to the owners of book-entry interests.
Accordingly, owners of book-entry interests in the relevant Notes must rely on the procedures of
Euroclear and Clearstream and if such owners are not a participants in Euroclear and/or Clearstream,
on the procedures of the participant through which their interest is owned, to exercise any rights and
obligations of a holder of the relevant Notes under the relevant Indenture.

Unlike the holders of the Notes themselves, owners of book-entry interests will not have any direct
rights to act upon any solicitations for consents, requests for waivers or other actions from holders of
the Notes. Instead, owners of book-entry interests will be permitted to act only to the extent they have
received appropriate proxies to do so from Euroclear and Clearstream or, if applicable, from a
participant. There can be no assurance that procedures implemented for the granting of such proxies
will be sufficient to enable an owner of a book entry interest to vote on any matters or on a timely basis.

Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the relevant Indenture, unless and until
the relevant definitive registered Notes are issued in respect of all book-entry interests, owners of bookentry interests will be restricted to acting through Euroclear and Clearstream. We can make no
assurances that the procedures to be implemented through Euroclear and Clearstream will be adequate
to ensure the timely exercise of rights under the Notes.

**_The interests of the Group's principal shareholders may conflict with your interests._**

The interests of the Group's principal shareholders, in certain circumstances, may conflict with your

would reduce the Group's ability to meet its debt service obligations or fund working capital, capital

ability to generate revenue, each of which could adversely affect holders of the Notes.

In addition, our principal shareholders own the EG Group, which operates in the fuel and convenience
retail industry in jurisdictions including the United Kingdom, and may, in the future, own businesses that
directly compete with ours or do business with us.

**_We will be subject to significant restrictive debt covenants, which limit our operating and financial_**
**_flexibility._**

The Indentures will contain covenants which impose significant operating and financial restrictions on
us. These agreements limit our ability to, among other things:

    - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness or issue certain preferred stock;

    - make certain restricted payments and investments;

    - transfer or sell assets;

    - create or incur certain liens;

    - create or incur restrictions on the ability of our subsidiaries to pay dividends or to make other
payments to us;

    - take certain actions that would impair the Security Interests granted for the benefit of the holders
of the Notes; and

    - merge, consolidate or transfer all or substantially all of our assets.

our other liabilities and the liabilities of our subsidiaries which would be due and payable and to make

of those amounts.

**_We will require a significant amount of cash to service our debt and sustain our operations. Our_**
**_ability to generate or raise sufficient cash depends on many factors beyond our control._**

On the Issue Date, we expect to issue a significant amount of debt and will have significant debt service
obligations, including under the Notes, the Senior Facilities and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility.
Our ability to make principal or interest payments when due on and to refinance our debt, and to fund
working capital, rental and lease payments and capital expenditures, will depend on our future operating
performance and ability to generate sufficient cash. This depends, to some extent, on the success of our
business strategy and on general economic, financial, competitive, market, legislative, regulatory and
other factors discussed in these "Risk Factors" and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, as well as
other factors, many of which are beyond our control. This also depends on our cash flow cycle, which
experiences seasonal fluctuations. Levels of customer traffic at our stores are affected by the weather and
travel patterns, among other factors, which could also have a negative impact on our cash position and
impact our ability to make payments on and to refinance our debt and to fund working capital and capital
expenditures. If our interest payment dates coincide with periods of significant cash outflow, we may have
insufficient cash to pay our obligations as they come due.

We cannot assure you that the currently anticipated cost savings, revenue growth and operating
improvements will be realised, that cash flows from operations will be sufficient, or that future debt and
equity financing will be available to us on satisfactory terms or in an amount sufficient to enable us to
refinance all or a portion of our debt, pay our debts when due, or to fund our other liquidity needs.

If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources are insufficient to pay our
obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be forced to:

    - reduce or delay our business activities and capital expenditures;

    - sell assets;

    - obtain additional debt or equity capital; or

    - restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, on or before maturity.

We cannot assure you that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis
or on satisfactory terms, if at all. In particular, our ability to restructure or refinance our debt will depend in
part on our financial condition at such time as well as on many factors outside of our control, including
then-prevailing conditions in the international credit and capital markets. In such event, we may not to be
able to meet our debt repayment obligations. In addition, the terms of our debt limit, and any future debt
may limit, our ability to pursue any of these alternatives. See "—We will be subject to significant restrictive
_debt covenants, which limit our operating and financial flexibility."_ Any refinancing of our debt could be at
higher interest rates and could require us to comply with more onerous covenants, which could further
restrict our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects. There can be no
assurance that any assets which we could be required to dispose of could be sold or that, if sold, the timing
of such sale and the amount of proceeds realised from such sale would be acceptable.

Furthermore, our inability to meet payment obligations under our existing debt could trigger various
default provisions, accelerate a substantial portion (if not all) of our debt, and would materially adversely
affect our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects.

**Risks Relating to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral**

**_Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes_**

**_Holders of the Senior Secured Notes will not control decisions regarding the Senior Secured Notes_**
**_Collateral in certain circumstances._**

basis by the same Collateral securing the obligations under the Senior Facilities and the Forecourt

The Intercreditor Agreement provides that a common Security Agent, who is also the security agent for
the lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility Agreement and
any additional debt secured by the Collateral permitted to be incurred by the Indentures, the Senior
Facilities Agreement and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility, will act only as provided for in the

Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility Agreement

the Senior Secured Notes, and following the repayment of the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility, we

to incur additional indebtedness secured on a _pari passu_ basis with the Senior Secured Notes, which
would further dilute the voting interest of holders of the Senior Secured Notes issued on the Issue Date.

The lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement, lenders under the Forecourt Disposal Bridge
Facility Agreement and creditors in respect of any indebtedness secured on a pari passu basis with the

interests of holders of the Senior Secured Notes and they may, subject to the terms of the Intercreditor

**_Secured Notes Issuer and other Shared Security may be limited._**

The obligations under the Senior Notes and the Senior Notes Guarantees will be secured by security

of the Senior Notes may not be able to recover on the Shared Security as the creditors in respect of the
Senior Secured Liabilities will have a prior claim on all proceeds realised from any enforcement of such

will need to share any remaining proceeds from such enforcement with any other secured creditor ranking

Security exceed the Senior Secured Liabilities, any excess amount of such proceeds will be paid to the
Senior Notes Trustee on behalf of itself and the holders of the Senior Notes. If there are no excess
proceeds, or if the amount of such excess proceeds is less than the aggregate amount of the obligations
under the Senior Notes, the holders of Senior Notes will not fully recover (if at all) under such Shared
Security.

In addition, the Shared Security may not be liquid, and its value to other parties may be less than its
value to us. Likewise, the Group cannot assure you that there will be a market for the pledged shares or
other Shared Security or that, if such market does exist, there will not be substantial delays in their
liquidation. The shares of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may also have limited value in the event of a
bankruptcy, insolvency or other similar proceeding in relation to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer because
all of the obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer (subject to the release mechanism in the
Intercreditor Agreement) (including the Senior Notes Guarantees) must be satisfied prior to distribution to
the Senior Secured Notes Issuer's equity holders. As a result, the holders of the Senior Notes may not
recover anything of value in the case of an enforcement sale of shares pledged in the Senior Secured
Notes Issuer. In addition, the value of the Issuer Share Collateral may fluctuate over time.

Pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement, the Senior Notes Trustee and holders of the Senior Notes will
(subject to certain limited exceptions) not be able to force a sale of the Shared Security or otherwise
independently pursue the remedies of a secured creditor under the Security Documents relating to such
