**THE TRANSACTIONS**

In this Offering Memorandum, references to the "Transactions" are to the (i) Acquisition and our
performance of all obligations contemplated by the Acquisition Agreement, (ii) Financing and (iii) PostCompletion Transactions, collectively, (with each of (i) through (iii) and any subcomponent thereof or other
transaction or intermediate step reasonably necessary to consummate any of the foregoing, a
"Transaction").

**The Acquisition and Acquisition Agreement**

On October 2, 2020, the Issa Brothers and TDR Capital (the "Shareholders") caused their jointly
controlled entity, Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited (the "Purchaser"), to enter into the Acquisition
Agreement with the Seller, a subsidiary of Walmart, pursuant to which the Purchaser committed to acquire
all of the issued ordinary shares of the Company on the Acquisition Completion Date (the "Acquisition").
The Purchaser, a limited company formed under the laws of Jersey, is an indirect, wholly-owned subsidiary
of the Issuers. It was formed by the Shareholders solely for the purpose of engaging in the transactions
contemplated by the Acquisition Agreement and has not commenced any operations, other than as set
forth in the Acquisition Agreement.

Pursuant to the Acquisition Agreement, the consideration payable by the Purchaser on the Acquisition
Completion Date will be £6,614.0 million (assuming an Acquisition Completion Date of February 16, 2021)
(the "Purchase Consideration"). Under the terms of the Acquisition Agreement, the Seller was required
to use commercially reasonable endeavours to cause the Company to make distributions to the Seller or
other Walmart Group Companies of at least £1,769.5 million prior to the Acquisition Completion Date. On
December 21, 2020, the Company approved a distribution of £1,769.5 million to ASDA Holdings UK
Limited, of which £1,269.5 million was a distribution in specie through the transfer of intercompany
receivables and £500.0 million was settled in cash. On the Acquisition Completion Date, the Company will
settle outstanding intercompany payables due by the ASDA Group to Walmart Group Companies in cash.

The Acquisition Agreement includes customary warranties by the Seller and the Purchaser. The Seller
and the Purchaser have also separately agreed on a dedicated indemnification regime applicable to any
losses arising from the Equal Value Claims. As contemplated by the Acquisition Agreement, the
Acquisition will be completed following receipt of the FCA's approval, but during the pendency of the review
of the Acquisition by the CMA, which is the competition authority that has the authority to review the
Acquisition following referral by the European Commission. The CMA's review is ongoing. Currently, the
CMA is conducting its phase 1 inquiry into the Acquisition. If the CMA identifies competition-related
concerns over the course of this phase 1 inquiry, we intend to propose remedies to address these
concerns, which may include the sale of certain PFS sites to unaffiliated third parties. See "—The Post_Completion Transactions—Forecourt Disposals." However, there can be no assurance that any remedies_
we may propose will be acceptable to the CMA. If the remedies we may propose are rejected, the CMA
Clearance Date could be significantly delayed and more extensive remedies may be required from us,
which could potentially include a mandated sale of the ASDA Group. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating
_to the Transactions—The Acquisition is subject to certain uncertainties and risks, which could adversely_
_impact recoveries under the Notes."_

In connection with the CMA's review of the Acquisition, we expect the CMA to issue an IEO shortly
before or immediately after Completion, which we expect to remain in force until the CMA Clearance Date.
Under this IEO, the Bellis Group will not be permitted to exercise de facto control over the ASDA Group
or otherwise direct its operations until the CMA Clearance Date. As a result, although we acquired the
ASDA Group on the Acquisition Completion Date, we will not effectively control the ASDA Group until the
CMA Clearance Date. Furthermore, while the IEO is in effect, it will prevent us from making any significant
structural or organisational changes to the ASDA Group, including the Forecourt Business Disposal, the
Excluded Forecourt Divestments or any other Post-Completion Transactions, unless we seek and obtain
a derogation from the CMA. Accordingly, we do not intend to initiate these post-completion transactions
until the CMA Clearance Date.

**The Financing**

**_The Financing in the event that the Acquisition Completion Date occurs prior to the Issue Date_**

We expect to settle the Offering after the consummation of the Acquisition. In this case, we expect to
fund our payment of the Purchase Consideration on the Acquisition Completion Date using the Equity
Contribution (including Walmart's Rollover Equity Investment) and amounts drawn under the Senior
Facilities, the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility, the Senior Bridge Facility and the Senior Secured Bridge
Facilities (the "Initial Financing") and the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. On the Issue Date,
we will then use the proceeds from the Offering to repay a portion of the Initial Financing, including all

### 138


-----

amounts drawn under the Senior Bridge Facility and the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities (together with
the Initial Financing and the other related transactions described in this section of the Offering
Memorandum, the "Financing"). See "Use of Proceeds."

**_Utilisations of Senior Bridge Facility_**

On the Acquisition Completion Date, the Senior Notes Issuer expects to draw the full amount of the
Senior Bridge Facility under the Senior Bridge Facility Agreement and to on-lend the amounts received to
the Senior Secured Notes Issuer under the Senior Financing Proceeds Loan. See "Description of Certain
_Financing Arrangements."_

**_Utilisations of Senior Facilities, the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities and the Forecourt Disposal_**
**_Bridge Facility_**

On the Acquisition Completion Date, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer expects to draw the full amount
of the Term Loan Facilities under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities
and the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer will on-lend the net proceeds
from these drawings along with funds received from the Senior Notes Issuer under the Senior Financing
Proceeds Loan to the Purchaser, to be used as described in "Use of Proceeds." See "Description of
_Certain Financing Arrangements."_

**_Utilisation of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility_**

On the Acquisition Completion Date, the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower expects
to draw £950 million under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, which will be on-lent by way of
the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Proceeds Loan to Midco 2. Midco 2 and its subsidiaries, in
turn, will on-lend the net proceeds of the drawing to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer pursuant to a deeply
subordinated instrument, to be used as described in "Use of Proceeds." See "Description of Certain
_Financing Arrangements—Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility." To secure the Distribution Asset_
Disposal Bridge Facility, certain entities within the ASDA Group will grant first priority mortgages, fixed
charges or standard securities, as applicable, over the Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets and,
to the extent required thereunder, certain Substitute Retail Assets, as well as first-ranking pledges on the
Designated Bank Accounts. Prior to the execution of these mortgages, fixed charges, standard securities
and pledges, as applicable, entities within the ASDA Group are expected to enter into lease agreements
in respect of the Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, the Substitute
Retail Assets on substantially the terms summarised in "Certain Relationships and Related Party
_Transactions―ASDA Leases."_

**_The Equity Contribution_**

In connection with the Acquisition, the Shareholders and Walmart will cause Bellis TopCo Limited and
its subsidiaries to contribute to the equity of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or on-lend to the Senior
Secured Notes Issuer pursuant to deeply subordinated instruments approximately £1,280 million in
aggregate (the "Equity Contribution"), which includes the proceeds of Walmart's £500 million Rollover
Equity Investment and £780 million of funds raised by the Shareholders.

**_The Offering and the repayment of the bridge loans_**

On the Issue Date, the Senior Notes Issuer will use the proceeds from the Offering of the Senior Notes
to repay all amounts outstanding under the Senior Bridge Facility Agreement, and the Senior Secured
Notes Issuer will use the proceeds from the Offering of the Senior Secured Notes to repay all amounts
outstanding under the Senior Secured Bridge Facilities Agreement. See "Use of Proceeds."

**_Estimated cash and cash equivalents as of the Acquisition Completion Date_**

On or about the Acquisition Completion Date, ASDA will settle in cash intercompany loans owed to
Walmart of £409.0 million. In addition, on December 3, 2020, the Company announced that it will pay in
full its business rates for the UK tax year ending April 5, 2021 to the UK government (and the devolved
administrations of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland), thus waiving the relief it had received earlier in
2020 in respect of such payment as part of the UK government's measures in support of UK businesses
in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is estimated to be within a range of £320 million to £340
million. As a result, the Company expects to pay £254 million in retrospective business rates for the period
from April to December 2020, to be funded from cash available on the Company's balance sheet. The
Company expects to engage in due course with the competent UK authorities to discuss and agree the
exact terms of such payment, including its timing. ASDA also plans to resume its regular payments of the
business rates on a monthly basis commencing with the month of January 2021. The Company estimates

**_The Financing in the event that the Issue Date occurs prior to, or substantially concurrently with,_**
**_the Acquisition Completion Date_**

It is possible that the Acquisition Completion Date may be delayed until after the Issue Date, including
due to the timing of our receipt of the FCA's approval of the Acquisition. In this case, unless the Offering
is settled substantially concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition, we will, pending completion of the
Acquisition, fund the gross proceeds of the Offering into Escrow Accounts, which will be held in the name
of the relevant Issuer, but controlled by the relevant Escrow Agent, and pledged in favour of the relevant
Trustee on behalf of and for the benefit of the holders of the relevant Notes, pursuant to the terms of the
Escrow Agreements and Escrow Account Charges dated on or before the Issue Date. Under the terms of
the Escrow Agreements, release of the Escrowed Proceeds will be subject to the satisfaction of certain
conditions, including the completion of the Acquisition and the solvency of the relevant Issuer. Following
release from escrow, we expect to use the proceeds of the Offering, together with the Equity Contribution
and amounts drawn under the Senior Facilities, the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility and the Distribution
Asset Disposal Bridge Facility (as described above and in "Use of Proceeds.") to fund our payment of the
Purchase Consideration on the Acquisition Completion Date. In the event we deposit the gross proceeds
of the Offering into the Escrow Accounts on the Issue Date and the Acquisition Completion Date has not
occurred, or the conditions to the release of such Escrowed Proceeds have not been satisfied, on or before
the Outside Date, Midco has not elected to extend the initial Shortfall Agreement Termination Date (or any
extension thereof) and the Release has not occurred as at such date or in certain other circumstances,
subject to certain conditions, the Notes will be mandatorily redeemable at a price equal to 100% of the
aggregate issue price of the Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issue Date to, but not
including, the Special Mandatory Redemption Date and Additional Amounts, if any.

If the Offering is settled substantially concurrently with the completion of the Acquisition, we will forgo
these escrow procedures and will instead retain the proceeds of the Offering to fund part of the
consideration payable under the Acquisition Agreement on the Acquisition Completion Date. See "Use of
_Proceeds," "Description of the Senior Notes—Acquisition Agreement, Timing of Completion Date and_
_Issue Date; Escrow of Proceeds" and "Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Acquisition Agreement,_

to the Designated Bank Accounts, and to the extent required by the terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal
Bridge Facility, Substitute Retail Assets and Select Retail Assets, to Propco 2 or other affiliates who are

(the "Post-Completion Disposal Receivables"). Alternatively, Select Retail Assets and, as relevant,
Substitute Retail Assets may remain held by the ASDA Group but will continue to be charged in favour of
the lenders under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility as described in the paragraph below.
ASDA will agree to subordinate its claims against Propco 2 or such other affiliates to those of lenders
under the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility pursuant to a separate subordination agreement. The
transfers of each of the Warehouse Assets and, to the extent required by the terms of the Distribution
Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, Substitute Retail Assets and Select Retail Assets in connection with the
Post-Completion Disposals will be subject to the ASDA Leases, which will remain in effect. To the extent

**_Forecourt Disposals_**

On February 3, 2021, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and Bellis Forecourts Limited entered into the
Forecourt SPA, whereby the Senior Secured Notes Issuer undertook to sell to Bellis Forecourts Limited
the share capital of Acquisition 2 or any other member of the Bellis Group or a member of the ASDA Group
that holds the Forecourt Business, directly or indirectly, following the Acquisition Completion Date, the
CMA Clearance Date and completion of the acquisition by Acquisition 2 (or such other company) of the
Forecourt Business. Pursuant to a separate agreement, the EG Forecourt SPA, entered into on or about
the same date, Property Newco agreed to sell to Euro Garages Limited the share capital of Holdco (owning
in turn Bellis Forecourts Limited and therefore the Forecourt Business) promptly upon closing under the
Forecourt SPA. Property Newco may assign such separate agreement to the shareholders (i.e., Optima
Group S.à r.l. and Able Holdings Limited), who may sell Property Newco itself, rather than Holdco or one
of its subsidiaries. In preparation for, and prior to, the closing of the Forecourt SPA, we expect that ASDA
will distribute the Forecourt Business to Acquisition 2 as soon as practicable following the CMA Clearance
Date. In order to effect the distribution of the Forecourt Business to Acquisition 2 as a dividend in kind,
ASDA will have to arrange for the separation of the freehold or leasehold title to its co-located forecourts
(comprising the vast majority of the Forecourt Assets) from the parent title currently comprising adjacent
store or retail assets or sites by way of a Forecourt Assets Separation and the entities within the ASDA
Group that currently hold non-co-located Forecourt Assets will need to distribute such assets to Acquisition
2. We expect that the process of effecting these title separations and distributions to take several months
following the Acquisition Completion Date.

The headline enterprise value established under the Forecourt SPA, subject to customary working
capital adjustments, is £750 million, less the aggregate value of any Excluded Forecourts (and of any other
assets relating to the Excluded Forecourts). The consideration will be left outstanding at the closing of the
Forecourt SPA (the "Forecourt Disposal Receivable") and we expect it to be ultimately settled in cash
and in full promptly following the closing of the EG Forecourt SPA. See "Certain Relationships and Related
_Party Transactions—Forecourt SPA." The parties may decide to novate and assign the Forecourt SPA to_
another member of the Bellis Group or a member of the ASDA Group (as seller) and to a member of the
EG Group (as buyer), in which case the separate agreement between Property Newco and Euro Garages
Limited would be terminated and the Forecourt Business (or a holding company thereof) would be sold
directly to EG Group by the ASDA Group.

The IEO that is expected to be issued by the CMA will not permit us to sell any Forecourt Assets
pursuant to the Forecourt SPA for so long as the IEO remains in force. Consequently, we do not expect
to consummate the Forecourt Business Disposal before the CMA Clearance Date. The Forecourt SPA
requires us to complete the transactions contemplated thereunder as soon as reasonably practicable
following the satisfaction of the conditions precedent stipulated in its terms, which include the IEO to be
issued by the CMA ceasing to be in effect.

The CMA's investigation of the Acquisition is ongoing, and we may be required to take remedial action
to address any competition-related concerns the CMA may identify. If remedies prove necessary, we may
be required to designate certain Forecourt Assets (along with certain related assets) as Excluded
Forecourts and sell them to unaffiliated third parties (the "Excluded Forecourt Divestments"). Although
we will attempt to carry out the Excluded Forecourt Divestments by way of orderly sales following a
competitive sales process, there can be no assurance that the market conditions or circumstances of the
Excluded Forecourt Divestments will permit such an outcome, and the price we receive for any Excluded
Forecourts sold through the Excluded Forecourt Divestments may be less than what we would have
ultimately received in a fully voluntary sale. In addition, third parties may have rights over the Forecourt

### 143


-----

Assets (including rights to acquire and pre-emption rights) exercisable in the event of a transfer of the
Forecourt Assets (whether of the freehold or leasehold interest or of whole or part). In all such cases, the
transfer of those Forecourt Assets may be significantly delayed, prevented in part or prevented entirely.
See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—The Acquisition is subject to certain uncertainties
_and risks, which could adversely impact recoveries under the Notes."_

Under the terms of the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility, the proceeds from the sale of both the
Forecourt Business Disposal and the Excluded Forecourt Divestment must be used to repay amounts
outstanding under the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility until it has been repaid in full. See "Description
_of Certain Financing Arrangements—Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility."_

**Overview**

We are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom and the second-largest grocery retailer
in the North of England, Scotland and Wales (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a
52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). We operate a significant store estate of
614 stores (excluding standalone PFSs) that are geographically diversified across the United Kingdom.
We also have the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom (in terms of Total Grocery
Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). The graph below
compares our total grocery market share with that of other major UK grocery retailers.

(Source: Kantar. Based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020. *Ocado Market share
shown.)

We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market that is underpinned by
favourable macroeconomic factors including GDP, population, consumer confidence and household
expenditure on food and beverages and which has historically demonstrated resilient performance through
economic fluctuations. Groceries are a necessary and regular consumer expenditure, which we believe
generally allows the grocery retail market to weather economic downturns better than certain other retail
markets. For example, the UK grocery retail market demonstrated its two strongest periods of growth in
recent history during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and during the COVID-19 pandemic. See also
"Industry."

153


-----

One of the key capabilities that drives our performance is our differentiated operating model, which is
in turn centred around our omni-channel offer (with multiple fulfilment options), our commitment to "Every
Day Low Price" and our wholly-owned supplier, IPL, which enables us to take a vertically-integrated
approach to procurement and which we believe gives us a competitive advantage in food sourcing. Other
key capabilities that drive our performance include our profitable and well-established George Clothing and
George Home offers, our well-developed own-brand grocery offers and our team of flexible and engaged
colleagues. Historically, we have benefited from the support of Walmart, our former parent company. We
will continue to receive support from Walmart over the next three years pursuant to the Transitional
Agreements negotiated in connection with the Acquisition. For more information about the ongoing support
to be provided by Walmart, please see "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—
_Transitional Agreements with Walmart" and "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are_
_risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart."_

We are a highly cash-generative business of scale with strong asset backing. In the year ended
December 31, 2019, our revenue was approximately £22.9 billion (including petrol), of which approximately
£2 billion was online sales, and our Adjusted EBITDA was approximately £1.2 billion (including petrol).

The chart below presents the breakdown of our 2019 revenue by product category (food, general
merchandise, clothing and petrol), food category (ambient and fresh and produce) and channel (stores and
online (including George.com)).

(Source: ASDA information. Year ended December 31, 2019. Note: Does not include £61 million of other revenue.)
Our differentiated operating model has resulted in strong financial performance: our successful financial
profile is underpinned by strong Adjusted EBITDA margins, free cash flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA
less capital expenditure) and cash conversion (defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA)
in recent years. In 2018 and 2019, our average Adjusted EBITDA margin was 5.5% (including petrol), our
cumulative free cash flow was approximately £1.7 billion and our average cash conversion was
approximately 70%.

-----

We believe that our business, operating model and financial performance also benefit from our
significant freehold real estate asset portfolio. See "Brokers' Opinions of Pricing."

We believe that our omni-channel food offer delivers low prices across the full basket and that we
maintain a meaningful price gap as compared to other traditional grocers in the United Kingdom. Within
the UK value market, we have strong market shares across ambient products (13.0%), fresh/chilled
(11.6%) and total grocery (12.2%) (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52
weeks ended December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). Our offer is strong across the full food basket: our

155


-----

category market shares range from 12% to 14% (except household and toiletries) (in each case in terms
of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). We
believe that we are the least expensive full-selection traditional grocer in the United Kingdom: according to
internal ASDA data, our prices are approximately 6% to 7.5% less expensive than our traditional grocer
competitors (on a 2020 year-to-date (weeks 1-42) average, based on total goods price gap percentage).

Our food business is already of significant scale, is supported by a strong online offer and is
supplemented by a large clothing and general merchandise business. We offer our entire range of food
and non-food products to customers as a convenient "one-stop shop" experience that is supported and
enhanced by our strong online offer. We believe our omni-channel offer, through which we reach customers
at our brick-and-mortar stores, through our significant online offering and on our app, appeals to our
customers. In 2020, there were approximately 9.8 million weekly visits to groceries.asda.com, with
approximately 488,000 weekly orders pre-COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days
ended February 28, 2020), and approximately 723,000 weekly orders post COVID-19 (based on the
average orders for the seven days ended September 30, 2020). The COVID-19 pandemic has increased
use of and engagement with our online platforms and we currently fulfil approximately 720,000 online
orders per week. Our online grocery business operates from 350 stores, we offer at-home delivery and
customers are also able to collect their purchases at one of approximately 460 ASDA Click & Collect sites.
We are also expanding our 1-hour Click & Collect offer. Our business model integrates our store-based
and online offer by leveraging our stores to fulfil online orders.

Our online grocery business is profitable and has been consistently gaining market share within one of
the world's most developed online grocery markets. We have consistently outperformed the UK online
grocery market and increased our online market share in the last three years. According to Kantar, we
currently operate the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom, holding 18.2% of
market share (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales) as of December 2019, which
grew to 19.8% as of December 27, 2020 (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales),
representing a 1.5% gain and the second-strongest share gain since December 2019 amongst our key
competitors. The chart below shows the evolution of our market share as compared with our key
competitors for the periods presented. See also "Industry."

(Source: Kantar. Based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales for the year-to-date as of December 27,
2020 as compared to the 52-week periods through December 31 for 2017, 2018 and 2019.)

-----

Our online business is already of significant scale: the chart below shows the growth of our online sales,
including a breakdown of online grocery versus George.com sales, for the periods presented.

(Source: ASDA information.)

According to Kantar, we are the second-largest online clothing retailer overall by volume in the United
Kingdom and we held 6.0% of the total UK online clothing (excluding essentials, footwear and accessories)
market by volume for the 52 weeks ended December 13, 2020. Combined sales for our online grocery
business and George.com have rapidly increased in recent years, growing from £1.7 billion (of which £1.5
billion were online grocery sales and £0.2 billion were George.com sales) in 2018 to £1.9 billion in 2019
(of which £1.6 billion were online grocery sales and £0.3 billion were George.com sales) to a total of £2.7
billion for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020 (of which £2.4 billion were online grocery sales and
£0.3 billion were George.com sales), representing a CAGR of 26% between 2018 and September 30,
2020. Additionally, our toyou service allows customers to conveniently collect and return orders from
George.com and other partner retailers at our stores. We have partnered with 119 brands and process
more than 10 million parcels per year.

With our team of approximately 140,000 flexible and engaged colleagues serving approximately 15
million customers each week (based on the average of weeks 39 to 42 of 2020), we are committed to and
deeply invested in the UK food supply chain.

Our business model is supported by diversification. First, we are a mass market retailer that serves the
entire UK population, in terms of both customer demographics and geography, with our customer base
skewing slightly towards value-seeking families, younger shoppers and lower-income customers who are
attracted by our Every Day Low Price strategy and with strong market shares in the North of England,
Scotland and Wales. For more information about our customer mix, see "—Our Customers," and for more
information about the geographic distribution of our stores, see "—Our Real Estate Portfolio." Second, we
believe we are well-positioned geographically, with a strong regional footprint across the United Kingdom.
Our store footprint is strongest in the North of England, Scotland and Wales. Our large and diverse store
estate offers customers a variety of differentiated shopping formats. We operate 30 supercentres, 396
superstores, 155 supermarkets and 33 ASDA Living stores. For more information on our stores, see "—
_Our Store Formats."_

Subject to receipt of regulatory approvals, our 18 standalone PFSs and 305 co-located PFSs (including
both their underlying real estate assets and their business operations) will be sold to EG Group pursuant
to the Forecourt Business Disposal. However, to the extent we are required to do so in order to obtain
regulatory approval for the Acquisition, we will sell all or part of our forecourt business to third parties. In
addition, we will transfer to Propco 2 (or an affiliate) the real estate relating to the Warehouse Assets, and
to the extent required pursuant to the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility, the Select Retail Assets
and, to the extent applicable, the Substitute Retail Assets promptly following the CMA Clearance Date. We
will continue to operate the Warehouse Assets, the Select Retail Assets and, to the extent applicable, the
Substitute Retail Assets pursuant to the ASDA Leases which will be put in place in accordance with the
terms of the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility. For more information, see "The Transactions—The
_Post Completion Disposals." This "Business" section, including historical statements herein, principally_
relates the ASDA's business as it will be following the completion of the Transactions.

Following the completion of the Acquisition, we will continue to benefit over the next three years from
support provided by Walmart, the world's largest retailer, through the Transitional Agreements. See
"Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart" and "Risk
_Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are risks associated with the Separation of ASDA_
_from Walmart." In addition to the Transitional Agreements, we have also agreed with Walmart to set up_

is expected to bring a number of benefits, in particular:

 • Deep research and development expertise and capabilities;

 • Global sourcing, leveraging Walmart's sourcing capabilities in clothing and general merchandise;

 • Best practices, leveraging Walmart's expertise and experience as a leading global retailer; and

 • Long-term support and continued partnership with Walmart's management and leadership.

**Segment Reporting**

We are engaged in a single reportable operating segment of business: the retailing of food, clothing,
general merchandise, petrol and services in a single geographical segment, the United Kingdom, and
online. All significant revenue is generated by the sale of goods through retail outlets in the United Kingdom
and through the Company's online channels. The operations of all product areas of the business are subject
to similar economic characteristics and are sold in a similar retail environment.

**Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations**

Our results of operations are affected by a combination of factors. This section discusses key factors
that we believe have had a material effect on our results of operations and financial condition during the
periods under review, as well as those that are reasonably likely to have a material effect on our results of
operations and financial condition in the future. While we believe that our results of operations and financial
condition, and particularly the results of operations and financial condition during the periods under review,
have been primarily affected by the following key factors, these factors are not exhaustive, and the entirety
of this Offering Memorandum should be reviewed, particularly the "Risk Factors" section. Additionally,
although we believe that the underlying operating trends that have benefitted our business in recent years,
as described further below, are relatively stable and will generally continue to drive relatively steady
patterns of revenue and EBITDA metrics, it is difficult to predict future performance with any degree of
certainty.

_COVID-19_

The outbreak and spread of COVID-19 was confirmed in the United Kingdom in early 2020 and is
resulting in a high level of uncertainty and disruption to UK economic, social and political activity. The
COVID-19 pandemic resulted in national and local authorities mandating or recommending various
restrictions and other measures throughout most of 2020, including mandatory business restrictions and
closures and social distancing, quarantine and lockdown measures. These restrictions and measures,
which were intended to slow the spread of the virus and protect lives, have resulted in significant job losses
across the United Kingdom and are expected to have serious adverse impacts on domestic and foreign

159

We consider that the principal risks and uncertainties associated with COVID-19 that have led, and
could continue to lead, to a significant financial impact on our business relate, in particular, to product
availability, colleague absence and restrictions on customers' ability to physically access stores. We have
implemented measures to address these principal risks, including plans in place to protect product
availability, to provide cover for increases in levels of colleague absence and to maximise access to ASDA
for customers who are considered most vulnerable to the impacts of COVID-19.

We believe that during the first UK lockdown, consumers strongly favoured supermarkets and
convenience stores that were close to their homes as they responded to the UK government's "stay at
home" message. During the second lockdown, we believe that the change in message from "stay at home"
resulted in customers being willing to travel further during the lockdown, which supported footfall in out-oftown shops. As a result, we generally performed somewhat behind the market during first lockdown, which
we believe was largely driven by not having a convenience offering as well as by consumer hesitation to
venture far from home, while we generally performed somewhat ahead of the market during the second
lockdown, which we believe reflects greater consumer willingness to return to more ordinary shopping
habits as well as the appeal of one-stop shopping experiences, which we believe has benefitted us. This
appeal was further supported by strong promotional and pricing activity during the second lockdown period.

Structural shifts due to COVID-19 have led to increased overall growth in the grocery retail market.
During the COVID-19 pandemic, customer behaviour has changed, with a shift away from out-of-home
food consumption towards at-home food consumption, to the benefit of the UK grocery retail market. The
chart below shows COVID-19-accelerated channel shifts over the periods presented. For further

(Source: Kantar Worldpanel, based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a year-to-date basis ended December 27, 2020.)

Grocery sales have grown by 12.3% between December 1, 2019 and December 27, 2020, according
to Kantar, based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales. Changes to consumer behaviour that have positively
benefitted the grocery market during the COVID-19 pandemic include: increased consumption of food at
home, a shift to online shopping channels, increased preference for shopping locally, in particular during
the first UK lockdown (which we believe benefitted retail groups with a strong convenience store presence),
and an increased focus on food safety, hygiene and health.

Despite significant challenges posed by COVID-19, our business has remained resilient, supported by
a well-developed online channel which saw significant growth through the government-imposed lockdowns
as customer behaviour evolved. We were able to quickly increase the capacity of our online offer in
response to increased demand driven by the COVID-19 pandemic, gaining market share and improving
the profitability of our online business.

During the COVID-19 pandemic, we have benefitted from healthy revenue growth driven by higher food
sales volumes (which were in turn driven by stockpiling and increased customer demand for in-home
groceries via the online grocery channel), while margins contracted due to adverse changes in sales and
product mix resulting from decreases in clothing sales, which impacted the George Clothing brand, the
temporary closure of 33 ASDA Living stores and the shift in product mix within the food category away
from higher-margin categories, such as food-to-go, and towards lower-margin categories, such as beer,
wine and spirits and meat, which factors were partially offset by lower levels of promotional activity and
stronger general merchandise sales. Furthermore, the George Clothing and George Home product
categories generally have higher margins than our food product categories. Profitability was also adversely
impacted by COVID-19-related increases in operating costs, such as the increase in retail colleague wage
costs (driven by bonus payments, overtime wages and wages paid colleagues absent from work due to
COVID-19, as well as wages paid to colleagues who worked during such sick colleagues' absences, rather
than as a result of increased wage rates), increased cost incurred in connection with supplier goodwill
compensation paid to clothing suppliers, inventory markdowns on holiday ranges, enhanced cleaning and
related health and safety measures, as well as higher retail operating expenditures.

We have considered the outbreak of COVID-19 to be a non-adjusting post-balance sheet event: the

_Competitive Environment_

We operate in the highly competitive UK grocery retail market, which we believe is undergoing a period
of significant structural change, characterised by factors such as strong growth and aggressive pricing on
the part of discounters (such as Lidl and Aldi) as well as the other traditional grocers, a shift away from
brick-and-mortar stores to online purchasing and the recent increase in like-for-like sales growth reported
by traditional grocers, all against the backdrop of the general political and economic uncertainty, as well as
the uncertain economic prospect of Brexit (including the risk that Brexit may, among other things, increase
regulatory and compliance costs for imports and products shipped from mainland Great Britain to Northern
Ireland, which we might pass through to customers) and the continuing COVID-19 pandemic, the latter of
which has accelerated many of these trends.

Across all of our market channels, we compete with grocery retailers and other operators for customers,
employees, locations, products and other important aspects of our business. Our success depends on our
ability to satisfy customer needs more effectively than the competition. In order to do so, we have adopted
a strategy to differentiate ourselves from our competitors and compete effectively against them on product
selection, quality, price, convenience of location and the overall shopping experience, among other things.
Our market differentiation strategy focuses on optimising our product offerings, monitoring our mix of
formats and store concepts, strengthening our brand identity through strategic partnerships and by seeking
out opportunities to increase omni-channel sales. Further, our strategy is based on what we believe to be
a well-established own-brand grocery offering, our large and diverse store estate that caters to our
customers' different preferences and our deployment of digital tools and online platforms and innovation
and a well-known and successful clothing brand, George, which was the number two clothing brand by
volume of units sold (excluding essentials, footwear and accessories) in the United Kingdom for the 52
weeks ended December 13, 2020, according to Kantar.

Competition may also affect the prices we charge for our products, which in turn impacts our revenue
and margins, although this is usually experienced on a product-specific basis. For example, a competitor
may cut its prices to attract footfall to its stores, which in turn may require us to respond with a similar price
reduction. We in turn have implemented various strategic initiatives, including our price investment in mid2020 and accompanying "That's ASDA Price" slogan and "pocket tap" PR market campaigns, investments
in new product development, particularly low cost/high-quality options, and accessing the convenience
market through our trial of the ASDA On the Move wholesale-convenience asset-light business model, to
help us remain competitive.

163


-----

Prices for most of our products are set on a national basis and, as a result of significant structural
changes to the UK grocery market, there has been substantial pressure on profit and EBITDA margins
across the industry, which has led market participants to engage in intense short-term promotional activity,
particularly through coupons and selective price cuts. At the same time, we have also experienced an
overall market trend of food and other input price inflation. For example, increases in the UK National
Minimum Wage and National Living Wage have led to grocery market wage inflation. Moreover, following
the Brexit referendum, the relative value of the pound sterling has declined as compared to other relevant
currencies, including the euro. As a result, we and other grocers have experienced inflationary pressures
relating to food prices, as the price of non-British sourced foods, in particular, rose in sterling-denominated
terms. In 2019, 45% of food consumed in the United Kingdom was imported, according to the UK
Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs. Overall, we believe that UK food retailers are trying
to balance the retention of market share with their desire to maintain margins.

We manage this input cost inflation in several ways, such as by using our bargaining power with
suppliers, increasing or decreasing the prices of certain products to offset each other, through product reengineering, for example by maintaining the same price point and altering the weight or recipe, but without
compromising on quality and, in certain circumstances, passing through cost increases to consumers.
These changes, however, have put pressure on our profit and EBITDA margins during the periods under
review and we expect moderate input cost inflation to continue during the remainder of 2020.

We also monitor the competitive UK grocery retail market and trends at a regional and store concept
level and react to such trends by reinforcing our market differentiation strategy, as described above, and
adjusting pricing as appropriate in response to such trends. For example, consumer trends may include
sustained interest (despite COVID-19) in sustainably-sourced products and plant-based eating. We also
seek to identify and execute opportunities to increase our addressable market where appropriate, develop
new concepts and adapt our existing formats to meet customer demand and respond to market trends.

We also operate in the highly competitive UK clothing and footwear retail market through the George
Clothing brand, which offers a wide variety of low cost, high-quality clothing and apparel for babies,
children, men and women, including jewellery, footwear and hosiery selections. The George Clothing brand
was the number two clothing brand by volume of units sold (excluding essentials, footwear and
accessories) in the United Kingdom for the 52 weeks ended December 13, 2020, according to Kantar, with
strong margins as compared to food categories and strong online growth in the past three years. However,
we face competitive challenges in the clothing and footwear retail market, which in the first half of 2020
experienced a significant downturn as a result of decreased clothing sales relating to the COVID-19
pandemic (see "Industry—UK Clothing and Footwear Retail Market"). Furthermore, we face competitive
challenges from competitors that continue to invest in their online and in-store presence. Such competitors
target some of George Clothing's key customer categories. As of September 2020, we completed a
reorganisation of the George business, which was aimed at developing an agile operating model in order
to enable us to retain and grow our customer base and further drive our value proposition. However, we
will continue to face steep competition on the basis of, among other things, the location of our stores; our
website and mobile applications, and their respective design; the breadth, quality, style, price and
availability of our merchandise; and the level of customer service offered. See "Risk Factors—Risks
_Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—Competitive pressures_
_in the apparel, footwear and homeware retail industries are high." For a further discussion of our_
competitive landscape, market share and consumer trends in the UK grocery retail business, see
"Industry—UK Grocery Retail Market Competitive Landscape."

_General Economic Conditions in Our Geographic Markets_

Our core grocery retail business generated 85% of our total sales (excluding petrol) for the year ended
December 31, 2019 and 87% of our total sales (excluding petrol) for the nine months ended September
30, 2020. The grocery retail business is generally relatively insulated from swings in demand related to
general economic conditions because consumer purchases of grocery and non-grocery staples tend to be
less discretionary than purchases in other retail categories. Certain of our other non-grocery offerings, on
the other hand, are more correlated to discretionary spending, and therefore, are more susceptible to
changes in general economic conditions. Such offerings, including George Clothing and general
merchandise, generated 15% and 13% of our total sales (excluding petrol) for the year ended December
31, 2019 and for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, respectively.

Notwithstanding the overall resilient nature of our core grocery retail business, consumer tastes and
shopping practices are affected by specific economic conditions in the local markets in which we operate,
as well as, to a lesser extent, global economic conditions. Such conditions include employment levels,
inflation, GDP growth, average and minimum wage levels, real disposable income, currency exchange

164


-----

rates, consumer confidence and consumer willingness to spend. For example, we believe that when
consumers are confident about current and future economic conditions, our premium grocery offerings,
which carry higher margins, are more likely to attract shoppers. Moreover, we believe that consumers with
rising disposal incomes are more likely to make impulse purchases, which can be margin accretive and lift
average basket sizes. During times of economic stress, such as during the 2007-2009 global financial
crisis, basket sizes may tend to decrease while frequency of trips increases. Additionally, during a
recessionary environment, we may also record more purchases of our affordably-priced and attractive midtier and opening price point own-brand products relative to local and international third-party branded
goods.

According to data from the World Bank, the United Kingdom has some of the strongest macroeconomic
indicators globally and in Europe, ranking as the sixth largest economy globally, and the second-largest in
Europe by real GDP. According to the ONS, the United Kingdom's real gross domestic product ("GDP")
amounted to £2.3 trillion in 2019. According to Fitch Solutions, although the United Kingdom's GDP is
projected to have declined by 9.0% in 2020 due primarily to COVID-19, GDP is expected to rebound in
2021 and return to pre-COVID-19 levels and stabilise by 2023, with an average expected GDP growth of
approximately 1.7% from 2023 to 2025. Other general economic conditions in the United Kingdom have
also been favourable in recent years. According to Fitch, GDP increased by 1.7%, 1.3% and 1.3% between
the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019, respectively, which translated into stable household
expenditure on groceries. For the nine-month period ending September 30, 2020, GDP in the United
Kingdom declined by approximately 8.6%, according to ONS. Average weekly household spend on food
and non-alcoholic drinks as a percentage of total household spend was 10.5%, 10.6% and 10.6% between
the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019, respectively.

For a further discussion of the macroeconomic conditions in the UK grocery retail market and the trends
affecting its growth, see "Industry."

Additionally, there are a number of ways in which Brexit could have an impact on our business, results
of operations and prospects. There are two areas in which we believe the potential for Brexit impacts on
our business to be most relevant: non-tariff barriers to trade and Northern Ireland. As regards non-tariff
barriers to trade, we believe that delays at port could pose a significant risk relating to fresh produce
imported from the EU. We believe that all of the major UK grocery operators are exposed to a similar risk
in this respect. We have a port delay risk mitigation plan in place, which we also would deploy in case of
other disturbance events and which we would use to re-direct shipments from Calais to other ports if
needed. As regards Northern Ireland, we operate 17 stores in Northern Ireland and we are eligible for the
special provisions for supermarkets as we operate in Northern Ireland only and do not have any stores in
the Republic of Ireland. While "supermarket solution" rules have been proposed, we believe that significant
bureaucratic hurdles may result. We note that the EU has granted the United Kingdom a six-month
exemption from its ban on prohibited and restricted goods for products (such as minced meat) being
transported into Northern Ireland. However, this means that alternative sourcing will be needed from July
2021. We also note that current proposals would require significant re-labelling and classification updates
to products in order to sell in Northern Ireland.

_Sensitivity of Our Cost Structure_

Excluding purchases of goods sold, we have a largely fixed cost base in the short- to medium-term,
which does not fluctuate with sales volumes. Instead, our costs generally increase from period to period
based on the sensitivity of certain costs to inflation. We are able to control some costs to a certain degree,
such as those related to marketing and labour (via short-term contracts as well as adjustments to the
number of hours our colleagues work), but must maintain sufficient sales levels to absorb the increase in
our expenses in order to maintain or improve our retail margins. We have also been able to reduce overall
costs by leveraging our vertically integrated procurement arm, IPL, which is a wholly-owned supplier that
serves us exclusively and provides us with a cost price advantage by eliminating the "middle man" in our
supply chain. However, even after taking such actions, certain expenses such as rent, the price of food
ingredients, energy costs, energy taxes and other direct and indirect taxation are outside of our control.
See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to our Business—We are vulnerable to fluctuations in the availability
_and price of food ingredients commodities and packaging material, as well as to fluctuations in the price of_
_electricity and fuel."_

Labour costs represent a significant part of our cost structure. Whilst we can adjust the size of our
workforce, where we have proposals to reduce our headcount, we have legal obligations to consult with
colleague representatives (including trade unions) and engage other labour force actors before proposals
can be implemented. The obligation to consult with colleague representatives may result in amendments

165


-----

to proposed reductions in headcount and therefore take time before we can implement such changes
should they proceed. Additionally, we are subject to laws setting minimum wages. During the periods
presented, the UK government increased the National Minimum Wage and National Living Wage, which
had an impact on our cost structure and generally increased our costs, although this has been in part offset
by cost saving and efficiency initiatives. In particular, as of April 2020, the National Living Wage increased
from £8.21 per hour for April 2019 to £8.72 per hour. Any further increase in wages, energy, maintenance
or any other input in our cost structure which is not mitigated, can also affect our results of operations. See
"Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our failure to attract and retain qualified
_colleagues, increases in labour costs and social charges and other changes to wage regulations could_
_adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition."_

_Investment in New Store Concepts and Channel and Product Innovation_

One of the drivers of our results of operations is our ability to maintain our traditional customer base
and attract new customers through our ongoing investments in fulfilment capacity and development of our
operations, including the evolution of our network of brick-and-mortar retail stores. Our retail store network
is largely mature; however, we regularly evaluate the performance of our stores and have repositioned and
remodelled stores under new store concepts to improve our customers' experience and respond to their
changing preferences. For example, we have refocused capital expenditure on remodelling our existing
stores, in particular to realign store space and offerings to enhance our customer proposition and better
respond to customers' shopping behaviour. In October 2020, we opened our first "sustainability store" at
our Middleton superstore location, which is a concept designed to encourage customers to reuse and refill
their products, allowing customers to bring and fill their own containers with products such as coffee, rice,
pasta and other goods, as well as offering second-hand clothing and increased recycling options. We
generally incur initial and ongoing capital expenditure and pre-opening costs with each new grocery retail
store, although these store concept improvements are expected to require a lower capital expenditure
investment than the format refurbishments we have completed in the past. We are further responding to
shifting customer preferences through our recent trial of the ASDA On the Move wholesale-convenience
asset-light business model. We believe that this store concept will allow us to access the smaller
convenience market and is responsive to changes in our customers' lifestyles. This represents our first
entrance into the growing convenience market, which we have undertaken with in an asset-light approach.
We have also dedicated significant investment into the expansion of our online grocery channel, ASDA
Groceries, and our Click & Collect and toyou services to access new and existing customers who are
increasingly shopping online, a trend that has accelerated during the COVID-19 pandemic. We intend to
continue to target operating model improvements to our online channel supported by developments in our
IT infrastructure.

_The Online Grocery Market in the United Kingdom_

The UK online grocery market was estimated to have a value of £7.1 billion on a Retail Value RSP basis
in 2019 and has grown faster than the overall grocery market since its inception, according to PlanetRetail.
We believe it will continue to grow substantially in the mid-term, fuelled by consumers shifting to online
channels and at-home consumption, which have accelerated through the COVID-19 pandemic. We believe
our growth has been, and we expect our growth to continue to be in the medium term, ahead of the UK
online grocery market. We currently operate the second-largest online grocery platform in the United
Kingdom, according to Kantar, representing 18.2% of the market (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total
Grocery Absolute Sales) as of December 2019, which grew to 19.8% as of December 27, 2020 (on a 52week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales), representing a gain of 154 basis points and posting
the second-strongest share gain of any online grocery retailer since December 2019 and throughout the
COVID-19 pandemic. See "—Overview" for further detail.

The UK online grocery market is intensely competitive. We compete with traditional grocery retailers
that are active in the online grocery retail market, including Tesco.com, Sainsburys.co.uk, Waitrose.com
and Morrisons.com, as well as with new competitors in the online grocery market, including broad-reaching
e-commerce companies such as Amazon, which recently began offering online grocery sales in the United
Kingdom, including through its Morrisons@Amazon offering, and which expanded the rollout of its online
grocery service through Amazon Prime more broadly across the United Kingdom at the end of 2020, as
well as pure online players like Ocado, which has recently added Marks & Spencer food products to its
grocery offerings following the creation of a joint venture between Ocado and Marks & Spencer. In order
to retain our competitiveness in the evolving UK online grocery market, we continue to develop innovative
customer solutions, such as our Express Collection service which enables customers to place an order for

166


-----

collection within one hour while other grocers also explore rapid delivery offerings (e.g. Ocado Zoom,
Sainsbury's Chop Chop). Furthermore, we continue to invest in strategic partnerships that lead to
innovation and which we believe will drive further increases in our market share, such as our partnership
with Uber Eats, which provides express and last-mile delivery options for convenience groceries. See
"Business—Our Online Platform" and "Business—Our Tenants and Strategic Partners" for further detail.
We believe these broad-ranging online options, and in particular our in-store picking model, has bolstered,
and will continue to bolster, the performance of our online channel and our ability to adapt to shifting
consumer demands.

_Accounting Treatment of Properties Used in Our Business_

In accordance with IAS 16 (Property, Plant and Equipment), land and buildings are stated at cost less
accumulated depreciation and impairment losses except for certain items that were revalued to fair value
prior to January 1, 2004, the date of our transition to IFRS, which are measured on the basis of deemed
cost, being the revalued amount at the date of that revaluation. Items under construction are valued at cost
and not depreciated. Depreciation is charged from the date that the assets are available for use. Assets
acquired by way of a finance lease are stated at an amount equal to the lower of fair value and the present
value of the minimum lease payments at inception of the lease, less accumulated depreciation and
impairment losses. Following the adoption of IFRS 16, these amounts are classified as right-of-use assets.
When an item is disposed of or when no future economic benefits are expected to arise from its continued
use, any gain or loss arising on the derecognition of the asset is included in the income statement.

_Expanding Partnerships and Taking Advantage of Synergies_

Creating a platform of partnerships has been key to reaching new customers and consistently delivering
innovative customer propositions that draw shoppers to our stores, driving increased sales in our core
grocery retail business. We have commercialised our capabilities and years of learning derived from our
retail experience to partner with various service providers who can deliver access to, among other services,
new convenience and delivery channels, where we believe there are significant opportunities to serve our
customers in new and appealing ways. For example, since July 2020, we have been partnering with
UberEats in 100 of our stores to provide a new delivery option to our customers. Certain partnerships have
also allowed us to focus on our omni-channel proposition. For example, we are currently trialling an instore and click & collect concession with the DIY product retailer, B&Q, that expands our reach to customers
in the DIY and garden channel. Additionally, we have developed partnerships with general merchandise
retailers, that leverage their authority in certain categories and will attract customers to our stores. For
example, we have launched a trial with The Entertainer which will see them take over our offering in
children's toys. Partnerships across our various channels will continue to be an important focus for us as
we continue looking for new ways to reach existing and new customers and to capitalise on our customers'
growing desire for convenient lifestyles, whereby individuals seek to accomplish multiple missions at once.
See "Business—Our Tenants and Strategic Partners" for further detail.

In addition to rental income payable from EG Group to ASDA arising from EG Group's proposed roll out
of ASDA Food to Go outlets, we also anticipate synergies stemming from incremental uplift to ASDA's
wholesale margin from the roll out of the ASDA On the Move wholesale-convenience concept, which is
currently being trialled by EG Group at three of their sites. Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA for the 12 months
ended September 30, 2020 reflects an adjustment of £7.0 million based on the Shareholders' estimates of
the total potential forward-looking run-rate synergies that we expect to realise in the first 24 months from
the anticipated uplift to ASDA related to incremental wholesale margin from the roll out of the ASDA On
the Move wholesale-convenience concept by EG Group across its network.

**Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Financial Information**

The comparability of the Company's historical financial information is impacted by a number of factors.
This section discusses key factors that the Company believes have had a material effect on the
comparability of its results of operations and financial condition during the periods under review, as well as
those that are reasonably likely to have a material effect on its results of operations and financial condition
in the future.

_Seasonality of Our Results of Operations_

Our sales and cash flows are affected to a relatively limited extent by seasonal variations due to
consumers' shopping habits and, to a lesser extent, weather conditions. Family groups represent a
significant proportion of our customer base. As a result, our revenue has historically been comparatively
higher during the Christmas and Easter periods. In general, revenue shifts due to weather tend to be
relatively short-term, with impacts occurring within a given month, rather than across a quarter or a longer
period. From time to time, we may also experience reduced sales revenue if inclement or severe weather
reduces in-store footfall and impulse purchases, without concomitant offset by online sales. At the same
time, adverse weather conditions, such as snow or flooding, can increase customer demand for our online
offerings, although they can also adversely affect our ability to deliver products to customers. In this case,
however, increased demand for online offerings would not likely offset reduced sales revenue in stores
resulting from inclement weather, as online sales account for a comparatively small portion of our total
revenue (excluding petrol) (9.8% in the year ended December 31, 2019 and 13.9% in the 12 months ended
September 30, 2020). In general, our fixed costs, including labour expenses (other than related to seasonal
workers), real estate leases and SG&A expenses, are more evenly distributed over the year. Additionally,
our procurement and sourcing activities are also generally more evenly spread throughout the year, except
for a build-up in preparation for the Christmas season. While our financial calendar generally aligns with
our operational profile, we experience calendar effects when, for example, the number of trading days or
payroll periods in a given period varies from period to period or year to year or certain holidays fall in
different periods from year to year. As a result of the foregoing, comparisons of consecutive interim periods
may not be a good indication of our performance, and the calendar effects we experience may have an
impact on year-on-year comparisons of interim periods.

_ASDA Group Pension Scheme Buy-In_

During the year ended December 31, 2019, the trustees of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme entered
into an agreement for a bulk annuity insurance buy-in of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme with Rothesay
Life. This agreement secures the benefits of members and the transaction is expected to de-risk and
simplify the Company's balance sheet, is entered into with Rothesay Life, and insures the long-term
benefits of approximately 12,300 members of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme. The buy-in transaction,
which was enabled by a one-off final contribution by ASDA of £0.7 billion and a loan facility made available
by the ASDA Group Pension Scheme's sponsor, ASL (see below), has taken place ahead of a full schemebuy-out that is expected to take place in the first half of 2021. The transaction removes future ASDA Group
Pension Scheme liabilities from the ASDA and Walmart balance sheets, simplifying the business. The
agreed buy-out will also mean ASDA Group Pension Scheme members will receive an individual annuity
policy, issued by Rothesay Life, which will pay members' pension benefits in full. See note 1 ("Accounting
_policies") and note 17 ("Employee benefits") of the 2019 Financial Statements._

At the time of the buy-in, it was agreed that certain of the assets of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme
did not meet the criteria for transfer to Rothesay Life pursuant to the buy-in transaction and were retained
by the ASDA Group Pension Scheme (the "Illiquid Assets"). The sponsor of the scheme, ASL, agreed to
make a loan facility available to the trustees in an aggregate principal amount of £467.0 million with the
principal purpose of providing liquidity to the ASDA Group Pension Scheme to allow the trustees to pay
the premium in full under the buy-in policy with Rothesay Life, and also to provide prudent reserves that
are available to fund the operation of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme up to completion of the buy-out
and eventual winding-up (the "Pension Scheme Expenses"). The loan facility was set up on arm's-length
terms, including in relation to interest. From completion of the buy-in transaction any proceeds realised in
respect of the Illiquid Assets are required to be applied by the trustees to fund interest and principal
payments under the loan facility, to the extent such proceeds are not required to be retained to maintain
prudent reserves with respect to the Pension Scheme Expenses. Pursuant to arrangements agreed in
connection with the Acquisition Agreement, payments received by ASL under the loan facility that are
attributable to the Illiquid Assets are required to be paid to Walmart. Accordingly, the risk and reward of
the performance of the Illiquid Assets has effectively been transferred to Walmart. To the extent that
realisations from the Illiquid Assets are insufficient to cover interest and principal payments owing to ASL

168


-----

under the loan facility, ASL is obliged under a separate agreement to provide sufficient funding to the ASDA
Group Pension Scheme to enable the trustees to fund such shortfall. As the amount of such funding
provided by ASL to the ASDA Group Pension Scheme would be applied to repay the loan facility owing to
ASL, the combined effect of such transactions would have no net impact on ASL. ASL reached an
agreement with the trustees of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme to make a cash contribution of £214.6
million to the ASDA Group Pension Scheme on December 30, 2020. Such amount was applied to repay
amounts due to ASL under the loan facility on the same day.

_IFRS 16 (Leases)_

With respect to the 2019 Financial Statements, the Company applied the new IFRS 16 (Leases)
accounting standard, effective from January 1, 2019, using the modified retrospective approach, as defined
by the IFRS 16 accounting standard. The cumulative effects of applying this new accounting standard were
therefore recognised as an adjustment to retained earnings as of January 1, 2019 (the date of initial
application), while comparative figures were not restated. Additionally, previous lease-related balances
including operating lease prepayments, onerous lease provisions and straight-line rent accruals have been
derecognised as part of the Company's adoption of IFRS 16. The 2017 Financial Statements and the 2018
Financial Statements have not been restated for the adoption of IFRS 16 and thus cannot be directly
compared to the 2019 Financial Statements, and the Company has not otherwise restated comparative
amounts as of and for the years ended December 31, 2017 or 2018. IFRS 16 eliminates the classification
of leases as either operating leases or finance leases for lessees and introduces a single lessee accounting
model with some exemptions for short-term and low-value leases. The lessee recognises a right-of-use
asset representing its right to use the underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to
make lease payments. The effect of applying IFRS 16 is to align the presentation of leases more closely
to that of owned assets, rent expense is no longer deducted in arriving at operating profit or EBITDA and
instead profit before tax includes an interest charge on the unwinding of the lease liability and a
depreciation charge on the right of use asset.

_Impact on lessor accounting_

IFRS 16 does not change substantially how a lessor accounts for leases. Under IFRS 16, a lessor
continues to classify leases as either finance leases or operating leases and account for those two types
of leases differently. Where the Company is an intermediate lessor, the classification under IFRS 16 is
required to be made with reference to the right-of-use asset that arises under the head lease. On transition
to IFRS 16, there has been no change to how leases where the Company is a head or intermediate lessor
are accounted for.

_Practical expedients and policy choices_

The Company has applied IFRS 16 using the modified retrospective approach which:

  - requires the Company to recognise the cumulative effect of initially applying IFRS 16 as an
adjustment to the opening balance of retained earnings at the date of initial application; and

  - does not permit restatement of comparatives, which continue to be presented under IAS 17 and
IFRIC 4.

IFRS 16 allows for certain transition and accounting policy options for companies taking the modified
retrospective approach. The Company has applied the following practical expedients at January 1, 2019,
but no others:

  - to rely on the previous identification of a lease (as provided by IAS 17 or IFRIC 4) for all contracts
that existed on January 1, 2019; and

  - to exclude initial direct costs other than those arising on leases with lease buy-out costs from
lease buy-outs (see note 11 ("Intangible Assets") of the 2019 Financial Statements) from the
measurement of the right-of-use asset on January 1, 2019.

With respect to all leases previously classified as operating under IAS 17, the Company has elected to
measure right-of-use assets recognised on January 1, 2019 at an amount equal to the lease liability,
adjusted by the amount of any prepaid or accrued lease payments relating to that lease recognised in the
balance sheet immediately before January 1, 2019.

169


-----

The Company has taken the following ongoing policy choices from January 1, 2019:

  - to account for any lease with a term of less than 12 months as a short-term lease, recognising
cost in the income on a straight line basis over the lease term and not recognising a right-of-use
asset and lease liability at the contract date;

  - to apply the IFRS 16 low value asset exemption threshold based on the value of the asset when
new, on an individual asset basis if deemed appropriate;

  - to apply a materiality threshold to all leases on and post transition: costs relating to leases with
total undiscounted cash flows over the life of the lease below a documented threshold will be
expensed as incurred and no right-of-use asset or lease liability will be recognised at the contract
date; and

  - to elect to combine lease and non-lease components prospectively after January 1, 2019: this
applies to all leases with the exception of IT and printer leases.

For more information, see note 1 ("Accounting Policies") of the 2019 Financial Statements.

_Financial impact of adoption_

In the year ended December 31, 2019, the overall impact of adoption of IFRS 16 on the Company's
consolidated income statement was a decrease in profit before tax of £21.3 million, resulting in a decrease
in operating costs of £31.4 million and an increase in finance costs of £52.7 million. In addition, right of use
assets of £2,263.9 million and additional lease liabilities of £1,979.4 million were recognised on the
Company's consolidated balance sheet as of January 1, 2019.

_The Transactions_

Historically, the ASDA Group has had little external indebtedness. On October 2, 2020, the
Shareholders announced they had reached an agreement with Walmart to acquire the Company pursuant
to the Acquisition Agreement. We estimate that, following the Transactions, the Restricted Group will have
total third-party debt of approximately £4,721.0 million (of which £750 million relates to the Forecourt Assets
Disposal Bridge, which is expected to be repaid in full during the course of 2021). In addition, we estimate
that the disposals of the Warehouse Assets by the Distribution Asset Disposal Bridge Facility Borrower or
Propco 2, following the CMA Clearance Date and the consummation of the Post-Completion Disposals,
may trigger a gain upon disposal and result in a net tax liability for ASDA of approximately £40 million. See
"The Transactions" and "Capitalisation." Accordingly, our financial condition and results of operations
following the Transactions will be impacted by interest costs related to this debt and may differ from the
historical financial condition and results of operations presented in this discussion as a result of the
Transactions.

_Operating costs_

Operating costs include all income (of which the most significant are rental income and income from
recycling of certain categories of waste) and costs, other than revenue, finance income, finance costs
and tax. The largest components of this are cost of goods sold (net of supplier rebates), employment

tax adjustment to prior periods, as well as deferred taxation, including deferred taxation arising from the
origination and reversal of temporary differences, from changes in tax rates and laws, and from previously
unrecognised tax losses, tax credits or any temporary differences in prior periods.
