_Results of operations for the nine-month period ended September 30, 2020 as compared to the nine-_
_month period ended September 30, 2019_

Revenue

Revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 was £16,589.4 million, a decrease of £183.6
million, or 1.1%, compared to £16,773.0 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This
decrease was primarily due to COVID-19-driven impacts. Petrol sales decreased particularly through the
periods of lockdown when there was decreased travel by car. Clothing sales also decreased as consumer
shopping habits changed in response to COVID-19. These reductions were partially offset by increases in
food sales, particularly in edible grocery and fresh food, which were also COVID-19-driven, both due to
consumer stock up behaviour ahead of lockdown and due to food spending shifting away from restaurants
and takeaways.

Operating costs

Operating costs for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 were £16,098.3 million, a decrease of
£290.5 million, or 1.8%, compared to £16,388.8 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019.
This decrease was primarily due to lower cost of goods sold, driven by decreased petrol and clothing sales,
lower business rates as a result of government relief following COVID-19 and lower impairment charges
following the impairment of two home shopping centres in the period ended September 30, 2019. There
was also a reduction in the expense of share options in the period, primarily driven by lower increases in
the Walmart share price. These decreases in operating costs were partially offset by higher cost of goods
sold, due to increased food sales and increased employment costs due to COVID-19, including paying
colleagues that needed to self-isolate and the payment of an additional thank you payment to colleagues.
Food cost of sales was also adversely impacted by the mix of products sold, with an overall shift to lower

173


-----

margin products. There were also increased operating costs as a result of the increase in online sales
participation, which incurs more costs for the picking and delivery of orders.

Finance income

Finance income for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 was £38.5 million, a decrease of £2.8
million, or 6.8%, compared to £41.3 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. The decrease
in interest receivable on loans was primarily due to decreased bank interest receivable and was partially
offset by increased interest receivable on amounts owed from group undertakings.

Finance costs

Finance costs for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 were £49.0 million, a decrease of £18.6
million, or 27.5%, compared to £67.6 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease
was primarily due to reduced net interest cost on the defined benefit pension scheme as a result of the buy
in of the ASDA Group pension scheme. Following the buy in there is no longer an additional minimum
funding liability and therefore no interest charge on this liability.

Income tax expense

Income tax expense for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 amounted to £83.4 million, an
increase of £40.3 million, or 93.5%, compared to £43.1 million in the nine months ended September 30,
2019. This increase was primarily due to increased profit before tax and decreased available tax relief
surrendered from elsewhere in the ASDA Group: in the nine months ended September 30, 2020 £24 million
less in losses were surrendered to the ASDA Group than in the nine months ended September 30, 2019.

Cash flow hedges reclassification during the period to income statement

Cash flow hedges reclassification during the period to income statement for the nine months ended
September 30, 2020 amounted to a loss of £8.0 million, a change of £31.6 million, or 79.8%, compared to
a loss of £39.6 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This change was primarily due to
fluctuations in the USD/GBP exchange rate between entering into forward contracts to purchase U.S.
dollars and the settling of those forward contracts that occurred in the relevant period: losses were caused
by the GBP strengthening versus the USD over the period of forward contracts, resulting in the contracts
being "out of the money." The reduced loss in the nine months ended September 30, 2020 is a result of
the GBP strengthening less versus the USD over the average forward contract life in the nine months
ended September 30, 2020 as compared to the nine months ended September 30, 2019. Forward contracts
have historically been used by the ASDA Group to hedge purchases against movements in foreign
currency: these are mainly forward purchases of USD in GBP that upon settlement are used to pay for
imported non-food goods for resale. These are effective hedges, therefore any gain or loss on the forward
contracts is accounted for directly in equity and the cost of sale of the goods for resale is recorded at the
hedged forward FX rate in the income statement.

Cash flow hedges net (loss)/gain during the period of the not-yet-matured contracts

Cash flow hedges net gain during the period of the not-yet-matured contracts for the nine months ended
September 30, 2020 amounted to a net gain of £18.1 million, a decrease of £16.3 million, or 47.4%,
compared to a net gain of £34.4 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This decrease was
primarily due to fluctuations in the USD/GBP exchange rate between entering into forward contracts to
purchase U.S. dollars in each financial year and the value of those contracts not settled at the period end
based on the exchange rate at the period end.

Tax on cash flow hedges recognised directly in other comprehensive income

Tax on cash flow hedges recognised directly in other comprehensive income for the nine months ended
September 30, 2020 was an expense of £1.7 million, a change of £3.2 million, compared to a credit of £1.5
million in the nine months ended September 30, 2019. This change was primarily due to the tax impact of
cash flow hedges changing from a net loss in 2019 to a net gain in 2020 as described above.

Other comprehensive (expense)/income for the period

Other comprehensive expense for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 amounted to £75.2
million, an increase of £30.5 million, compared to an expense of £44.7 million in the nine months ended
September 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to an increase in net expense items not to be
reclassified to profit or loss in subsequent periods following the defined pension buy in transaction and was
partially offset by items to be reclassified to profit or loss in subsequent periods as a result of cash flow
hedges, as described above, changing from a net expense to a net credit.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

The Company's liquidity needs have historically been met primarily by cash flows generated from
operations. In recent years, the Company's cash-generative business, due to the nature of the grocery
industry, together with the Company's relatively low capital expenditure, has driven cash flow generation,
including comparatively high unlevered free cash flow.

Our principal source of liquidity on an ongoing basis is expected to be our operating cash flows and
borrowings under our Revolving Credit Facilities. Our ability to generate cash depends on our future
operating performance, which, in turn, depends to some extent on general economic, financial, industry
and other factors, many of which are beyond our control. See "Risk Factors."

Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operations, together with available borrowings
under our Revolving Credit Facilities, will be adequate to meet our anticipated working capital and general
corporate needs for the next 12 months, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient
cash flows from operating activities or that future debt financing will be available to us in an amount
sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes offered hereby, or to fund our other
liquidity needs. The availability of our Revolving Credit Facilities is dependent upon certain conditions,
including compliance with a springing maintenance covenant as described further under "Description of
_Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement."_

_Revolving Credit Facilities_

As part of the Transactions, the Group entered into the Senior Facilities Agreement which provides for
the Senior Facilities, including the Revolving Credit Facilities. The Group expects to draw under the
Revolving Credit Facilities upon the completion of the Offering.

The Senior Facilities Agreement provides for multi-currency senior secured revolving credit facilities in
an aggregate amount equal to £690.0 million. The Revolving Credit Facilities may be utilised by any Original
Revolving Facility Borrower or Additional Revolving Facility Borrower (subject to certain exceptions) under
the Senior Facilities Agreement. Pursuant to the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement, a Lender may
also provide Letters of Credit, Fronted Ancillary Facilities or Ancillary Facilities (in each case as defined in
the Senior Facilities Agreement) on a bilateral basis in place of all or part of its Revolving Facility
Commitment.

Pursuant to the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement, loans made under the Revolving Credit
Facilities may be borrowed, repaid and re-borrowed at any time. Such loans will be available to be used

for, amongst other purposes, general corporate and working capital purposes of the Group (as defined in
the Senior Facilities Agreement) and, without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing, to fund certain
permitted acquisitions, capital expenditure, certain fees and other amounts payable in connection with the
Transaction (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) and to backstop existing ancillary facilities,
letters of credit and/or hedging arrangements of the Target Group (if applicable) and financing or
refinancing any other transactions contemplated in connection with the Acquisition (each as defined under
the Senior Facilities Agreement).

The Group will be subject to certain customary affirmative, negative and incurrence covenants under

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Financial Risk Overview**

_Overview_

In the ordinary course of the Company's business, it is exposed to a variety of market risks arising in
relation to its financial assets and liabilities, including credit risk, interest rate risk, liquidity risk, foreign
currency risk and capital risk. The Company has a risk management programme in place through which
it seeks to mitigate the adverse effects of these market risks. Following consummation of the
Transactions, we may hedge interest and exchange rate exposure. We do not enter into financial
instruments for trading or speculative purposes.

_Credit risk_

We believe there is no significant credit risk within the Company. The maximum credit risk exposure
relating to financial assets is included in their carrying value as at the balance sheet date. See note 13
("Trade and other receivables") of the Company's 2019 Financial Statements for further information on
trade receivables and details of recoverability.

The Company has established procedures to minimise the risk of default in relation to trade receivables
including detailed credit checks undertaken before a customer is accepted. Historically, these procedures
have proven effective in minimising the level of impaired and past due receivables. Surplus cash is placed
on short-term deposit with various global financial institutions. This is managed by the Company's treasury
function, which actively monitors the market in order to identify the best terms of deposit. Deposit limits
and approved financial institutions have historically been dictated by the investment policy of the ultimate
parent company. Intercompany receivables have been considered in relation to the expected credit losses

181


-----

model under IFRS 9 (Financial Instruments) and no impairment is required.

_Interest rate risk_

The Company's short-term borrowings have historically all been held with entities which are part of the
Walmart Inc. group and have been at fixed rates of interest. Amounts owed to fellow subsidiaries (see
note 24 ("Related Parties") of the Company's 2019 Financial Statements) accrue interest at a rate of
5.448% to 6% in the year ended December 31, 2019 (which was also the case during the years ended
December 31, 2017 and 2018). As interest rates have been fixed on all of the Company's historical debt,
interest rate movements would not have an impact on profitability, cash flow or equity in prior periods.

Following the Transactions and subject to the assumptions set forth under "Use of Proceeds," our
indebtedness and other debt arrangements will be primarily composed of the Senior Facilities, including
the Revolving Credit Facilities, the Forecourt Disposal Bridge Facility and the Notes (all of which, other
than the Notes, will bear a floating interest rate based on EURIBOR or LIBOR, as applicable).

_Liquidity risk_

The Company's Treasury function ensures that the Company continues to have sufficient funding by
monitoring rolling forecasts of the Company's cash flows. The Company's objective is to maintain a
balance between continuity of funding and flexibility through the use of operating cash flows and
intercompany balances. At December 31, 2019, the Company had no external borrowings, other than
lease liabilities.

At December 31, 2019, the Company held cash of £1,929.3 million (as compared to £2,916.1 million
at December 31, 2018 and £2,171.7 million at December 31, 2017), utilised along with overdrafts where
necessary, to secure short-term flexibility. At December 31, 2019, the Company had committed overdraft
facilities of £30.0 million (as compared to £30.0 million at December 31, 2018 and £30.0 million of
uncommitted overdraft facilities at December 31, 2017), standby credit facilities, including bonds of £96.7
million (as compared to £112.1 million at December 31, 2018 and £112.9 million at December 31, 2017),
and committed lines of credit facilities of £30.0 million (as compared to £125.0 million at December 31,
2018 and uncommitted lines of credit facilities £125.0 million at December 31, 2017). The Company also
has historically had access to an intercompany financing facility which gives ASDA the ability to borrow
from other Walmart entities and which is available to other subsidiaries of Walmart, the limit of which
depends on the usage by fellow subsidiaries. This intercompany financing facility will be terminated upon
the completion of the Acquisition.

_Foreign currency risk_

The Company purchases goods and services denominated in currencies other than pounds sterling.
Cash flows can be affected by movements in exchange rates, primarily US dollars and euro. Some
purchases in US dollars are managed through the use of forward contracts.

The Company implements hedge accounting and had forward currency hedging contracts outstanding
at December 31, 2019, designated as hedges of expected future purchases from suppliers in US dollars.
The forward currency contracts are being used to hedge the foreign currency risk of the future purchases.
The terms of the forward currency hedging contracts have been negotiated to match the terms of the
commitments and none exceed a period of more than 12 months after December 31, 2019. Amounts
recognised in other comprehensive income are transferred to the income statement when the hedged
transaction affects profit or loss.

The cash flow hedges of the expected future purchases were assessed to be highly effective and as
at December 31, 2019, a net unrealised loss of £11.8 million (as compared to a net unrealised gain of
£29.6 million as at December 31, 2018 and a net unrealised loss of £21.0 million as at December 31,
2017) was included in the hedge reserve in respect of hedging contracts. The net loss recognised in other
comprehensive income during the year in respect of these hedging contracts was £41.4 million (as
compared to a net gain of £50.6 million as at December 31, 2018 and a net loss of £57.8 million as at
December 31, 2017). This consists of £38.0 million of gains reclassified to the income statement during
the year (as compared to £24.2 million of losses as at December 31, 2018 and £35.9 million of gains as
at December 31, 2017), a £12.9 million loss on not-yet-matured contracts during the year (as compared
to a £38.3 million gain as at December 31, 2018 and a £34.4 million loss as at December 31, 2017) and
a £9.5 million taxation credit (as compared to a £11.9 million charge as at December 31, 2018 and £12.5
million credit as at December 31, 2017).

182


-----

Under the Company's hedging policy, the only items for which forward currency contracts are in place
are forecast purchases of goods for resale. The Company hedges up to 95% of forecast cash flows. Gains
and losses attributable to forward contracts are transferred to cost of inventories recognised as an
expense within the income statement upon maturity of the forward contract. Forward contracts entered
into which are not in line with forecast cash flows would be the principal source of hedge ineffectiveness.
No instances of this occurred during the year ended December 31, 2019 (which was also the case during
the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2018), therefore amounts recognised in the income statement
in relation to ineffective hedges were nil (which was also the case during the year ended December 31,
2018).

The Facility B will be denominated in euro and the Senior Secured Notes, Senior Notes, Facility A and
the Forecourt Assets Disposal Bridge Facility will be denominated in pounds sterling, and changes in
foreign exchange rates will therefore give rise to foreign exchange exposure with respect to the Facility
B.

As the Company manages more than half of its foreign currency exposure through the use of forward
currency contracts, changes in exchange rates are not expected to have a significant impact on shortterm profitability or cash flow. It is anticipated that a 5% movement in the US dollar/pounds sterling
exchange rate, which represents management's assessment of a reasonably possible change, would give
rise to a movement in the cash flow hedge reserve of £29.7 million (as compared to a movement of £36.6
million during the year ended December 31, 2018 and £42.1 million during the year ended December 31,
2017).

_Capital risk_

The Company is subject to the risk that its capital structure will not be sufficient to support the growth
of its business. In order to maintain or adjust the capital structure, the Company has historically had the
option to adjust the amount of intercompany loans payable or receivable to and from the Walmart Inc.
group of companies. There were no changes to the Company's approach to capital management during
the year ended December 31, 2019. Full details of the Company's approach to capital management and
how the Company defines capital is provided in the Strategic Report that is included in the 2019 Financial
Statements. Full details of the amount of intercompany loans payable or receivable to and from the
Walmart Inc. group of companies are disclosed in note 24 ("Related Parties") of the Company's 2019
Financial Statements.

**Overview**

The retail sector in the United Kingdom, across all sales channels, was estimated by Euromonitor in the
Retailing 2020 edition to have had sales of approximately £384.4 billion in 2019 (based on a Retail Value
Retail Sales Price basis excluding sales tax ("Retail Value **RSP") in current value terms) and to have grown**
at a CAGR of 2.2% between 2007 and 2019. According to Euromonitor, grocery retail – referring to the
sum of hypermarkets and supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retail, and food and
drink e-commerce – is the single largest category of retail spending in the United Kingdom and in 2019 it
represented £163.1 billion of Retail Value RSP (comprising approximately 42% of total retail sales). In the
past twelve years, grocery retail in the United Kingdom has not experienced negative year-on-year ("YoY")
growth, despite macroeconomic uncertainties and periods of food deflation measured by the consumer
price index ("CPI"), according to the OECD.

We operate in the retail market, offering a wide range of both food and non-food products and services
from our supercentres, superstores, supermarkets and ASDA Living stores, as well as through various
online platforms. The origins of our business are in the UK grocery retail market and, while our business
has grown and diversified into other markets including clothing retail and general merchandise retail, we
remain focused on offering high-quality, value-based grocery retail options to our customers.

Within the UK grocery retail market, we hold the third-largest market share, representing 12.2% of total
expenditure by households in the United Kingdom on specific grocery sectors (fresh & chilled, ambient,
frozen, alcohol, household, toiletries and healthcare) ("Total Grocery Absolute Sales"), calculated on a
52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar.

While the overall UK grocery retail market has in recent years remained stable in many respects, market
channels and customer habits have been changing. Customer preference has shifted away from larger,
out-of-town formats towards smaller, proximity formats, with customers prioritising convenience and
shopping habits shifting towards smaller basket sizes coupled with increased frequency of purchases. The
industry has also seen the rapid growth of discounters (mainly represented by Aldi and Lidl) that compete
through differentiation on price coupled with a more limited selection of own-brand products. In addition to
these changes within the physical store channels, the UK grocery retail market has also seen an increasing
shift away from physical stores towards online purchasing. More recently, according to Kantar, COVID-19
has accelerated the shifts towards these online and convenience formats since lockdown measures were
first introduced in the United Kingdom earlier this year, as shown in the chart below. Underlying all of these
trends is a shift towards at-home food and drink consumption away from OOH food and drink consumption,
which has led to an 12.3% YoY increase in the value of the overall UK grocery retail market on a Total
Grocery Absolute Sales basis for the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020. For more information, see "—
_UK Grocery Retail Key Trends."_

(Source: Kantar Worldpanel, based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a year-to-date basis ended December 27, 2020.)

**UK Grocery Retail Market Competitive Landscape**

The following chart illustrates the UK grocery market breakdown by channel on a Retail Value RSP
basis and its development between 2007 and 2019, as well as the CAGRs between the years 2007 and
2014, 2014 and 2019, and 2007 and 2019.

(Source: Euromonitor Retailing 2020 Edition. Note: The UK grocery retail market refers to the sum of channels including
hypermarkets and supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retail, and food and drink e-commerce.)

Grocery retail sales in the United Kingdom are made via multiple channels, including hypermarkets,
supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retailers and online. We currently operate in the
hypermarket, supermarket and online channels.

Hypermarkets are larger-format retail stores, frequently located on out-of-town sites or as anchor stores
in a shopping centres, with a primary focus on selling food, beverages, tobacco and other groceries while
offering a wide variety of non-grocery products, such as general merchandise and clothing. Supermarkets
are smaller-scale retail stores that offer a wide variety of food, beverages and household products.
Hypermarket formats are offered by the traditional grocers, while supermarket stores are offered by the
Co-op, Waitrose and M&S, in addition to the traditional grocers. Based on Euromonitor data, the sum of
hypermarket and supermarket channels constitute the largest share by Retail Value RSP of the UK grocery
retail market, representing 61.1% of grocery Retail Value RSP in 2019. However, in the last five calendar
years, growth for the sum of these two channels has declined, with a combined CAGR of -0.4% between
2014 and 2019, according to Euromonitor.

In contrast, over the past fifteen years convenience stores such as Tesco Express, Sainsbury's Local,
Co-op On the Go, Little Waitrose and M&S Simply Food, have gained popularity. In 2019, they represented
19.0% of Retail Value RSP and are the second-largest channel in the grocery retail market, according to
Euromonitor.

The 2007-2009 global financial crisis and the resulting weakened customer sentiment thereafter helped
discounters (mainly represented by Aldi and Lidl) to gain a strong foothold in the UK grocery retail market.
Between 2007 and 2014, discounters gained considerable scale and market share due to new store
openings and increased footfall resulting primarily from product offerings targeted at increasingly priceconscious customers. According to Euromonitor, the discounters channel represented 11.4% of the total
grocery retail market on a Retail Value RSP basis in 2019. For more information see "— UK Grocery Retail
_Key Trends."_

The UK grocery retail market has seen an increasing shift away from physical stores to online
purchasing, with online grocery sales having grown significantly faster than those of physical stores in
recent years. According to Euromonitor, in 2019 the online channel (food & drink e-commerce) comprised
5.1% of the UK grocery retail market. The online channel, which has also reported strong Retail Value RSP

Following the recent outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, this growth has been bolstered as customers
increasingly turn to online groceries in order to maintain social distance, a trend which may result in a
sustained change in preferences going forward.

On the basis of Total Grocery Absolute Sales for the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020, we are the
third-largest player in the UK grocery retail market with a 12.2% market share, according to Kantar. Other

**UK Grocery Retail Key Trends**

The UK grocery retail market has been undergoing a fundamental shift in recent years, driven by
changing customer lifestyles, technological changes, evolving competitive dynamics and socio-economic
factors. These trends have led to a shift towards discounters, convenience stores and online channels,
amongst other changes.

We believe there are five key trends that may shape the future of the UK grocery retail market: the
increased focus on value-based propositions and the growth of the discounters, the growth of the online
channel, the shift to convenience, the redefinition of service expectations and the increased demands for
social responsibility.

**_Increased focus on Value-Based Propositions and Growth of the Discounters_**

Since the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, customers have become increasingly price sensitive. Such
customers, however, still desire high-quality offerings. In response, discounters developed a range of valuebased propositions focused on delivering high quality at low prices, which appeal to this growing number
of UK shoppers who seek a good 'value'. These propositions have helped discounters to achieve a strong
presence in the UK grocery retail market. For example, discounters Aldi and Lidl have increased their
combined market share (on a Total Grocery Absolute Sales basis) from 3.7% in the calendar year 2007 to
12.1% in the calendar year 2019, according to Kantar and as reflected in the following chart.

(Source: Kantar.)

From 2013 to 2019, discounters gained considerable scale and market share as a result of new store
openings and continued price consciousness from customers. According to Euromonitor and relevant
public reporting, discounters' store count grew from approximately 1,118 in 2013 to approximately 1,664 in
2019, as set forth in the following chart.

(Source: Euromonitor: Retailing 2020 edition (with the exception of the 2019 numbers, which are taken from competitor public
disclosure).)

As discounters have increased their store counts, they have won market share from other market
players.

193


-----

According to Kantar, as of December 27, 2020, we had significant market share in the same geographic
areas where discounters already commanded a relatively high market share - the North of England,
Scotland and Wales - on a Total Grocery Absolute Sales basis. We believe that, as discounters seek to
increase their market share through expansion in new areas, they are likely to consider expanding into new
regional markets - particularly in London, South of England and East of England - where we have a lower
market share, a trend that we believe is supported by the information about market share by geography
set forth in the following chart. We also believe the majority of ASDA's stores have discounters in their
catchment area.

(Source: Kantar as of December 27, 2020.)

**_Growth of Online Channel_**

ASDA, along with Tesco, Sainsbury's, Morrisons and Waitrose, offer groceries and non-food items for
purchase and delivery online alongside "Click & Collect" services for purchases made through our
websites. Pure online players, such as Ocado and Amazon Fresh, also compete in the UK online grocery
market.

The strong growth of online grocery sales in the United Kingdom is supported by multiple drivers,
including:

  - Increasing population of tech-aware customers with a higher propensity to buy online;

  - Higher internet penetration (driven by increased usage of mobile and faster connections)
combined with an increasing propensity to use the internet to buy online;

  - Technological advances significantly improving the online proposition for customers (such as better
interfaces, mobile apps, convenient digital wallets and payment systems);

194


-----

  - Improving product offerings as technology improves and competition increases (for example,
greater availability of products online compared to in-store); and

  - Improving delivery options as density of deliveries improves (resulting in cheaper, faster deliveries
and improved availability of more predictable, flexible and diverse delivery timeslots).

Growth in online grocery has been accelerated by the onset of COVID-19 as customers have
increasingly prioritised factors such as social distancing and convenience and government restrictions have
encouraged customers to find ways to remain at home.

**_Shift to Convenience_**

Another significant customer trend shaping the UK grocery retail market is customers' increasing
prioritisation of convenience. As part of that, there is an increasing preference amongst customers for more
frequent but smaller shopping trips, with numerous top-ups through the course of the week at smaller, more
conveniently located stores. This trend can be partly explained by a preference for reduced food waste in
light of growing environmental concerns, smaller households, less pre-planned lifestyles and a growing
preference in general for convenience. This trend has also been compounded by the COVID-19 pandemic
as shoppers increasingly seek conveniently located stores in order to avoid longer travel for health and
safety reasons and comply with government restrictions put in place since the outbreak of the pandemic.

**_Redefined Service Expectations_**

Increasing digitalisation and evolving customer dynamics have shaped an increasingly fast-paced
market. Customers are now seeking a transparent and frictionless experience to improve and expedite
their grocery retail experience. This is reflected in the increased usage of self-checkout, "Scan & Go," "Click
& Collect" and online services as customers opt to use these facilities to tailor and improve their shopping
experiences. In line with the growing desire for convenience and efficient shopping experiences, there is
increasing demand for combined and differentiated service offerings in the grocery retail market, which
allow customers to fulfil multiple needs in one convenient location such as parcel collection and drop-off,
pharmacy services and selections of household items, all in addition to traditional grocery retail offerings.
Grocery retailers, like ourselves, have responded with increased service offerings such as "toyou," which
takes advantage of customers' growing online shopping habits to create a service that allows customers to
return or collect online purchases while on a regular trip to a brick-and-mortar grocery retailer.

**_Increased Demand for Social Responsibility_**

Dedication to social responsibility is increasingly relevant to customers, particularly for Gen Z and
Millennial customers, and a commitment to social responsibility has become a necessary factor if retailers
want to meet customers' expectations. There is a growing share of customers who have concerns about
animal welfare, environmental sustainability and ethical sourcing, and who view their purchasing decision
as a lifestyle statement. In line with these concerns, customers are increasingly demanding traceability and
information about production methods, driving the popularity of fair trade and organic products that can
meet these needs. In response, retailers are adapting their business models in order to meet customers'
demand.

We are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom and the second-largest grocery retailer
in the North of England, Scotland and Wales (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a
52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). We operate a significant store estate of 614
stores (excluding standalone PFSs) that are geographically diversified across the United Kingdom. We
also have the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom (in terms of Total Grocery
Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar). The graph below

We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market that is underpinned by
favourable macroeconomic factors including GDP, population, consumer confidence and household
expenditure on food and beverages and which has historically demonstrated resilient performance through
economic fluctuations. Groceries are a necessary and regular consumer expenditure, which we believe
generally allows the grocery retail market to weather economic downturns better than certain other retail
markets. For example, the UK grocery retail market demonstrated its two strongest periods of growth in
recent history during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and during the COVID-19 pandemic. See also
"Industry."

One of the key capabilities that drives our performance is our differentiated operating model, which is
in turn centred around our omni-channel offer (with multiple fulfilment options), our commitment to "Every
Day Low Price" and our wholly-owned supplier, IPL, which enables us to take a vertically-integrated
approach to procurement and which we believe gives us a competitive advantage in food sourcing. Other
key capabilities that drive our performance include our profitable and well-established George Clothing and
George Home offers, our well-developed own-brand grocery offers and our team of flexible and engaged
colleagues. Historically, we have benefited from the support of Walmart, our former parent company. We

**HISTORY**

Headquartered in Leeds, we are an omni-channel retailer across England, Scotland, Wales and
Northern Ireland. We have built our business on listening to our diverse range of customers, offering what
they need at the best value and bringing innovation to the UK market.

We were founded in 1965 through the merger of the Asquith family grocery business with the Associated
Dairies company in Yorkshire. Our name is derived from this historic merger, combining "Asquith" and
"Dairies" to form "ASDA."

Founded in the North of England, we have a rich history, heritage and culture. The Asquith family has
deep ties to the grocery business, W.R. Asquith having run a butchers shop in Knottingly, West Yorkshire,
which eventually expanded to seven shops. W.R. Asquith's sons, Peter and Fred, went on to create the
United Kingdom's first self-service supermarket in Castleford, introducing food discounting to the UK
grocery market, and eventually co-founded ASDA. In parallel to the growth of the Asquith family business,
a group of West Riding dairy farmers joined forces, eventually becoming Associated Dairies & Farm Stores
Limited led by Arthur Stockdale. Arthur's son, Sir Noel Stockdale, went on to co-found ASDA with Peter
and Fred Asquith.

In 1965, we acquired GEM, a major U.S. discount retailer operating in the United Kingdom. With the
addition of general merchandise to the former GEM stores, we introduced the superstore to the UK market,
a landmark event in the development of UK retailing. To complement this offer, Peter Asquith also
introduced the first discounted petrol filling station.

By 1970, we operated over 30 stores and were poised to expand beyond our original home in the North
of England. Throughout the 1970s, we grew our presence in the South of England, opening stores in
Newport, Plymouth and Gosport. In 1977, we launched our "ASDA Price" TV adverts, featuring the "pocket

200


-----

tap" which came to be the official sign language for ASDA. By the end of the 1970s, we were operating
over 80 stores and opened our 100th store in 1981.

Throughout the 1980s, we focused on expanding our distribution capabilities, opening seven new
distribution centres strategically located throughout the United Kingdom by 1985. In 1987, our flagship
Watford store opened, another landmark in UK retailing, and featured the longest-ever checkout bank at
the time, with 45 checkouts. In 1988, we opened our headquarters in Leeds, with Prime Minister Margaret
Thatcher overseeing the opening ceremonies. In 1989, George Davies was asked to produce a line of
clothing for us that was high-quality, high-value and had its own identity: the pioneering George brand was
born.

In the 1990s, we developed the ASDA Way of Working, an innovative framework for a new
organisational structure that focuses on our stores and promotes colleague involvement, which set the
stage for the ASDA culture of today. In 1996, we opened our first ASDA Pharmacy location in Harrogate,
North Yorkshire and launched our "Tickled Pink" campaign to raise money for the fight against breast
cancer, a partnership that continues to this day. In 1998, we began our online retail operations with a
dedicated depot in Croydon.

In 1999, we joined the Walmart family, becoming part of the world's largest retailer. Throughout the
early 2000s, we continued to grow and innovate, expanding our online and Click & Collect offers, opening
our first ASDA Living store and our first Eco Store, winning awards for the value we offer customers as well
as for the positive environment we create for colleagues, launching our Free From and Extra Special offers,
launching standalone PFSs as well as ASDA Opticians. In 2015, we celebrated our 50th birthday and
George's 25th birthday. In 2016, Roger Burnley joined our team as Chief Operating Officer and Deputy
Chief Executive and was promoted in 2018 to President and CEO. ASDA has continued to roll out
innovations, including the United Kingdom's first parcel tower, which allows customers to collect online
orders in less than 60 seconds, and voice-activated shopping through Google Home.

Our values are rooted in service to our customers, respect for the individual, striving for excellence and
acting with integrity. We pursue our values with the support of our colleagues, culture and technology.

**KEY STRENGTHS**

We believe that we benefit from the following strengths, including being a business of significant scale
with a history of resilient performance, a differentiated operating model, a successful financial profile and
a significant asset backing, as further described below.

**_We are a business of significant scale with a history of resilient performance_**

_We operate in a large, historically stable, resilient and growing industry with favourable macroeconomic_
_tailwinds_

We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market, which has demonstrated
resilient performance underpinned by favourable macroeconomic factors including GDP, population,
consumer confidence and household spend on food and beverages. Since the 2007-2009 global financial
crisis, UK GDP growth has shown stable development: annual GDP growth has ranged between 1.3% and
2.9% between 2010 and 2019, according to ONS. In 2020, GDP growth in the United Kingdom is expected
to reflect a sharp decline due to the impact of COVID-19. However, it is predicted by ONS to quickly recover
to growth of approximately 5.5% in 2021 and, post-2021, UK GDP growth is expected to stabilise to an
average of 1.9% in subsequent years through 2025. The UK grocery retail market is also characterised by
favourable demographic characteristics, including a growing population. According to ONS, the UK
population is projected to grow from 67 million in 2019 to 70 million by 2031, which is expected to result in
an overall increase in the consumer base for groceries.

In addition to its historical stability, the UK grocery retail market is also resilient. Groceries are a
necessary and stable consumer expenditure, which generally allows the grocery retail market to weather
economic downturns better than certain other retail markets that involve more discretionary spending. For
example, the UK grocery retail market demonstrated its two strongest periods of growth in recent history
during and following the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and during the COVID-19 pandemic. The UK
grocery retail market peaked at 6.2% year-over-year growth in 2011, with a CAGR of 5.1% between 2007
and 2011, in each case according to Euromonitor. Additionally, during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis,
according to ONS, the percentage of average weekly household spend on food and non-alcoholic drinks
remained fairly consistent at approximately 11.0%, demonstrating the market's resilience during periods of
macroeconomic difficulty. According to ONS, this percentage has remained relatively flat following the
2007-2009 global financial crisis and the 2011 sovereign debt crisis, averaging 10.6% between 2012 and
2019, which we believe underscores the largely non-discretionary nature of grocery purchases. According
to Kantar, the UK grocery market's year-over-year growth increased to 12.3% (on a Total Grocery Absolute

201


-----

Sales basis for the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020), although growth in 2020 has been principally
driven by the impact of COVID-19 (mainly consisting of an increase in the consumption of food and drink
products at home during lockdowns), rather than long-term underlying growth drivers.

_We are the United Kingdom's third-largest grocer, holding sizeable market share_

According to Kantar, we are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom, with 12.2% of
market share and the second-largest grocery retailer in the North of England, Scotland and Wales (based
on Total Grocery Absolute Sales over 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020), with revenue of approximately
£19.6 billion and £20.0 billion (excluding petrol) for the year ended December 31, 2019 and the 12 months
ended September 30, 2020, respectively. We have a network of 614 stores (excluding standalone PFSs)
throughout the United Kingdom, with a particular focus on superstores, supermarket and online formats.
We are also the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom by value (in terms of Total
Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of December 27, 2020, according to Kantar) and have been
growing faster than our competitors except for Sainsbury's in this channel, having increased our market
share over many years and particularly throughout 2020 and the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result, we
believe that we are well-positioned as a large and established business with a clear set of peers.

We also believe that our multi-format, omni-channel offer positions us well to compete effectively and
to continue growing our market share. Despite not operating convenience formats, our Adjusted EBITDA
in the year ended December 31, 2019 was £1.2 billion (including petrol), which we believe indicates that
we have headroom for growth in the convenience market. We also cater to a broad target demographic,
which we believe provides us a long-term competitive advantage. In contrast to discounters, we provide a
broad range of branded as well as own-brand offers, while also having a more developed and established
online platform.

**_We believe we have faced the greatest impacts of discounters on our market_**

The adverse impact of discounters (primarily Aldi and Lidl) on the traditional grocers in recent years has
been significant but, while we believe that discounters will continue to put pressure on the market, we
believe that we have already faced the greatest impacts of this competition in the markets in which we
operate and that the discounters pose a greater challenge to other traditional grocers, who we believe are
more geographically exposed to the areas where discounters are likely to focus in the near-term.

As compared to our traditional grocer peers, our geographical concentration in the North of England,
Scotland and Wales, as evidenced by our number two market shares in those regions. The discounters
have already penetrated these areas and we expect the discounters to shift the focus of their expansion to
the South of England, the East of England and London, where we operate fewer sites as compared to the
Midlands, the North of England, Scotland and Wales. Furthermore, the catchment areas of 76% of our
stores already contain both major discounters, Aldi and Lidl, which is a higher percentage than any of our
traditional grocer competitors (the boundary used is a 10-minute drive-time radius around each point, which
is consistent regardless of location type or size of store and stores are only included in the count where
there is both Aldi and Lidl stores present within the drive-time boundary). Therefore, we believe that our
current performance already factors in the adverse impact of discounters to a large extent.

**_We have demonstrated resilience through downturns_**

Just as our market has proven resilient in times of economic difficulty and uncertainty, our business has
also proven resilient during recent economic and market downturns, including during the 2007-2009 global
financial crisis, as well as through a more recent period of low food inflation in the United Kingdom and the
rise of discounters in the UK grocery retail market in more recent years, particularly during 2014 to 2016.
During the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, we continued to perform well, achieving an average like-forlike sales (excluding petrol) growth rate of 6.1% for the fiscal years ended December 31, 2008 and 2009.
Our EBITDA margins have also remained stable, ranging from 5.1% to 6.6% between 2007 and 2019.
During this same period, we also experienced stable revenue growth, at a CAGR of 2.5%.

**_We have performed well and have benefitted from an improved reputation through COVID-19_**

Despite the significant social and economic shifts driven by the COVID-19 pandemic, our business has
experienced strong overall performance, particularly in our online and supermarket formats. While large
stores did not perform as well as smaller formats during the first UK lockdown, they have remained
instrumental in supporting the growth of our online retail grocery business, with online grocery orders being
largely fulfilled from our stores. We also believe that the "one-stop stop" offer of our stores appeals to
customers seeking to leave their homes and fulfil multiple missions efficiently. Overall, our food business
has performed relatively consistently throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, despite an initial increase in
sales due to panic buying and customers stocking-up on key staples at the outset of each of the first three
lockdown periods. Following an initial decline at the beginning of the first lockdown, our general

202


-----

merchandise business has also generally performed well throughout these lockdown periods, due to
increasing purchases of homeware products. While our clothing business was initially negatively impacted
during the early stage of the first UK lockdown period, we have recently experienced improved performance
in this business in line with an overall improvement of the general economy and a rebound in consumer
confidence. Finally, we have also taken steps throughout the COVID-19 pandemic to enhance our
reputation with our stakeholders through various initiatives, including meal donations, priority delivery
services to care homes and additional leave provided to staff affected by COVID-19, which we believe have
had an overall positive impact on perceptions of our brand and business.

**_We benefit from a differentiated operating model_**

_We operate the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom, which is profitable and_
_winning market share_

The United Kingdom has one of the most developed online grocery retail markets in the world, with one
of the highest rates of the population using the internet. There has been a significant shift in the grocery
retail market away from brick-and-mortar stores to online purchasing as demographic trends, greater
mobile and device usage, improved service proposition and technological advances in applications and
customer interfaces have driven increasing penetration rates in the online grocery retail market. We believe
we are poised to take advantage of these favourable consumer trends, as we have already established
ourselves in the rapidly growing UK online grocery retail market and our store and warehouse footprint is
strategically positioned across attractive geographic areas to service the growing demand for groceries
online.

According to Kantar, we are the second-largest online grocery retail platform in the United Kingdom,
holding 19.8% of market share (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales) for the 52-week period ended
December 27, 2020. Relative to our competitors, we have posted the second-strongest share gain since
December 2019 and through the COVID-19 pandemic, with an industry-leading 3.3% increase in our share
of the online grocery retail market between December 2017 and December 2020 and an increase of 154
basis points between December 2019 and December 2020, according to Kantar (based on Total Grocery
Absolute Sales for the 52-week periods through December 31 for 2017, 2018 and 2019 and the 52-week
period ended December 27, 2020).

As a result of our significant gain in online market share, our online sales, combined sales for our online
grocery business and George.com have rapidly increased in recent years, growing from £1.7 billion (of
which £1.5 billion were online grocery sales and £0.2 billion were George.com sales) in 2018 to £1.9 billion
in 2019 (of which £1.6 billion were online grocery sales and £0.3 billion were George.com sales) to a total
of £2.7 billion for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020 (of which £2.4 billion were online grocery sales
and £0.3 billion were George.com sales), representing a CAGR of 26% between 2018 and September 30,
2020.

We believe there is greater scope for our online profitability to improve further. We expect that the
demand for online groceries will continue to be strong as customers increasingly adopt online shopping as
a more permanent and preferred way to purchase groceries following the initial lockdowns.

_We benefit from vertically integrated procurement through IPL_

We believe that we have a competitive advantage in food sourcing via our captive sourcing arm, IPL,
which enables us to take a vertically integrated approach to procurement. We believe that IPL provides us
with valuable sourcing differentiation as compared to our competitors. IPL is the largest importer of produce
in the United Kingdom and, while IPL is a group company, it is also our largest supplier. The aim of our
vertically integrated procurement model is to consolidate import activity for key products and reduce our
overall costs. In 2019, we purchased £1.5 billion of our products through IPL. The foundation of IPL's costprice advantage is that it eliminates the "middle man" who typically serves as the intermediary in the supply
chain, thereby giving us greater control of costs, quality and supply of a diverse range of products. We
have an extensive IPL footprint across the United Kingdom, with ten processing facilities across the country
and more than 4,200 colleagues. Our IPL product mix is diversified according to our needs, with a mix of
61% in produce, 27% in protein, 9% in beverages and 3% in grocery in 2019. Additionally, we have been
able to build upon and benefit from our supplier relationships to deliver supply chain continuity and make
progress in our sustainability agenda. We also believe that IPL will provide greater stability and allow us
greater control over our supply chain now that the United Kingdom has left the European Union's single
market and customs union.

_The George Clothing and George Home offers are profitable and well-established_

We launched our clothing offer, George, in 1990 and it is the second-largest clothing brand in the United
Kingdom by volume of units sold (excluding essentials, footwear and accessories) for the 52 weeks ended
December 13, 2020 and is the leading UK childrenswear brand with 21% market share by volume of units
sold as of December 13, 2020, in each case according to Kantar. Despite challenges to this product
category overall, our online clothing sales have increased from £104.3 million for the year to December 31,
2016 to £308.6 million for the 12 months ended September 30, 2020, with more than two-thirds of all sales
now made via mobile devices. We believe this demonstrates our strength in the online segment, which is
a key part of our operating model. Additionally, we have expanded the George branded offer to include
general merchandise. The George Home brand generated approximately £530 million in sales and
contributed approximately 38% of our total general merchandising sales for the fiscal year ended December
31, 2019. Sales by the George Home brand grew at a CAGR of approximately 3% between the years
ended December 31, 2016 and 2019. Furthermore, the George Clothing and George Home product
categories generally have higher margins than our food product categories.

_We have well-developed own-brands_

We believe that our own-brand offers have been a key strength of our business and continue to offer
growth opportunities. We have an extensive own-brand product range in our food business, with
approximately 7,000 own-brand SKUs, while our premium "Extra Special" offer is our fastest growing ownbrand product line. Our award-winning approach to range development and innovation enables us to meet
changing customer needs: we launched approximately 850 new lines in 2020 and approximately 2,500
lines having been reformulated in 2020. In addition to our diverse and extensive product offer with our ownbrand range, we have also been able to drive growth through service and price positioning. We leverage
our IPL sourcing model to deliver value, especially in our produce, cooked meats and wine segments.

_We are driven by our commitment to Every Day Low Prices_

We believe our commitment to Every Day Low Prices is a significant competitive advantage as we aim
to lead on price while staying competitive on assortment. We believe that we are the least-expensive fullselection traditional grocer in the United Kingdom: according to internal ASDA data, our prices are
approximately 6% to 7.5% less expensive than our traditional grocer competitors (on a 2020 year-to-date
(weeks 1-42) average, based on total goods price gap percentage). Our low prices are supported by
rigorous cost control and a commitment to Every Day Low Prices, which enables us to control expenses
so that we can pass cost savings on to our customers.

**_We have achieved a successful financial profile_**

We have achieved a successful financial profile that is underpinned by strong Adjusted EBITDA
margins, free cash flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA less capital expenditure) and cash conversion
(defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA) in recent years. In 2018 and 2019, our average
Adjusted EBITDA margin was 5.5% (including petrol), our cumulative free cash flow was approximately
£1.7 billion and our average cash conversion was approximately 70%. This strong financial performance
is driven by our Every Day Low Price model, diverse product offer, strong own-brand grocery offer and
well-established George-branded product categories. Our Adjusted EBITDA margins have benefitted from
our cost transformation programmes, which have generated SG&A cost savings without compromising the
low prices we offer our customers. Our active working capital management has resulted in approximately
£400 million of improvements over the past three years. Furthermore, we have pursued a disciplined
approach to our capital expenditure over time, with the aim of maintaining and improving our real estate
platform. Our well-invested store real estate portfolio underpins our strong, ongoing cash flow generation.

**_We are supported by a significant asset portfolio_**

We are supported by a well-invested and geographically diversified store estate, with 71% of our retail
sites being freehold (calculated as gross square footage of freehold stores as a percentage of gross square
footage of total stores, as of December 20, 2020; freehold percentage also includes certain properties that

**BUSINESS STRATEGY**

Our primary strategy is designed to "win on price" by narrowing our price gap with discounters (such as
Aldi and Lidl) while providing good value and maintaining our price leadership position against our
traditional grocery peers, which we expect to further enhance customer loyalty. We aim to provide a
consistent, trusted experience, incentivising customers not to shop elsewhere, through the creation of
attractive store propositions and partnerships that increase our appeal to customers. We serve our
customers with our team of flexible and engaged colleagues, while increasing the number of self-serve
opportunities and transforming the in-store experience. We focus our growth where customers care,
expanding our addressable markets in online grocery, wholesale and community convenience.

**_Winning on price with value equivalent to the discounters_**

We are already well established as the lowest-price full-selection retailer in the United Kingdom and we
comfortably lead the traditional grocers in terms of lowest price. Moving forward, we intend to narrow our
price gap to the discounters and further expand our existing price gap with other traditional grocers. We
aim to achieve this by simplifying our core customer proposition to offer a curated range in food, general
merchandise and clothing that responds to customers' demonstrated willingness to shop a tighter range of
offers in-store. We will also create a more hassle-free customer experience in-store with our digital
transformation. For example, we intend to implement more customer self-serve options, such as moving to
a checkout model which features 80/20 self-checkout solutions and we plan to optimise our in-store
fulfilment operations. We believe this will enable us to deliver a simplified operating model and end-to-end
supply chain efficiencies to drive further investment in value for the customer at the shelf edge, driving
greater traffic and therefore sales growth, which will in turn stimulate greater volume, thereby creating a
positive effect for our overall business.

We are assessing our approach to further reward customer loyalty by exploring non-traditional and
digitally-based loyalty mechanisms so that we can identify more customers in more transactions. We
believe that this approach will allow us to grow our customer analytics platform to bring better, faster, and
deeper customer insights to our largest investment decisions and to improve the overall customer
experience by personalising our offer.

205


-----

**_Develop ASDA as a platform by forming relevant partnerships_**

We aim to grow ASDA as a platform through simplification of the store proposition by forming
partnerships that enable us to provide a broader set of relevant branded products and services, while also
building upon our existing capabilities, such as logistics and our customer-facing toyou proposition. We
believe adding partners to our platform will result in the creation of appealing "one-stop-shop" store
destinations for more customer missions. We are attracting relevant partners with our existing customer
base and scale, particularly with respect to the George brand clothing and general merchandise offers. For
example, our own-brand general merchandise proposition, led by the George Home brand, will become
more omni-channel focused as we grow those categories in which we believe we already have a strong
position and can maintain or gain leading market share. Meanwhile, in other categories, we will extend
product ranges with partners who specialise in those categories, have a strong affinity fit with our existing
customers and bring complementary expertise and reputation, such as in toys with The Entertainer. We
believe these partnerships will not only provide additional income through rent and revenue share models,
but will also create a positive effect on our overall business.

**_Growth where customers care, expanding our addressable market_**

We have grown our online grocery channel ahead of the market in 2020, having achieved 80% yearover-year growth as compared to the 66% year-over-year growth (in terms of value) achieved by the overall
UK online grocery market, according to Kantar (based on the 52 weeks ended December 27, 2020).
However, we believe there is further headroom for growth based on continued channel shifting, demand
and customer "stickiness." We plan to continue to drive growth and market share gains in the online channel
through the acceleration of our online grocery channel's capacity to meet increased demand. We continue
to seek to optimise our online grocery operating model and further develop our already profitable economic
model through the ongoing assessment of our online product range and promotions, further monetisation
of our e-commerce assets, as well as other initiatives.

In addition to growing our core online grocery business, we are targeting further growth by expanding
the reach of our online platform and expanding our delivery services. We expect to provide customers with
greater and more convenient access to our product range by accelerating our last-mile delivery capabilities
via partnerships: for example, we have recently expanded our partnership with UberEats to over 100 of our
stores, with a further 100 planned in early 2021.

We believe that customers seeing ASDA in new locations and new formats will help us broaden our
customer base, thereby benefitting our core proposition (which is composed of our in-store and online food
and non-food offerings, and does not include trials, such as the ASDA On the Move wholesale-convenience
concept). We also believe that we can further expand our addressable market by accessing wholesale and
community convenience channels in an asset-light manner. We are looking to extend the reach of our
products delivered through wholesale and more specifically through partnerships that would provide
wholesale delivery services by using the logistics and distribution capabilities of IPL. We aim to broaden
our reach to existing and new customers through further convenience channel trials, using our established
partnerships to access the convenience channel within local communities. For example, ASDA On the
Move is our first entrance into the convenience market, where we are carrying out an initial trial with the
EG Group at three store locations in Ashby, Leamore and Primley. ASDA On the Move is a wholesale
arrangement whereby ASDA's own brand products as well as branded products will be sold in third-partyowned smaller convenience store formats.

During the COVID-19 pandemic, customer behaviour has changed, with a shift away from out-of-home
food consumption towards at-home food consumption, to the benefit of the UK grocery market. The chart
below shows COVID-19-accelerated channel shifts over the periods presented. For further information on
prevailing trends in the UK grocery retail market and, in particular, the recent channel shifts which have
been accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic, please see "Industry."

(Source: Kantar Worldpanel, based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a year-to-date basis ended December 27, 2020.)

Grocery sales have grown by 12.3% between December 1, 2019 and December 27, 2020, according
to Kantar, based on Total Grocery Absolute Sales. Changes to consumer behaviour that have positively
benefitted the grocery market during the COVID-19 pandemic include: increased consumption of food at
home, a shift to online shopping channels, increased preference for shopping locally, in particular during
the first UK lockdown (which we believe benefitted retail groups with a strong convenience store presence),
and an increased focus on food safety, hygiene and health.

Despite significant challenges posed by COVID-19, our business has remained resilient, supported by
a well-developed online channel, which saw significant growth during government-imposed lockdowns as
customer behaviour evolved. We were able to quickly increase the capacity of our online offer in response
to increased demand driven by the pandemic, gaining market share and improving the profitability of our
online business.

During the COVID-19 pandemic, we have benefitted from healthy revenue growth driven by higher food
sales volumes (which were in turn driven by stockpiling and increased customer demand for in-home
groceries via the online grocery channel), while margins contracted due to adverse changes in sales and
product mix resulting from decreases in clothing sales, which impacted the George Clothing brand, the
temporary closure of 33 ASDA Living stores and the shift in product mix within the food category away from
higher-margin categories, such as food-to-go, and towards lower-margin categories, such as beer, wine
and spirits and meat, which factors were partially offset by lower levels of promotional activity and stronger
general merchandise sales. Furthermore, the George Clothing and George Home product categories
generally have higher margins than our food product categories. Profitability was also adversely impacted
by COVID-19-related increases in operating costs, such as the increase in retail colleague wage costs
(driven by bonus payments, overtime wages and wages paid colleagues absent from work due to COVID19, as well as wages paid to colleagues who worked during such sick colleagues' absences, rather than
as a result of increased wage rates), increased costs incurred in connection with goodwill compensation
paid to clothing suppliers, holiday markdowns, enhanced cleaning and related health and safety measures,
as well as higher retail operating expenditures.

We have considered the outbreak of COVID-19 to be a non-adjusting post-balance sheet event: the

impact on future results and cash flows is difficult to estimate and we have therefore considered a range of
scenarios as described in note 1 ("Accounting Policies") of the 2019 Financial Statements. See "Risk
_Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—The_
_impact of COVID-19 on our business and industry is significant and its effects will continue to create_
_uncertainty in our market and materially impact our business, financial condition and results of operations_
_for the foreseeable future due to many factors, most of which are beyond our control."_

We took significant steps during the first twelve weeks of the first lockdown period in the spring of 2020
to protect our most vulnerable colleagues, asking them to remain home on contracted pay in order to
ensure their safety, while we increased social-distancing and protective measures at our stores. When we
welcomed these colleagues back, we carried out individual risk assessments and conducted socialdistancing training for them. In September 2020, we further tightened our safety measures across our
stores to provide an enhanced level of protection to our customers and colleagues, introducing new door
marshals at the front of stores and increasing security presence in the aisles of larger stores; marshals also
provide sanitised baskets to customers as they enter stores. Colleagues continue to be on hand to help
customers with safety queries and reiterate government guidelines to wear a face covering and maintain
social distancing while they shop. Customers who do not have a face covering when they enter the store
are offered a pack of disposable masks that they can pay for as they complete their shopping. Additional
hand sanitisation stations are in place in the busiest sections of all stores in addition to the multiple cleaning
points already found throughout stores.

Should current safety guidelines continue, we believe that it is unlikely that we will continue to incur a
significant portion of the additional costs in the future that we incurred in responding to the COVID-19
pandemic during the first two lockdowns, as many of these costs incurred were one-off in nature. The chart

**OUR BUSINESSES**

We are an omni-channel retailer centred around a brick-and-mortar store network, which is
geographically diversified across the United Kingdom, and our websites (primarily through
groceries.asda.com and George.com). Our retail business comprises a food (which in turn comprises
produce, ambient products and fresh food products) and a non-food offer (which in turn comprises clothing,
homeware and general merchandise offers). We also offer our customers other services, including, among
other things, a mobile phone service, various financial products, parcel drop and collection and in-store
pharmacies and opticians.

**Our Retail Business**

Our retail business comprises a food segment, which consists of our grocery business, and a non-food
segment, which includes our well-known George Clothing and George Home brands, as well as a general
merchandise and health and wellness offer. We offer over 90 product groups for sale across 22 categories
(excluding petrol).

We operate our retail business through both brick-and-mortar retail sites and through online sales made,
primarily, via groceries.asda.com and George.com.

Our physical retail business operates under four distinct formats: supercentres and superstores,
supermarkets, ASDA Living and PFSs. We also recently entered the convenience market, with the launch
our ASDA On the Move wholesale-convenience concept. The concept is being trialled by EG Group at
three of their sites and is based around a wholesale approach. Our standalone PFSs and co-located PFSs
will be sold to EG Group pursuant to the Forecourt Business Disposal, or to the extent we are required to
do so to obtain regulatory approval for the Acquisition, we will sell all or part of our forecourt business to
third parties. For more information on our store formats, see "—Our Store Formats" and for more
information on how the Transactions will impact our PFS business, see "The Transactions."

We aim to develop ASDA as a platform by forming partnerships that enable us to provide a broader set
of relevant branded products and services while also building on our existing capabilities such as logistics
and the customer-facing toyou proposition. We believe adding partners to our platform will result in the
creation of attractive store destinations, in which more customer missions can be accomplished under one
roof. See "—Business Strategies."

Food

In 2019, our food segment accounted for 85% (£16.6 billion) of our total sales of £19.6 billion (excluding
petrol). Within our food segment, in 2019, ambient food items and non-edible items accounted for 53%
(£8.8 billion), and fresh/produce accounted for 47% (£7.8 billion), of our food sales.

_Ambient_

Our ambient product category includes core grocery items (such as rice, pasta, baking supplies, canned
goods, condiments and cereals), impulse grocery items (such as snacks, confectionary treats, biscuits and
soft drinks), beer, wine, spirits, baby and toiletry items, non-edible grocery items (such as paper products,
pet care supplies, cleaning supplies and laundry-related items), newspapers, magazines and other kiosk
items, pharmacy (including health products and ambient medicines) and optical products. We believe that
certain of our own-brand ambient products, such as our Little Angels nappies and our Shades toilet rolls,
are among the most popular products of their kind on the market.

We have recently expanded the range of our plant-based and vegan food products within our overall
ambient food selection. In September 2020, we rolled out new offers and dedicated space in our stores to
over 70 plant-based products, in addition to our already strong Free From offer. New items offered include
vegan and plant-based proteins, cooking sauces, condiments, snacks and sweets. Our goal is to provide
vegan and plant-based foods at affordable prices and our intention is that these new vegan items will
eventually be rolled out across approximately half of our store network.

_Fresh_

Our fresh product category includes core chilled products (such as cheese, cooked meats, pies, salads
and dips, eggs and dairy products), fresh proteins (such as fresh beef, fresh pork, fresh poultry, bacon,
sausage and pre-packed fish), bakery (such as cakes, breads and morning goods bought and produced in
store), in-store café (such as beverages, main meals, snacks and drinks), food to go (such as sandwiches,
snacks, confectionary treats, salads and drinks) serve-over and self-serve counters (such as rotisserie,
pizza, Greggs, Panku, Sushi Daily, Kulaba Kitchen, ASDA takeaway and various local partners), frozen
(such as frozen meat, chips, vegetables, desserts, ice cream and frozen meal solutions) fresh ready meals,
soups and pizzas.

_Produce_

Our produce product category includes fruit, vegetables, salads, nuts, plants and flowers.

Non-Food

In 2019, our non-food segment accounted for 15% (£3.0 billion) of our total sales of £19.6 billion
(excluding petrol and other), with clothing and general merchandise accounting for 8% and 7% of our total
sales (excluding petrol), respectively.

_Clothing_

Our clothing product category includes the George Clothing line which offers a wide variety of clothing
and apparel, including for baby, children, men, women, jewellery, footwear, socks and hosiery.

_General merchandise_

Our general merchandise product category includes George Home (kitchenwares, housewares,
electrical appliances, furniture, lighting, bath, kids items and furnishings and bedding), seasonal and
occasions products and toys (cards, celebration products, stationary, toys, hobby items and festive and
Halloween products), outdoor and essential items (sporting goods, automotive, hardware, paint, access
products and home and garden products) and entertainment (electronics, books and telecoms products).

**Our Other Services**

ASDA Pharmacy and ASDA Opticians

We operate complementary pharmacy and optical businesses that offer enhanced customer
experiences and diversify our cash flows.

We have 254 ASDA Pharmacies offering NHS, locally commissioned and private services to our
patients. These services include dispensing NHS and private prescriptions, electronic prescriptions and
collection services as well as our ASDA Pharmacy flu vaccine service for NHS and private
patients. Examples of NHS services we offer include our New Medicine Service in England, Pharmacy First
in Scotland and our Common Ailment scheme in Wales, each of which are commissioned by the home
nations.

ASDA Opticians offers our customers access to optical services and products in 156 stores and has a
dedicated online site selling contact lenses. In our stores, we complete eye examinations, contact lens
examinations and provide additional NHS services. Our in-store spectacle pricing model does not charge
extra to patients for prescription needs, including varifocals. We offer a wide contact lens portfolio of various
brands, designs and modalities. We also offer safety spectacles, sunglasses, eye care products,
accessories and contact lens solutions.

ASDA Money

We offer certain financial and insurance products on a commission-only basis. All products are provided
through third-party partnerships. The products we offer include home insurance, car insurance, travel
insurance, pet insurance, money transfer, breakdown cover, third-party gift cards, personal loans, credit
cards and travel money. See also "Regulation—Regulation Relating to our Money and Insurance Offers."

ASDA Gift Cards

We offer ASDA branded gift cards for sale in our stores and on our dedicated websites, which can be
used to buy goods in-store, on George.com or to purchase online groceries. Our gift card offer includes
ASDA's Christmas Savings Card, an ASDA-branded card that pays a bonus to customers in November
based on how much they have saved on their card up to that date. We also participate in pre-paid card
schemes through our business-to-business gift card programme, through which a commission is paid to
businesses to encourage end-users to shop at ASDA. Businesses who purchase ASDA gift cards can also
receive a discount on bulk purchases.

ASDA Mobile

ASDA Mobile operates as a Mobile Network Virtual Operator, offering pay-as-you-go mobile services
to customers. The ASDA Mobile network is currently powered by EE. In 2020, we entered into an exclusive

transitioned to Vodafone during the first half of 2021. Existing customers using EE's services will be asked
to migrate over to the new network, which will have additional features and benefits not currently available
through the EE network.
