**Our Online Platform**

We offer online grocery shopping through our online ASDA groceries platform, including delivery
services for our customers' online orders, as well as our Click & Collect service. We also offer our popular
George Clothing and homeware range online through George.com.

ASDA groceries

ASDA groceries is our online groceries business. We sell our groceries through groceries.asda.com
and our mobile application. Customers place an order either for delivery or for collection from one of
approximately 460 Click & Collect sites. Delivery orders are fulfilled either from our home shopping centres,
which are dedicated fulfilment centres for online grocery orders, or from ASDA stores, depending on the
customer's location. This in-store online model proved effective in responding to rapid increases in demand
during the recent COVID-19-related lockdowns in the United Kingdom and we believe this demonstrates
our ability to scale our online offering quickly to meet customer demand.

Delivery to customers is primarily made by ASDA colleagues using our van fleet. For deliveries,
customers book a delivery slot and can choose to either pay per delivery or to sign up for unlimited
deliveries across a period of time for a fixed cost.

Online innovation continues to be a priority for us, as evidenced in our strategic partnership with
UberEats to enable convenience groceries to be delivered to customers quickly and our Express Collection
offer, which enables customers to place an order for collection within an hour.

In 2020, there were approximately 9.8 million weekly visits to groceries.asda.com, with approximately
488,000 weekly orders pre-COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days ended February
28, 2020), and approximately 723,000 weekly orders post COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the
seven days ended September 30, 2020). The COVID-19 pandemic has increased use of and engagement
with our online platforms and we currently fulfil approximately 720,000 online orders per week.

George.com

**OUR SUPPLIERS AND LOGISTICS**

We operate a "hub and spoke" logistics network, with two hubs and two deconsolidation centres serving
33 depots throughout the United Kingdom. Our logistics model is designed to support our extensive store
and online businesses. This approach starts with suppliers that provide goods to our hubs and depots as
well as directly to our stores for certain products. Our hubs and depots supply our stores via our fleet. In
addition to in-store purchasing, ASDA and ASDA Logistics Services also offer customers home delivery
and Click & Collect services.

_Hubs: Our two hubs are split by category: our Lutterworth hub handles general merchandise and_
ambient goods, while our Doncaster hub, which is operated by a third party, handles general merchandise
and ambient products.

_Suppliers: We had more than 4,400 active suppliers as of September 30, 2020, the top 20 of which_
(excluding IPL and petrol) reflected approximately 35% of cost of goods sold (excluding VAT, for the
October 1, 2019 to September 30, 2020 period). These suppliers deliver goods either to a hub (such as for
ambient and non-edible products and non-food products), direct to depots (such as for fresh food, produce
and fast-moving ambient) or direct to stores (such as for bread). New suppliers undergo a number of checks
and procedures managed via the shared service centre team. If a supplier is identified as a third-party
intermediary, which is typically only relevant to goods not for resale suppliers presenting a bribery and
corruption risk, further procedures are required as part of the on-boarding and ongoing management
processes for that supplier, focused on anti-corruption. During the on-boarding of goods not for resale
suppliers, we undertake a compliance risk review covering topics including, among others, modern slavery,
information security and privacy. If compliance risks are identified, then we agree on and implement

215


-----

appropriate mitigation measures. Relationships with goods for resale suppliers are managed by the
relevant buying team within the commercial team. Our buyers are responsible for negotiating key terms,
including pricing, promotional activity, supplier income arrangements, and payment terms. For goods not
for resale suppliers, the applicable business owners manage the contract terms and arrangements. We
leverage supplier relationships to deliver supply chain continuity.

_Ordering process: the purchase order process varies according to the category of goods._

## •Goods for resale: Automatic orders are generated with suppliers based on stock levels / stock
availability, historical demand trends and forecast trends. This is applicable for the majority of food
orders. The supply team has manual override capabilities for automatic orders, albeit limited and rarely
required. Non-food products typically operate on a longer lead time. The orders are based on forecast
sales numbers provided to the supply team by the buying team and the commercial finance team.

## •Goods not for resale: Purchase orders are raised by the procurement team or the applicable colleague
and reviewed by the budget holder (the individual who is responsible for the budget to which the
associated cost relates) within that colleague's team.

_Logistics facilities: logistics facilities_ receive, process, warehouse and distribute goods for sale at our
stores. IPL, Forza and Kober are treated as suppliers and largely deliver to depots. In addition, we operate
home shopping centres, which are fulfilment centres for online grocery orders.

_Fleet: ASDA drivers deliver goods to stores and customers using fleet vehicles (approximately 1,150_
leased tractors and approximately 2,300 leased trailers), home shopping vans (approximately 2,800 leased
vans) or occasional spot-hire or use of third-party hauliers (figures as of January 6, 2021).

_Stores: aside from in store purchasing, we also offer our customers home delivery and Click & Collect_
service.

**IPL**

We believe we have a competitive advantage in food sourcing via IPL and its two subsidiary companies,
Forza and Kober, which enables a vertically integrated approach to procurement. IPL is an important asset
that provides valuable sourcing differentiation. In 2019, £1.5 billion was purchased through IPL, reducing
our overall costs.

Our 2019 product mix sourced from IPL was 60% produce, 28% protein, 8% beverages and 3% grocery.
IPL employed over 4,000 colleagues as of December 31, 2019 across its group of companies, and only
serves us. IPL receives products directly from producers and centralises sourcing, processing and
packaging. This disintermediation of export agents, import agencies, suppliers and packers is the
foundation of IPL's cost price advantage: IPL sources produce, cooked meats, wine, nuts and dried fruit,
plants and flowers and has a national footprint of nine processing facilities across the United Kingdom,
supported by seven overseas technical/logistical operations. IPL's overseas offices provide us with the
benefit of being close to our foreign suppliers and sources, which we believe gives us greater insight and
control over our supply chain, conferring on us a competitive advantage as compared to competitors that
do not benefit from comparable vertically integrated procurement.

**OUR QUALITY CONTROL SYSTEM,** **HEALTH AND SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL POLICIES**

**Quality Control**

We are committed to providing customers with safe and high-quality products, including both our ownbrand products and name brand products. We have a due diligence framework in place which covers,
among other things, our supplier audit framework, our governance policies, product testing and our
specification management system. Our supplier audit framework measures compliance, supplier
performance against food safety hazard analysis and critical control point principles. In addition, we have
a quality management system that measures how our products perform in terms of quality.

To control the quality of the products we sell, we execute a number of quality control initiatives. We
conduct regular quality controls on the acceptance of fresh food at our depots. In addition, we analyse ownbrand product samples in our in-house sensory kitchens and through a third-party, Cambridge Market
Research, to ensure that our products meet our customers' expectations.

We conduct quarterly food safety audits at our stores to ensure that each store meets our required
standards for food safety and hygiene. We conduct annual refresher trainings for store colleagues to ensure
that they are trained in all relevant aspects of food safety, including allergen management.

All new own-brand suppliers must be Global Food Safety Initiative accredited and must pass a new
supplier audit before proceeding. In addition, all own-brand suppliers will have an annual unannounced
ASDA bolt-on food safety audit that measures supplier adherence to ASDA policy.

217


-----

When deciding whether to work with an own-brand supplier, we monitor the quality of its products based
on a control of samples delivered by the supplier during the selection phase. Following selection, we
regularly evaluate the quality of the products the supplier offers, including through randomly selected
samples. Our general supplier terms and conditions include a section dedicated to quality, safety, labelling
and traceability. By signing these terms and conditions, our suppliers confirm that they are fully aware of,
and comply with, our safety and quality standards. Furthermore, suppliers must adhere to our technical
manufacturing guide and associated policies for food as well as work with our own-brand technical teams
to ensure compliance with this guide and these policies.

**Health, Safety and Environmental Policies and Ethics**

We are committed to maintaining high standards of health and safety practices for our colleagues,
customers, visitors, contractors and anyone affected by our business activities. We therefore consider good
health, safety and environmental management as an essential part of our business performance and
culture. We formally monitor health and safety incident rates. Our health and safety policies and procedures
include:

        - managing risk and promoting a corporate culture that emphasises the benefits of health and
safety;

        - appropriate training and education of all colleagues to support legal compliance and best
practices; and

        - proactively conducting regular risk assessments and root cause analyses to provide and
maintain safe and healthy working environments to significantly reduce occupational injuries
or illnesses.

We carry out a range of monitoring activities to provide assurance of the effectiveness of our policies
and procedures. These activities are completed by both internal teams and external experts. We have a
wide variety of health and safety and ethics policies that address topics such as Food Safety, Food
Contamination, Warehouse Safety, Product Safety, Privacy, Environment and Environmental Services,
Anti-Money Laundering and Licences and Permits, among others.

We also have a number of policies that relate specifically to waste management issues, such as Food
and Drink Waste, Confidential Waste, Optical Waste and Pharmacy Waste.

**Our Environmental, Social and Governance Goals**

We are committed to reducing our environmental impact and having a positive social impact in the
communities we serve and we have a governance programme in place to support us achieving this aim.
With respect to our environmental goals, we strive to reduce carbon emissions, promote sustainable
farming and fishing practices, sustainably source ingredients like palm oil that make their way into our
products, reduce food, product and packaging waste throughout our supply chain and deliver a greener
proposition to customers at a great value. We have a demonstrated track record of giving back to local
communities through our ASDA Foundation, among other dedicated community initiatives, while also
striving to tackle wider social issues through fundraising efforts with long-standing partners such as Breast
Cancer Now and BBC Children in Need. In line with our commitment to public health, we also aim to
increase the proportion of low fat, salt and sugar content products within our own-brand offering. We
manage our commitments to environmental and social impact goals with our established governance
structure. We have compliance policies in place regarding privacy and ethics, grocery supply standards,
anti-corruption, anti-trust, licences, consumer protection and health and safety, all of which are managed
by qualified and experienced audit and legal teams. We also maintain clear work standards across our
supply chain and collaborate with our stakeholders as well as across industries and organisations to
improve working conditions, including through initiatives to promote the dignity of workers as well as combat
modern slavery. As a result, we have been recognised for our overall compliance with the Groceries Supply
Code of Practice. In addition, we have been actively engaged in passing on our best practices through our
ASDA Local Supplier Development Academies, which help small suppliers develop their capabilities in
logistics and sustainability.

**OUR TECHNOLOGY AND INFORMATION SYSTEMS**

Our information systems are critical to our business operations. They provide management, analytical
and performance evaluation tools that assist management at all levels to undertake business processes.
Our technical infrastructure and computer applications are also used for the day-to-day management of
our business, including purchasing, sourcing, distribution, online sales, data exploitation, invoicing, cash
collection, reporting, consolidation and electronic data interchange. Our business depends on the ability of
our colleagues to process transactions on secure information systems and our capacity to store, retrieve,

218

process and manage information. Our information systems are highly integrated, covering most of our
fundamental business service areas. The majority of our core systems are currently provided and managed
by Walmart, and we aim to migrate off of these systems onto alternative solutions following the Separation,
as part of a three-year transition process. We believe that our information systems are robust, adequate to
support our activities and operate at standards that are comparable to other operators in our industry. See
"Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are risks associated with the Separation of
_ASDA from Walmart" and "Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional_
_Agreements with Walmart."_

**OUR PUBLICITY,** **MARKETING AND CUSTOMER SERVICE**

Marketing is an integral part of the promotion of our brand, stores and products. We carry out a number
of branding and advertising initiatives through our stores, websites and mobile applications, as well as
through print, social and broadcast advertising campaigns. We work these through owned, earned and
paid channels. The key focus of our messaging to our customers is an emphasis on value, the innovative,
high-quality and well-priced products we offer and brand sentiment, services and ways to shop as well as
a focus on corporate social responsibility. We also have an online and paper magazine, ASDA MAG/Good
Living, through which we promote our products and brand values, as well as encourage customer
engagement with our brands and offers. Our ASDA Price News publication (which is available in online
and paper formats) promotes our value offer and competitive deals. We receive publicity for our innovations
in product range and quality across own-brands, which helped us to win 543 product awards, 200 food
awards, 343 beer, wine and spirits awards and 15 retailer awards in 2019.

Customer service is key to winning and retaining customers. We make customer service available in
our stores, online and by telephone. We also offer our customers loyalty programmes, such as George
Rewards.

**OUR INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY**

We use a variety of trade names, service marks and trade marks in our business and rely on trade mark
and copyright laws, confidentiality procedures and contractual provisions to protect our intellectual
proprietary rights. Our key brands are, among others: ASDA, George and George Home.

We believe that the brand names of each of our various banners enjoy high brand recognition and are
material to our business. Our intellectual property policy is centred around the protection of our brands,
associated logos and our domain names. This policy involves filings and reservations on either a local
country basis or in the full range of countries where we operate or wish to preserve and protect our rights.

Certain intellectual property rights related to ASDA, including trade marks, are owned solely by Walmart.
In particular, intellectual property rights relating to the George Clothing brand are owned by a Walmart
group company and used by both Walmart and ASDA. Following the Separation, Walmart will grant ASDA

brand in certain other territories outside the United Kingdom and such specified European countries (on a

**INSURANCE**

We maintain insurance coverage against the risks inherent in our various businesses. Our insurance
policies are currently placed by Walmart pursuant to an umbrella policy, which covers marine and cargo,
directors and officers, core property, terrorism and political, cyber, employment practices and crime risks.
Following the Separation, we will replace the umbrella policy that has historically been provided by Walmart
with our own insurance policies. We also carry combined liability (employee liability, public liability, products
liability, medical malpractice (for our pharmacy business) and motor, marine (for our toyou offer), non-core
property (material damage and property owners' liability), machinery movement and health insurance
policies in addition to the umbrella policy. See "Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There
_are risks associated with the Separation of ASDA from Walmart."_

To support our insurance programme (in particular the self-funding/deductible and aggregate
provisions), letters of credit are provided to our insurers for each policy year. These are amended from time
to time to reflect the existing and anticipated book value in each policy.

**REGULATION**

We are subject to a wide variety of laws, regulations and industry standards administered by local,
national and other government entities. The following provides a brief description of the main laws and
regulations that govern our activities. References and discussions to directives, laws, regulations and other
administrative and regulatory documents are entirely qualified by the full text of such directives, laws,
regulations and other administrative and regulatory documents themselves.

We are in regular contact and dialogue with relevant regulators and have subject matter experts across
the business who monitor and manage compliance with the regulatory frameworks within which we operate.

**Controlled Land Order**

We are subject to the Groceries Market Investigation (Controlled Land) Order 2010 (the "Controlled
**Land Order") which is UK legislation designed to limit the ability of large grocery retailers to prevent land**
being used by their competitors for grocery retailing in the future. The Controlled Land Order is administered
by the CMA.

**Groceries Supply Code of Practice and Groceries Code Adjudicator**

We are subject to the Groceries Supply Code of Practice (the "GSCOP"), which is UK legislation
designed to regulate the relationship between designated retailers and their grocery suppliers. GSCOP
provides detail on how retailers should manage their relevant supplier relationships fairly.

The Groceries Code Adjudicator (the "GCA") is the independent regulator of GSCOP.

**Food Safety, Hygiene, Labelling and Nutrition and Consumer Protection**

We have a food safety team, which forms part of our compliance team, to ensure food handling
procedures are monitored closely to guarantee product safety, quality standards and compliance with all
applicable food safety and hygiene laws and regulations. Scheduled internal and external audits are
conducted by qualified, third-party food safety experts to ensure procedural compliance and adherence
with our policies. This verification programme identifies and evaluates the hazards that are significant for
food safety and hygiene, taking account of the Food Safety Act 1990, the Food Information Regulations
2014 (as amended) and Food Safety and Hygiene Regulations in place across England, Scotland, Northern
Ireland and Wales.

**Regulation Relating to our Health and Wellness Offers (ASDA Pharmacy and ASDA Optical)**

With respect to our Optical offer, we are regulated by the General Optical Council ("GOC"). ASL is a
registered Body Corporate with the GOC, which allows us to provide Optical services subject to the GOC
Business Standards and the Opticians Act of 1989. Our professionals are registered as individual
registrants with the GOC and are subject to GOC Standards for Individuals and the Opticians Act of 1989.

We hold NHS mandatory contracts for all of our ASDA Opticians locations and are subject to the terms
of these contracts. In some of our English ASDA Opticians locations, we also hold Enhanced Services
contracts and are subject to the NHS standard contracts and local service level agreements.

With respect to our pharmacies, we are regulated by the General Pharmaceutical Council ("GPHC").
Each of our individual pharmacies is registered with the GPHC. This allows us to carry out pharmaceutical
activity from our registered premises subject to the Standards for Registered Pharmacies. Our pharmacists
are registered with the GPHC as individual registrants and are subject to the GPHC Professional
Standards.

-----

**Regulation Relating to our Money and Insurance Offers**

_Financial Conduct Authority-authorised Entities_

ASL has been authorised by the FCA since 2017 and currently holds a limited permission to carry on
credit brokerage activities (limited to secondary broking). As a result of this authorisation, ASL is regulated
and supervised by the FCA.

_Appointed Representatives_

The Group includes two introducer-appointed representatives: ASL and ASDA Financial Services
Limited.

In addition to the FCA authorisation noted above, ASL is also payment services directive agent and
introducer-appointed representative that is currently involved in credit, insurance and payments
intermediation.

ASDA Financial Services Limited is an introducer-appointed representative which is currently involved
in credit and insurance intermediation.

In respect of these roles, ASL and ASDA Financial Service Limited are not directly authorised by the
FCA but may instead perform certain regulated activities and act as agent for firms that are directly
authorised by the FCA.

**Regulations Relating to our Mobile Offer**

_OFCOM Regulations_

ASDA is selling mobile communication services to consumers under the ASDA Mobile brand using EE's
network pursuant to a mobile virtual operator agreement with EE. See also "Our Businesses—Our Other
_Services—ASDA Mobile." The sale and supply of mobile communication services are regulated primarily_
by the Office of Communications ("OFCOM"), an independent regulator and competition authority for the
UK communications industries, within the framework set by the various European directives, the UK
Communications Act 2003 and other UK and European Union regulations and recommendations. ASDA
does not require a licence to operate the mobile communication services, however, it must comply with the
provisions of OFCOM's General Conditions of Entitlement that apply to such services.

**Regulations Relating to Electricity Purchasing**

We currently purchase our electricity on a wholesale basis via a dedicated subsidiary, which sells
electricity back to the rest of the ASDA Group companies. These electricity purchases are regulated by the
Office of Gas and Electricity Markets ("OFGEM"), which is the government regulator for gas and electricity
markets in Great Britain. In addition to OFGEM, we are also regulated by Elexon, which is the administrator
of the Balancing and Settlement Code. Therefore, the subsidiary which procures our power is subject to
the Performance Assurance Reporting and Monitoring System (PARMS) reporting regime which must be
submitted to Elexon on a monthly basis.

We are also required to submit certain returns to various government departments pursuant to
legislation including the Climate Change Levy Return submitted to HMRC, the Monthly Sales Report
submitted to the Department of Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy and the Demand Forecast
Submission to the National Grid.

In 2021, following the Separation, we aim to transition from our existing wholesale purchasing model for
electricity, which is currently arranged through Walmart, to purchasing electricity on a retail basis. See
"Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—There are risks associated with the Separation of
_ASDA from Walmart."_

**Data Privacy Regulations**

Through our in-store and online business, as well as certain of our other services (such as our money
and pharmacy offers), we have access to and may process personal data relating to our customers and
colleagues or any other individual in connection with the provision of our services (the "Relevant Data").
As such, we are subject to applicable laws and binding regulations on data protection and data privacy,
including the General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679 ("GDPR") (such laws and binding
regulations together with the GDPR, "Applicable Privacy Laws"), which will form part of domestic law of
the United Kingdom by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal Act) 2018 following the end of the Brexit
transition period. We will continue to review and develop existing processes to ensure that we comply with
Applicable Privacy Laws in relation to our processing of any Relevant Data.

In addition to the foregoing regulations, in the ordinary course of our business, our operations and

**LEGAL PROCEEDINGS**

At any given time, we may be party to litigation or be subject to non-litigated claims arising out of the
normal operations of our business, including but not limited to colleague claims, disputes with our suppliers
and customers and disputes with our lessors as part of our real estate management operations. A
description of material legal proceedings and investigations to which we are party is below. See also "Risk
_Factors—From time to time we and/or our management are subject to claims that can result in litigation,_
_arbitration, tax or regulatory proceedings which could distract management from our business activities_
_and result in significant liability."_

**Equal Value Litigation**

ASL is a defendant in over 40,000 equal value claims (the "Equal Value Claims") that began in 2008
and are proceeding before an Employment Tribunal in Manchester (the "Employment Tribunal") in the
United Kingdom on behalf of current and former ASDA store colleagues, and further claims may be
asserted in the future. The claimants allege that the work performed by colleagues in ASDA's retail stores
is of equal value in terms of, among other things, the demands of their jobs compared to that of colleagues
working in ASDA's warehouse and distribution facilities, that the difference in pay between these job
positions disparately impacts women because more women work in retail stores while more men work in
warehouses and distribution facilities, and that the pay difference is not objectively justified. The claimants
are requesting differential back pay based on higher wage rates in the warehouse and distribution facilities
and higher wage rates on a prospective basis.

In October 2016, following a preliminary hearing, the Employment Tribunal ruled that claimants could
compare their positions in ASDA's retail stores with those of colleagues in ASDA's warehouse and
distribution facilities. ASDA appealed the ruling and the oral argument was held before the Supreme Court
of the United Kingdom in July 2020. We are awaiting a decision.

Notwithstanding the appeal, claimants are proceeding in the next phase of their claims. That phase will
determine whether the work performed by the claimants is of equal value to the work performed by
colleagues in ASDA's warehouse and distribution facilities.

At present, we cannot predict the number of such claims that may be filed, and cannot reasonably
estimate any loss or range of loss that may arise from these proceedings. Accordingly, we can provide no
assurance as to the scope and outcomes of these matters and any losses that may arise from these
proceedings could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations
or cash flows. We believe we have substantial factual and legal defences to these claims, and intend to
defend the claims vigorously.

Under a separate indemnity undertaking, the Seller has agreed to indemnify the Purchaser in respect
of certain costs and losses incurred by the ASDA Group from Equal Value Claims filed with employment
tribunals, up to an agreed cap. As a result of these indemnity arrangements, even if the ASDA Group is
ultimately unsuccessful in defending any of the Equal Value Claims, we do not believe that such an
outcome would materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and/or results of operations nor
our ability to meet our debt service obligations, including on the Notes, or other financial obligations as they
become due.

As of September 30, 2020, the Company had no material off balance sheet arrangements or funding
arrangements that would be classified as a contingent liability under IFRS, except for a contingent liability
relating to the ongoing Equal Value Claims. With respect to these claims, the Company has not recognised
a provision on the basis that any loss or range of loss that may arise from these proceedings cannot be
reasonably estimated and any potential liability is only a possible obligation, as it has yet to be confirmed
whether the entity has a present obligation that could lead to an outflow of resources embodying economic

**Information About Our Principal Shareholders**

Mohsin Issa CBE and Zuber Vali Issa CBE have been active in the forecourt and convenience retail
sector since the acquisition of a single petrol station in Bury, United Kingdom in 2001. Following a merger
of their UK-based Euro Garages business with TDR Capital LLP's EFR Group in 2016, EG Group was
established, which the Issa Brothers now lead as co-CEOs. The business, globally headquartered in
Blackburn, United Kingdom, has an established pedigree of delivering a world class fuel, grocery &
merchandise and foodservice offer and currently employs in excess of 44,000 people working in more than
6,000 sites across Europe, USA and Australia. The Issa Brothers were honoured as Commanders of the
Order of the British Empire by HM The Queen in her Birthday Honours List 2020 for their contribution to
business and charity. They were also jointly named the 2018 EY Entrepreneur of the Year in the United
Kingdom.

TDR Capital LLP is a leading European private equity firm based in the United Kingdom, managing over
€10.0 billion of committed capital across three European buyout funds. Founded in 2002 by Manjit Dale
and Stephen Robertson, TDR Capital LLP has been creating value by applying a high-impact approach to
investing in a focused portfolio of companies. TDR Capital LLP has a proven value-based and operationally
focused investment strategy, which is delivered by a dedicated team of investment and operating
professionals from its single office in London. TDR's strong returns have been driven by combining
ambitious operational plans for portfolio companies with a rigorous focus on capital preservation. TDR
Capital LLP takes an active role in overseeing the transformation and growth of its investments, working in
partnership with management through board representation and professional support. To date, TDR has
completed 22 investments across the leisure, consumer, business and financial services sectors.

Walmart Inc. helps people around the world save money and live better – anytime and anywhere – by
providing the opportunity to shop in retail stores and through eCommerce. Each week, Walmart serves
over 265 million customers who visit approximately 11,400 stores and numerous eCommerce websites
under 55 banners in 26 countries. Walmart is engaged in global operations of retail, wholesale and other
units, as well as eCommerce, located throughout the U.S., Africa, Canada, Central America, Chile, China,
India, Japan, Mexico and the United Kingdom.

**Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco Shareholders' Agreement**

Prior to the completion of the Transactions, Able Holdings Limited (a company owned by Zuber Vali
Issa CBE and Mohsin Issa CBE), Optima Group S.à r.l., Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco will
enter into a shareholders' agreement (the "Shareholders' Agreement"), which will govern various rights
of the shareholders of Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco in relation to their direct shareholding in
Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco and indirect shareholding in the Group.

Pursuant to the Shareholders' Agreement, Able Holdings Limited (the "Individual Investors
**Shareholder"), on the one hand, and Optima Group S.à r.l. (the "TDR Shareholder"), on the other hand,**
will be entitled to appoint or remove directors in certain circumstances. The Individual Investors
Shareholder and the TDR Shareholder will each be entitled to appoint and remove (i) two members of the
board of directors of Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco so long as such shareholder, together with
its affiliates, hold 35% or more of the share capital of Bellis TopCo Limited or Property Newco (as
applicable), or (ii) one member of the board of directors of Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco so
long as such shareholders, together with its affiliates, hold between 15% and 35% of the share capital of
Bellis TopCo Limited or Property Newco (as applicable). The maximum number of directors for the board
of Bellis TopCo Limited or Property Newco (as applicable) will be five and, subject to certain actions which
required the consent of the Individual Investors Shareholder and the TDR Shareholder, as summarised
below, all decisions of the board of directors may be made by a majority of the votes cast.

228


-----

The Shareholders' Agreement will provide that certain actions in relation to the Group may not be taken
without the consent of either of the Individual Investors Shareholder (or any of the directors appointed by
it) and the TDR Shareholder (or any of the directors appointed by it). These include amendments to the
organisational documents of any member of the Group, variations to the rights attaching to the shares in
any member of the Group, the declaration or payment of any dividend or distribution by any Group company
(other than to Bellis TopCo Limited, Property Newco or another Group company which is wholly-owned by
Bellis TopCo Limited or Property Newco), a material change in the nature or scope of the Group's business
and the winding-up or dissolution of Bellis TopCo Limited, Property Newco, any of their subsidiaries or any
other Group company.

The Shareholders' Agreement will contain certain restrictions on the transfer by the Individual Investors
Shareholder or the TDR Shareholder of its shares in Bellis TopCo Limited, Property Newco or any other
member of the Group, including (other than transfers to certain permitted transferees, including affiliates)
an obligation to first offer any shares to the other shareholder before offering them for sale to a third party.

At any time on or after the third anniversary of the Acquisition Completion Date either the Individual
Investors Shareholder or the TDR Shareholder may propose an exit event involving the Bellis Group and
the Group, including the sale of shares in Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco; the sale by Bellis
TopCo Limited, Property Newco or any other member of the Group of all or substantially all of its business,
assets and undertaking; any public offering in respect of any shares in Bellis TopCo Limited, Property
Newco or any other Group company; the reorganisation of Bellis TopCo Limited or any other Group
company and the winding up of Bellis TopCo Limited in each case, on specified terms and subject to the
occurrence of certain conditions (an "Exit"). The recipient of such proposal regarding an Exit shall consider
such proposal in good faith, but shall not be obliged to accept such proposal. At any time on or following
the fifth anniversary of the Acquisition Completion Date either the Individual Investors Shareholder or the
TDR Shareholder may propose an Exit involving the Bellis Group and the Group. The recipient of such
proposal shall be required to accept such proposal provided that certain conditions are satisfied.

**Walmart Senior Shares and Special Participation Share**

On the Acquisition Completion Date, Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, Bellis TopCo Limited and Global Pinnacle
Corporation (among others) expect to enter into a shareholders' agreement (the "Topco 2 Shareholders'
**Agreement"), which will govern various rights of the shareholders of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited in relation to**
their direct shareholding in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited and indirect shareholding in the Group. The terms of the
Topco 2 Shareholders' Agreement will provide for Global Pinnacle Corporation to hold two classes of
shares: (i) the Senior Shares; and (ii) the Special Participation Share. Unless otherwise agreed between
the shareholders of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited (or where such transfer is made to a permitted transferee in
accordance with the terms of the Topco 2 Shareholders' Agreement or with the consent of the
shareholders), neither the Special Participation Share nor any of the Senior Shares may be transferred to
any person unless there is a simultaneous transfer of all of the Senior Shares and the Special Participation
Share to the same transferee.

Pursuant to the Topco 2 Shareholders' Agreement, Global Pinnacle Corporation, as holder of the Senior
Shares, will be entitled to appoint or remove one director to or from the board of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited
(the "Senior Shareholder Director"). The holder of the Senior Shares will have no voting rights as
shareholders of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, other than in relation to certain matters that would materially
adversely affect the rights of the holder of the Senior Shares.

The holders of the Senior Shares will have the right to receive an annual fixed cumulative senior
dividend. Such dividend is payable on the principal amount of the Senior Shares plus accrued but unpaid
dividends. Bellis TopCo 2 Limited may elect to pay such dividend in cash or for such dividend to accrue
unpaid.

The Senior Shares will be mandatorily redeemed by Bellis TopCo 2 Limited upon the occurrence of
certain events, including upon an exit event involving Bellis TopCo 2 Limited. Such exit events include: the

member of the Group of all or substantially all of its business, assets and undertaking; any public offering
in respect of any shares in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited or any other Group company; or a change of control of
Bellis TopCo 2 Limited. The Senior Shares will further be mandatorily redeemed by Bellis TopCo 2 Limited
on the seventh anniversary of the issuance of the Senior Shares. Bellis TopCo 2 Limited may voluntarily
redeem the Senior Shares at any time subject to paying a make-whole amount.

The holder of the Special Participation Share will have the right to participate in 10% of any dividends

price equal to 10% of the listing value of the fully diluted issued share capital of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited
following the completion of such public offering, subject to a minimum hurdle amount.

The Group enters into transactions with certain related parties or the Group's affiliates from time to time

**Transitional Agreements with Walmart**

On or around the Acquisition Completion Date, ASL and Walmart expect to enter into an ancillary
services agreement (the "ASA"), a trade mark agreement (the "TMA"), a transitional services agreement
(the "TSA"), ASL and Walmart (or, if agreed between the parties prior to the Acquisition Completion Date,
a Walmart affiliate) expect to enter into a global sourcing agreement (the "GSA"), the Company and
Walmart expect to enter into a deed of termination and release (the "Termination Deed") and the Seller,
the Purchaser and Walmart (among others) expect to enter into a transitional pensions deed (the "TPD").
In addition, a Transitional Electricity Supply Agreement (the "TESA") is expected to be entered into between
a subsidiary of Walmart (Texas Retail Energy LLC ("TRE")) and an ASDA entity called Power 4 All, on or
around the Acquisition Completion Date. The ASA, the TMA, the TSA, the Termination Deed, the GSA, the
TPD, and the TESA are referred to collectively in this Offering Memorandum as the "Transitional
**Agreements."**

**_Ancillary Services Agreement_**

Under the ASA, Walmart will agree to share (at quarterly meetings with ASL, or more frequently if
requested by ASL, acting reasonably) information on information technology developments, research,
know-how and innovation (collectively, "Innovation") that may be relevant to ASL's business in the United
Kingdom and which Walmart is using or intends to use within the Walmart Group from time to time. Walmart
will grant ASL a limited, non-exclusive licence of Walmart's intellectual property rights in respect of any
Innovation disclosed to ASL to enable ASL to evaluate such Innovation for use by ASL in the United
Kingdom. If ASL wishes to implement any Innovation, the parties will enter into good faith discussions on
the terms of that implementation (including the relevant charging model) which will be documented in a
separate written licence or agreement between the parties. Although Walmart's obligation to share
Innovation-related information will be effective from the Acquisition Completion Date, Walmart will not be
required to assist ASL with the implementation of any Innovation unless the parties agree otherwise and
reach a separate agreement.

The ASA will include customary warranties on the corporate existence and capacity of the parties. No
fee will be payable by ASL for the information-sharing services set out in the ASA. Walmart's liability to
ASL will be excluded in respect of the provision or receipt of the information-sharing services (subject to
certain exceptions including for fraud and for wilful breach of the ASA). The liability of both parties in relation
to the wider agreement will be excluded in respect of indirect or consequential loss or any loss of profit or
revenue, and ASL's liability to Walmart will be excluded where the loss is attributable to a breach by
Walmart of the ASA or TSA (both preceding exclusions subject to certain exceptions including for fraud).
The ASA will remain in force for two years following the date of its execution unless it is terminated by one
of the parties following the insolvency of its counterparty, a material breach of its terms (subject to a notice
requirement and a 30-day cure period, to the extent the breach is remediable) or by one of the parties
following its counterparty undergoing a force majeure event which has a material effect on the performance
of the counterparty's obligations.

**_Trade Mark Agreement_**

Under the terms of the TMA, Walmart, as licensor, will grant ASL a licence to continue to use certain of
Walmart's trade marks, domain names and brand-related intellectual property. The scope of the TMA is
expected to include licences of the George, Scan & Go, Smart Price and Rollback brands, certain domain
names, including George.com, as well as certain other Walmart-owned trade mark rights used by a
member of the ASDA Group between October 2019 and the Acquisition Completion Date (the "Licensed
**IP"). The TMA is expected to permit ASL to sub-license the use of the Licensed IP to specified permitted**
sub-licensees, including members of the ASDA Group, existing franchisees to which ASL has granted a
licence of the Licensed IP under franchise agreements in place as at the date of the Acquisition Agreement
and certain specified companies that are also owned by the Shareholders or funds managed by TDR
Capital LLP, provided Walmart is given written notice and the sub-licence fulfils certain conditions, including
that it is on terms that are no less onerous than the TMA. Additionally, the TMA is expected to provide that
Walmart cannot unreasonably withhold, delay or condition consent for ASL to sub-license the Licensed IP
to certain other entities including those that are controlled by the shareholders of ASL's ultimate holding
company, provided that the sub-licence fulfils certain conditions, including that it is on terms no less onerous
that the TMA.

-----

Manufacturing or packaging of goods bearing the Licensed IP may take place worldwide. The scope of
the licence for sale, marketing and distribution purposes is expected to be the United Kingdom only (on an

Completion Date, although it is expected that ASL will not be required to remove from sale or destroy any

"Save Money Live Better" (in respect of new marketing communications and new internal communications
in the United Kingdom) until the end of 2021 or, if earlier, the implementation of ASL's new business

to be required to be in the same manner and style of usage as used between October 2019 and the
Acquisition Completion Date, except in respect of the George RoW Licence and licence of the Walmart
spark logo, which must be used in the same way as such branding was used immediately prior to the date
of the Acquisition Agreement and the Acquisition Completion Date respectively.

The TMA is also expected to include: (i) an exclusive, royalty-free licence from ASL to Walmart of the
Extra Special brand (that is owned by ASDA) to enable Walmart to continue selling, marketing and
distributing products sold by Walmart under such brand on a perpetual and irrevocable basis in specified

ASL to Walmart of other ASDA-owned brands for 12 months to continue printing packaging in respect of
any other products sold, marketed or distributed by Walmart under such ASDA-owned brands, and in
respect of the territories in respect of which such products were sold, marketed or distributed by Walmart,
between October 2019 and the Acquisition Completion Date (and then a licence to sell down those
products, provided that Walmart uses commercially reasonable efforts to sell off all products in packaging
bearing such brands as soon as reasonably practicable following the expiry of such 12-month period and
in any event within two years of the Acquisition Completion Date, although it is expected that Walmart will
not be required to remove from sale or destroy any packaging bearing such logo on goods which are
available for purchase within any of Walmart's stores at the end of the two year period). In respect of (ii)
above, the relevant ASL brands must be used by Walmart in the same way and to the same extent as used
by Walmart immediately prior to the Acquisition Completion Date. The licence to Walmart of the ASL brands
referred to above is expected to be subject to similar sub-licencing and termination provisions as the licence
to ASL of Licensed IP.

ASL is expected not to be required to pay any royalties in respect of the above licence of the George
brand (other than George RoW Licence), the licences of the Scan & Go, Rollback and Smart Price brands
or the transitional licence of the Walmart spark logo and "Save Money Live Better" (other than a nominal
£1 royalty fee). The George RoW Licence is expected to be royalty-free for up to 12 months (or earlier if
ASL achieves a $25 million threshold of net sales revenue in respect of its use of the George brand under
the George RoW Licence outside the United Kingdom and the European countries specified in the TMA)
and thereafter subject to the parties, discussing in good faith and at arm's-length with a view to agreeing a
commercially reasonable royalty (otherwise the George RoW Licence will be terminated). In respect of all
other Licensed IP, ASL will be required to pay an annual royalty equal to 3.5% of the net sales revenue
received by ASL and any sub-licensees in connection with the use of such Licensed IP.

The TMA is expected to include restrictions and quality control covenants from ASL including ensuring
that the products sold by ASL under the Licensed IP maintain certain standards, complying with brand
guidelines in relation to visual style and formatting and limiting ASL's use of the Licensed IP and its ability
to register the Licensed IP. These covenants are expected to include not committing or knowingly omitting
acts which would bring the Licensed IP into disrepute or damage, or weaken or be detrimental to the
Licensed IP in any material respect. ASL is also expected to be prevented from maintaining an online or ecommerce presence of any of the businesses (excluding the George business in the United Kingdom) in
respect of which the Licensed IP is permitted to be used except in substantially the same manner and to
substantially the same extent as the presence those businesses had in the period between October 2019

232


-----

and the Acquisition Completion Date (or in respect of the George RoW Licence, immediately prior to the
date of the Acquisition Agreement). ASL is also expected to indemnify the Walmart Group against any
losses resulting from use of the Licensed IP in material breach of the TMA and losses related to actual or
alleged defect in products or services using the Licensed IP (other than the Scan & Go or Rollback
branding), recalls of defective products and actual or alleged mislabelling or food safety issues related to
the Licensed IP (other than the Scan & Go or Rollback brands). There is expected to be no cap on ASL's

warranties or representations (and any implied warranties, terms or conditions implied by statute or
common law are excluded to the fullest extent permitted by law).

The term of the TMA is expected to be perpetual (other than: (i) the George RoW Licence, which will

IP in that country (or if required by law), and (ii) in respect of the transitional licences described above).
Either party is expected to be able to terminate the licences expected to be granted to ASL under the TMA
on a per-licence basis following the insolvency of its counterparty or a material breach or repeated nonmaterial breaches of the terms of the TMA (in respect of the relevant licence and/or the relevant Licensed
IP) (subject to a notice requirement and a 30-day cure period, to the extent applicable). Walmart is also
expected to have the right to terminate the licences granted to ASL under the TMA on a per-licence basis
if ASL challenges the validity of the relevant Licensed IP or following certain change of control events, or
with respect to specific trade marks or specific categories or sub-categories of goods or services on 30
days' notice if the relevant Licensed IP is not put to material use for a period of two years. ASL, but not

expected to be separately terminable, under similar terms.

**_Transitional Services Agreement_**

Under the TSA, Walmart is expected to agree to provide certain information technology services to ASL
on a transitional basis with effect from the Acquisition Completion Date. The services are expected to
comprise all information technology and telecommunications services (and related operational system
processes) that Walmart Group Companies provided to the ASDA Group in the 12 months prior to the
Acquisition Completion Date, and each such service is expected to be supplied by Walmart until the earlier
of (i) migration of the relevant service as part of the separation of ASL from Walmart; and (ii) termination of
the TSA in accordance with its terms by one of the parties (as summarised below). The services are
arranged into six categories (referred to as "service towers," which relate to stores, supply chain,
merchandising, back office, e-commerce and infrastructure/security) for charging and migration purposes.

ASL is expected to have the right to terminate any service tower, or the TSA in its entirety, on three
months' notice. In addition, either party is expected to have the right to terminate the TSA following the
insolvency of its counterparty or a material breach of the terms of the TSA (subject to a notice requirement
and a 30-day cure period, to the extent applicable).

The TSA is expected to include customary warranties concerning the corporate existence and capacity
of the parties and an undertaking to provide information and participate in discussions in connection with
the delivery of the services. Walmart is expected to agree to provide each service to a standard and in a
manner that is consistent with Walmart's provision of the equivalent service in the 12 months prior to the
Acquisition Completion Date. Walmart is not expected to be required to provide the services to, or to meet,
any more onerous standard or service level.

Walmart is expected to be required to use reasonable endeavours to obtain and maintain third-party
consents that are required for the provision of the services. Where a third-party consent is not obtained or
maintained, Walmart is not expected to be required to provide the relevant service (and the TSA will
terminate in respect of the relevant service without liability on the part of Walmart) and the parties will work
together to agree a workaround (including replacement, in-sourcing or early migration) in order to enable
ASL to continue to receive the benefit of the affected service. All reasonable one-off or ongoing costs of
obtaining and maintaining third-party consents or implementing workarounds are to be borne by ASL,
subject to Walmart consulting with ASL before incurring these costs.

The TSA is expected to require ASL and Walmart to agree to a separation plan within 120 days after
the Acquisition Completion Date and cooperate in achieving separation. Separation costs (excluding
internal costs of the Walmart Group) are to be borne by ASL.

The charges for the TSA services for the first year following the Acquisition Completion Date are
expected to be initially equal to and are capped at £142 million (excluding any VAT) (which the TSA is
expected to state has been calculated according to the actual amount of the 2019 intra-group charges

233


-----

incurred by the ASDA Group in respect of the equivalent services), subject to specified adjustments set out
in the TSA, and the cap on service charges subsequently rises by 1% per year thereafter. The charges
payable for services in subsequent years are expected to be equal to the charges for such services for the
previous contract year (subject to any reduction as summarised below) subject to an inflationary increase
of 2% per year. The charges per service tower are split on a fixed cost and variable cost basis. The variable
proportion of the charges is expected to reduce to the extent that ASL is able to achieve certain agreed
milestones in its separation plan and ramp down usage of the relevant service tower. If ASL requires any
service to be provided beyond a long stop date of three years from the Acquisition Completion Date, the
charges for any remaining services will ratchet up by 10% every six months.

The liability of the parties under the TSA is expected to be limited, where service-specific, to the amount
of fees paid or payable in respect of the relevant service tower during the relevant contract year. In the
case of liabilities that are not related to a specific service tower, the liability of the parties under the TSA is
expected to be limited to the total amount of fees paid or payable during the relevant contract year. Each
party's aggregate liability for each contract year is expected to be limited to the amount of fees paid or
payable during the relevant contract year. These limitations are expected to be subject to limited
exceptions, including in the case of fraud. Neither party is expected to be liable for any indirect or
consequential losses or loss of profit or loss of revenue and, to the extent Walmart's breach is caused by
a third-party default, Walmart's maximum liability to ASL is expected to be limited to the amount that
Walmart can recover from the third party (or an equitable proportion thereof to reflect the loss suffered by
the ASDA Group as compared to the Walmart Group). Walmart is not expected to be liable to ASL to the
extent the relevant liability is caused by a failure on the part of the ASDA Group to perform its obligations
under the TSA.

**_Global Sourcing Agreement_**

Under the GSA, Walmart (or, if agreed between the parties to the GSA, an affiliate of Walmart) is
expected to provide ASL with (or to procure the provision to ASL of) global sourcing services in relation to
apparel and non-apparel, including identifying manufacturers and suppliers on behalf of ASL and
supporting ASL's buyers in ASL's negotiation of prices, placing of orders and arranging of shipments. The
term of the GSA is expected to be two years from the Acquisition Completion Date unless the parties agree
to extend the GSA or the GSA is terminated earlier (in accordance with the termination rights summarised
below). During the initial two-year term, ASL is to pay to Walmart a commission of 5% of the net first cost
of merchandise procured by Walmart under the GSA. If the term is extended beyond the initial two-year
term, ASL will pay a new rate of commission agreed between the parties.

The GSA is expected to include customary warranties on the corporate existence and capacity of the
parties. ASL is expected to indemnify Walmart against claims for product liability or intellectual property
infringement resulting from goods sourced under the GSA (other than claims arising from the gross
negligence or intentional tort of Walmart under the GSA).

Each party is expected to have a right to terminate the GSA for material breach (subject to a notice
requirement and a 30-day cure period) or insolvency of the other or a force majeure event which has a
material adverse effect on the performance of the other party's obligations. Walmart is also expected to
have the right to terminate (subject to a notice period) if ASL is not making material use of the services
(determined by reference to a minimum purchase spend in respect of apparel and non-apparel shipped to
ASL in a rolling 12-month period). ASL is expected to have the right to terminate the GSA for convenience
on six months' written notice to Walmart.

Neither party is expected to be liable in respect of loss of profit or revenue and indirect or consequential
loss, and each party's liability to the other party is expected to be limited to an amount equal to 100% of
the aggregate of all commission that has been paid or would be payable to Walmart in, in the case of the
first contract year, that year, or, in any subsequent year, in the previous year (both preceding limits on
liability subject to certain exceptions including liability for fraud, gross negligence of Walmart or any of its
subcontractors and non-payment by ASL of due and undisputed charges).

**_Transitional Electricity Supply Agreement_**

Under the TESA, a subsidiary of Walmart, TRE, is expected to continue following the Acquisition
Completion Date to support Asda in the purchase of electricity and services that surround that purchase.
TRE have been providing this service since 2008 to an Asda entity called Power 4 All ("P4A"). P4A is a
licensed electricity supplier under the Electricity Act 1989 and that leads to a level of reporting which TRE
will continue to support for the term of the TESA. There are also multiple forward purchase trades of energy
in place with counterparties that are backed by Walmart Group guarantees. The intent is for Asda to procure
electricity and services from a new third party and when those arrangements are in place it is intended that
the trades are novated to the new supplier and the guarantees in respect to them will fall away. In addition,
Walmart is expected to retain some additional Walmart Group guarantees in favour of Distribution Network

234


-----

Operators in respect to P4A payment obligations for the term of the TESA to allow Asda to arrange for
replacement security (if required) to be put in place.

As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the specific services TRE will offer, the price and service
levels are being negotiated. However, the principle has been agreed that TRE will continue to provide the
services that it is currently supplying for the term of the TESA, together with some transitional support to
allow Asda to take over the management of P4A. The parties intend the TESA to run until March 31, 2021
and no further.

**_Transitional Pensions Deed_**

Under the TPD, the Seller is expected to indemnify the Purchaser in respect of any losses incurred by
ASDA in respect of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme, provided that the indemnity will not apply if the
losses arise from a voluntary act by the Purchaser (or any other affiliate of Bellis TopCo Limited), including
failure by ASDA to comply with its obligations under the documentation governing the ASDA Group Pension
Scheme Buy-In (described in Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results
of Operations above). Walmart is party to the TPD and is expected to guarantee the obligations of the
Seller in respect of this indemnity. The Purchaser and Bellis TopCo Limited are expected to agree to
indemnify ASDA and Walmart in respect of any losses incurred by either of them in respect of the ASDA
Group Pension Scheme if the losses arise from a voluntary act by the Purchaser (or any other affiliate of
Bellis TopCo Limited), including failure by ASDA to comply with its obligations under the documentation
governing the ASDA Group Pension Scheme Buy-In. Liability under both indemnity arrangements is
expected to terminate on the later of: (i) three years after completion of the buyout of the ASDA Group
Pension Scheme; (ii) the date of completion of the winding-up of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme; or (iii)
(in respect of losses relate to tax only) five years after the Acquisition Completion Date. As described in in
Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations above, as part
of the arrangements in respect of the buy-in of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme ASL agreed to make a
loan facility available to the trustees of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme. Under the TPD, in the event
that a funding obligation arises under the loan facility which ASDA it is unable to satisfy, Walmart Inc is
expected to agree to use reasonable endeavours to provide short-term funding to ASDA to allow ASDA to
meet the funding obligation. Under the TPD, Bellis TopCo Limited and ASDA are expected to agree to use
all reasonable endeavours to complete the buyout of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme as soon as
reasonably practicable and to keep Walmart informed of progress towards completion.

**_Deed of Termination and Release_**

Under the terms of the Termination Deed, Walmart is expected to unconditionally and irrevocably agree
in respect of itself, and on behalf of each other Walmart Group Company, and the Company is expected
to unconditionally and irrevocably agree in respect of itself, and on behalf of each other member of the
ASDA Group that any intra-group arrangement between any one or more Walmart Group Companies and
any one or more members of the ASDA Group immediately prior to Completion are terminated upon
Completion and each member of the Walmart Group and each member of the ASDA Group is released
and discharged from all claims or demands by the other under, or in connection with, such intra-group
arrangements (including without limitation claims for negligence but excluding liability for fraud), whether
arising at or before the termination of such intra-group arrangement, in each case whether known or
unknown to Walmart or ASDA (excluding amounts outstanding, or which are to be invoiced, under the
terms of such intra-group arrangements by or from one party to the other for services performed prior to
the Acquisition Completion Date). Certain arrangements are expected to be carved-out from this
termination and release notably the (i) Acquisition Agreement, (ii) documents entered into pursuant to the
Acquisition Agreement (including the Transitional Agreements), (iii) intra-group arrangements relating to
the ASDA Group Pension Scheme; and (iv) any arrangements or guarantees between TRE, any member
of the Walmart Group and/or any third party(ies) relating to the supply of energy or energy-related services
in favour, or for the benefit, of ASDA. The Termination Deed is not expected to terminate, release or
discharge obligations in respect of intra-group indebtedness between the Walmart Group and ASDA or in
respect of intra-group trading payables and trading receivables between the Walmart Group and ASDA,
which in each case are to be repaid or settled in accordance with the Acquisition Agreement.

**_Overview and Structure_**

In connection with the financing of the Acquisition, on February 5, 2021 the Senior Secured Notes Issuer
entered into a senior facilities agreement with, among others, Barclays Bank PLC, Bank of America Europe
Designated Activity Company, Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch, HSBC Bank plc, Lloyds Bank plc,
Morgan Stanley Bank International Limited, Coöperatieve Rabobank U.A. trading as Rabobank London,
Bank of China Limited, London Branch, Commerzbank Aktiengesellschaft, London Branch, Intesa
Sanpaolo S.p.A., London Branch, National Westminster Bank Plc and SMBC Bank International PLC as
mandated lead arrangers, the Agent and the Security Agent (the "Senior Facilities Agreement").

The Senior Facilities Agreement provides for (i) a senior term loan facility in principal amount of up to
£195,000,000 ("Facility A"), (ii) euro- and sterling-denominated senior term loan facilities (collectively,
"Facility B") in an aggregate amount of £1,390,000,000 (equivalent) and (iii) revolving credit facilities in a
principal amount of £500,000,000 (the "Original Revolving Facility 1") and £190,000,000 (the "Original
**Revolving Facility 2," together with the Original Revolving Facility 1, the "Revolving Credit Facilities,"**
and the Revolving Credit Facilities together with Facility A and Facility B, the "Senior Facilities"). The
Facility B (EUR) (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) is subject to certain redenomination
mechanics pursuant to which the Facility B (EUR) will be redenominated into Euro in the event that closing
occurs prior to pricing, with alternative redenomination mechanics in the event that closing occurs after
pricing, in each case in accordance with the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement).

**_Borrowers, Currencies and Utilisations_**

Facility A and Facility B are expected to be utilised by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer on the
Acquisition Completion Date and the proceeds of such utilisation are required to be applied (directly or
indirect) in or towards financing the Acquisition.

The Revolving Credit Facilities may be utilised by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and certain of its
restricted subsidiaries which accede to the Senior Facilities Agreement as additional borrowers of such
facilities, in sterling, euro or U.S. dollars and certain other currencies readily available in the amount
required and freely convertible into sterling in the Relevant Interbank Market (subject to obtaining consent
of the relevant lenders under the relevant Revolving Credit Facility), by the drawing of cash advances, the
issue of Letters of Credit and by way of Ancillary Facilities or Fronted Ancillary Facilities (each as defined
in the Senior Facilities Agreement).

If we settle the Offering after the Acquisition Completion Date, a portion of the initial drawings under
Facility B under the Senior Facilities Agreement will be repaid with the proceeds of the Senior Secured
Notes. The Senior Facilities Agreement is expected to be amended and restated either prior to or shortly
following the Acquisition Completion Date to make certain changes, including making Facility B an all eurodenominated facility (the "Amended SFA").

**_Purpose_**

All amounts borrowed under Facility A and Facility B are required to be applied (directly or indirectly) in
or towards: (i) satisfaction of the consideration payable for the Acquisition (including any interest payments,
completion account-related adjustments and purchase price adjustments (however structured)) and any
other amounts payable under the Acquisition Documents (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement);
(ii) refinancing or otherwise discharging any existing indebtedness of the ASDA Group (including
backstopping or providing cash-cover in respect of any letters of credit, guarantees, performance bonds or
ancillary, revolving, working capital or local facilities or other arrangements) and paying any related
breakage costs, redemption premium, make-whole costs and other fees, costs and expenses payable in
connection with such refinancing, discharge and/or the Acquisition; (iii) financing or refinancing the payment
of any transaction costs or paying any other related fees, costs and expenses; and/or (iv) making any

242


-----

payments contemplated by the Tax Structure Memorandum, the Funds Flow Statement (each as defined
in the Senior Facilities Agreement) or any other documents relating to the Transactions.

The Revolving Credit Facilities may be used for: (i) financing or refinancing: (A) the general corporate
purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Group (including, without limitation, the financing or
refinancing of capital expenditure, any permitted acquisitions (including the Acquisition), investments, jointventures, restructuring costs, operational restructurings and reorganisation requirements of the Group); (B)
the financial indebtedness of the Group, the ASDA Group or any acquired target group; and (C) any
required arrangement, up-front or original issue discount fees or similar fees or any additional original issue
discount fees or other fees arising as a result of any Market Flex (as defined in the Senior Facilities
Agreement), any ticking fees required to be paid in connection with, and any interest accruing under the
documents relating to the Transactions or any other Debt Document (as defined in the Intercreditor
Agreement (as defined below)) or any other fees, costs and expenses; (ii) to backstop existing ancillary
facilities, letters of credit and/or hedging arrangements of the ASDA Group (if applicable) and financing or
refinancing any other transactions contemplated in connection with the Acquisition; (iii) financing any other
payments identified in the Tax Structure Memorandum or the Funds Flow Statement (each as defined in
the Senior Facilities Agreement) or the documents relating to the Transactions; and (iv) financing or
refinancing the costs relating to the Acquisition and any other costs and expenses incurred in relation to
the purposes referred to in paragraphs (i) to (iii) above.

In addition to the Senior Facilities, the Senior Facilities Agreement includes (subject to the limitation on
indebtedness covenant and permissions thereunder) the ability to establish an additional facility
("Additional Facility") at any time provided certain conditions under the Senior Facilities Agreement are
met, including, without limitation: (i) Indebtedness incurred thereunder constitute Permitted Indebtedness
on the Applicable Test Date; (ii) no Material Event of Default (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement)
is continuing as at the Additional Facility Commencement Date or Applicable Test Date (as applicable) for
such Additional Facility; (iii) the Additional Facility complies with any applicable margin, maturity and
amortisation restrictions set out in the Senior Facilities Agreement and (iv) the Additional Facility shall rank
_pari passu with or junior to Facility A and Facility B._

**_Availability_**

Facility A and Facility B are available to be utilised from (and including) the date of the Senior Facilities
Agreement to and including the last day of the Certain Funds Period (as defined in the Senior Facilities
Agreement).

The Revolving Credit Facilities may be utilised from (and including) the Closing Date (as defined in the
Senior Facilities Agreement) to and including the date falling one month prior to the respective termination
dates of the Revolving Credit Facilities. The Original Revolving Facility 1 has a termination date falling
54 months after the Closing Date, and the Original Revolving Facility 2 has a termination date falling
364 days after the Closing Date. The Original Revolving Facility 2 may not be utilised unless on the
proposed Utilisation Date the Original Revolving Facility 1 is utilised in full (but, for the avoidance of doubt,
the Original Revolving Facility 2 may be utilised contemporaneously with the Original Revolving Facility 1).

**_Conditions Precedent_**

Utilisations of the Senior Facilities are subject to customary conditions precedent.

**_Interest and Fees_**

Loans under the Senior Facilities will initially bear interest at rates per annum equal to EURIBOR in
respect of loans denominated in euro, and for loans denominated other than in euro, LIBOR, plus an
applicable margin, which in each case will be subject to a decreasing margin ratchet based on the ratio of
Consolidated Senior Secured Net Debt to Consolidated EBITDA (each as defined in the Senior Facilities
Agreement) (the "Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio"). Furthermore, the applicable margin shall be
subject to further adjustment upwards or downwards depending on whether the Group's ESG Agency
Rating (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) (the "ESG Agency Rating") is more or less
favourable, respectively, than the initial ESG Agency Rating obtained by the Group following the Closing
Date.

If EURIBOR is less than zero, EURIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under
Facility B and the Revolving Credit Facilities (as applicable). If LIBOR is less than zero, LIBOR shall be
deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under Facility A and the Revolving Credit Facilities (as
applicable).

A commitment fee will be payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of each Revolving
Credit Facility from the Closing Date (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) to the end of the
availability period applicable to the relevant Revolving Credit Facility at a rate of 30% of the applicable

243


-----

margin for the relevant Revolving Credit Facility. Commitment fees will be payable quarterly in arrears, on
the last day of the availability period applicable to the relevant Revolving Credit Facility and if the relevant
Revolving Facility is cancelled in full, on the date on which the relevant commitments under that Revolving
Facility are cancelled.

Default interest will be calculated as an additional 1% on the defaulted amount.

The Senior Facilities Agreement will permit voluntary prepayments to be made (subject to de minimis

In addition, upon the occurrence of a Change of Control (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement),

Senior Secured Notes Issuer, subject to certain conditions; and

Group, subject to certain exceptions.
